PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered, the Senate meet on Friday, 19 November 1982, at 9 a.m., and that the sessional order relating to the adjournment of the Senate have effect at 4.30 p.m. on that day.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Ryan and at her request and in accordance with notice of intention to withdraw given yesterday, I now withdraw Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 1 for the next day of sitting, standing in the name of Senator Ryan, for the disallowance of the Fire Brigade (Administration) (Amendment) Ordinance 1982 as contained in the Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 21 of 1982.

—I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, although I realise that it might be referred to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. I refer to a report in today's Canberra Times which states that Trans Australia Airlines has told airline unions that it wants to cut its staff by 350 by early next year. Has TAA informed the Government of its plan to reduce its staff? Has the Government made any plans to assist those airline employees who will find themselves out of work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been well known for some time that TAA has been in a very difficult financial position. Substantial losses were incurred in 1981-82. It has been acknowledged for some time that retrenchments would need to be undertaken by TAA. In fact, I think an announcement was made some two months ago in that respect. Naturally, it would be the Government's concern to see that those who were retrenched found work in other areas as quickly as possible. The Government would be concerned as to the outcome. To obtain information on measures that might be taken in respect of the kind of situation outlined by Senator Colston I will need to refer the question to the Minister. I undertake to do so.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Health to an Age poll of 8 November 1982 which indicates the attitude of a representative sample of 2,000 people of voting age to smoking in public places. Will the Minister comment on this poll in which 81 per cent of the respondents thought that people should not be free to smoke in doctors' waiting rooms; 70 per cent on public transport; 58 per cent in restaurants; 54 per cent in aeroplanes; 50 per cent in taxis; and 44 per cent in public buildings? In view of the obvious hardening of community attitudes towards smoking in public places I ask the Minister--

—I can understand the sufferings of honourable senators opposite but we have to help them out of their problems. I ask the Minister: Firstly, what action will be taken by the Government to ensure that the rights of non- smokers and, in particular, those people who are forced to become involuntary smokers are recognised and protected? Secondly, what steps, if any, have been taken by the Government to protect the rights of non-smokers in the Commonwealth Public Service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the poll which appeared in the Melbourne Age but I am aware of the emerging majority of Australians who share the attitudes which Senator Missen has set out in his question as coming from that poll and indicating the views of citizens. A majority of Australians now share the views expressed by Senator Missen. Smokers who exercise their right to smoke are a minority of the community. Senator Missen's question falls into two parts. Some of the matters raised in the Age poll really fall within State areas of responsibility. For example, I do not think that the Commonwealth could legislate in regard to taxis, restaurants, doctors' waiting rooms, et cetera.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth can have an interest in the second part of Senator Missen's question which relates to Commonwealth Public Service operations and the rights of non-smokers within the Commonwealth Public Service. It is my understanding, without having any detailed information with me, that there is a code within the Commonwealth Public Service which attempts to regulate the rights of smokers and non-smokers; that there is a provision for the setting aside of non-smoking areas in buildings and in departments; that smoking is not allowed in public areas or lifts in Commonwealth Public Service areas; that negotiation generally takes place with those officers of the Public Service who want to work in smoke free areas; and that non-smoking areas are provided. The Commonwealth has a policy in place and it is being extended, mostly by negotiation and agreement. This is the way in which we have tried to move. I cannot answer the honourable senator about what is happening in other areas, some of which are outside our control. I think he will agree that the effort to move within the Public Service represents an attempt to respond to what is an emerging majority view in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he saw an article in last weekend's National Times which stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Australia is a party to a . . . international agreement whose details appear to have been kept from every responsible minister for over 30 years.

Did the article also claim that the agreement covered eavesdropping of confidential communications and that the agreement, called the UKUSA Agreement, dates back to 1947? Was the article correct in respect of these claims? What action has the Government taken to discover the full extent of the agreement? Is the Government satisfied that the agreement was never kept from it in the last seven years? If not, what action will be taken to ensure that such a breach of the principles of ministerial responsibility does not recur?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no recollection of the article and therefore I cannot comment on it. I will seek out the article, refer it to the responsible Minister and ask for a response.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction: What is the current estimated cost of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway line? What is the current estimated cost of supplying the rolling stock, engines and infrastructure required for this vital link?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will need to seek that detailed information from my colleague, and I undertake to do so.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction and refers to the Minister's announcement that the Australian maritime industry has established a peak council of Australian ship owners and maritime unions. Is the Minister confident that this new body will help to reduce significantly the ridiculously high number of waterfront disputes which are costing shippers and exporters many millions of dollars a year as well as harming Australia's reputation as a reliable trader?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters is well known for her concern about matters affecting Tasmania. Certainly the transport problems of Tasmania are very much connected with the affairs of the maritime unions. There has been a great deal of difficulty in the past few years in Tasmania and a lot of this has been caused by union difficulties on the waterfront in various northern ports. As to the particular points on which the honourable senator seeks an opinion, I do not believe that I am the appropriate person to give her that information. The best I can do is to refer the question to the Minister in the other place, and I undertake to do so.

—I ask Senator Sir John Carrick a question about unemployment, not necessarily in his capacity as the Leader of the Government in the Senate or in his ministerial capacity but as a leading member of the Cabinet. Because there are now 504,800 persons in Australia willing to work, looking for some kind of work and unable to find work, because this figure represents a record since the Great Depression of the 1930s, because of Press reports that the Acting Prime Minister has rather quaintly stated that the Government has no immediate plans to alleviate the situation and because the House of Representatives in an outrageous act of cynicism has risen for the year after sitting for only 26 days in this half of the year, will the Minister declare whether the Government is contemplating any action? If not, when will that contemplation take place? Above all, when will an announcement be made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all I correct the statement that the House of Representatives has risen for the year. The facts are well known: The House of Representatives is to resume when business is returned to it from the Senate. So , in fact, it has simply adjourned for several weeks.
—Come on now. Until 23 November. How many days does that leave? Humbug! Absolute humbug!

—Let me refer to the interjection that it is absolute humbug. Senator Chipp said in his question that the House of Representatives had risen for the year. The fact of the matter is that the House of Representatives has adjourned until business of this Senate is transmitted back to it in a few weeks time. Then it will resume. All the talk of humbug cannot get away from the fact that that was a totally incorrect statement.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the Senate to come to order. The question was asked by Senator Chipp in a very serious manner. It was listened to in silence in order for the Leader of the Government to get the full context. I ask the Senate to treat the answer with exactly the same respect.

—I repeat: The House of Representatives will resume in several weeks time, as was indicated last night on its adjournment and as has been published. The Government and the people of Australia regard the present level of unemployment as very serious indeed. The level of unemployment is primarily caused by the fact that the world is in a major recession, Australia is a major trading nation and there has been a very serious fall-off in trade. It is caused also by the fact that as a result of a soaring wage rate of something like 17 1/2 per cent last year we have costed ourselves very seriously out of world markets.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is very keen indeed to do everything it possibly can to abate unemployment. We have, of course, been undertaking a great number of incentive schemes-job training, transition from school to work programs and others. We have, in fact, provided within the last Budget a series of incentives to restrain the need for the upward pressure of wages. This is fundamental. We have provided in the last Budget a net incentive to people of something like $17 a week. This will be free of tax. It is the equivalent of something like a gross increase of $30 a week. We are looking towards ways in which we can further improve the employment possibilities in this community. Fundamentally, employment in this community will improve when our trading ability is improved. That will be when--

TALK.START.PARA: —When you get inflation down.

—The interjection is: 'When you get inflation down'. Who ought to know that better than the Australian Labor Party, which at the end of 1975, as the Australian Statistician says, had inflation running at the rate of 17 1/2 per cent?
—That is a lie.
—Order! Senator Walsh will withdraw that remark.
—I will withdraw the remark if the Minister withdraws the misstatement of fact.
—Order! Senator Walsh will withdraw the remark unconditionally. He knows that that language is unparliamentary. He will withdraw unconditionally.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President.
—Please sit down, Senator Bolkus. I am on my feet. I call upon Senator Walsh to withdraw unconditionally.
—I withdraw.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I seek a ruling. The statement made by the Leader of the Government relating to 17 per cent inflation is very much a misrepresentation of the fact. It is pretty well known that that is so.

—Order, Senator Bolkus. There is no point of order. I have given a ruling already. Everybody in this chamber is very aware of what language is parliamentary and what language is unparliamentary. I called upon Senator Walsh to withdraw because he used unparliamentary language.

—Some time ago a similar incident occurred in this chamber when it was alleged that a statement by me that the Australian Statistician indicated an inflation rate of 17 1/2 per cent in 1975 was untrue. I tabled the Australian Statistician's figures in the Senate and incorporated them in Hansard. I repeat that that figure was 17 1/2 per cent.
—Let us see you produce them now.

—I will be happy to do so again. In fact, twice now the Labor Party, by way of these kinds of interjections, has tried to get away from the real fact. Members of the Labor Party interject because they do not want to hear the fact that they were the very architects of inflation. The Government is acutely sensitive to unemployment. Indeed, some of us were the victims of unemployment in the days of the Depression. Some of us have the most acute personal knowledge of those days. Of course, we do not want those kinds of days to come again. It is all right for members of the Labor Party to keep interjecting. The Labor Party, by cutting preferences by 25 per cent across the board in 1974--
—Cutting what?

—By cutting tariffs by 25 per cent across the board in 1974, the Labor Party-they grin about it now-disemployed 110,000 Australians in one year. These are the people who come here today and scream and interject about unemployment when the main architects of unemployment in this country were those who created the huge upsurge in unemployment. There was a 37 1/2 per cent increase in wages in the space of 18 months and a disemployment of 110,000 people in 1974. The Labor Party is in no position to call out about unemployment or inflation.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat that the Government is very keen indeed to do everything that is humanly possible to overcome unemployment. All the shouting by the Labor Party to prevent this answer will do no good because the louder Opposition members shout the more I will bring the facts to the attention of the Australian people. The primary ways in which the Labor Party can help are to stop provocation and to ensure that there is wage restraint and an abatement of industrial unrest in this country. The Labor Party provokes because it does not want wage restraint or an abatement of industrial unrest. It wants to create misery in this country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask a true supplementary question because, with respect , it stems out of the answer given by the Minister for National Development and Energy. The Deputy Prime Minister in what I described as a quaint reply-I could say extraordinary reply-yesterday to back bench criticism that the Government had no immediate plans to alleviate unemployment said that the Government is looking at ways in which to improve the situation.

QUESTION.PARA: When does he expect that an announcement will be made by the Government to alleviate the situation? As a second part to the supplementary question, in response to the Minister's answer, might I say that it is true that the House of Representatives has so far this sessional period sat only 26 days. If it does resume later this year, as the Minister suggests it might, it will resume for one day. Even if it does sit for the remainder of the days available this year it will then have sat for a total of only 35 days in six months. Does the Minister not regard that as an outrageous act of cynicism at this time of high unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first part of the question, I regret I did not direct my attention to the statement alleged to have been made by the Acting Prime Minister. That largely was due to the fact that the Australian Labor Party was keen that the answer should not be given at all. That cannot be escaped. I am unaware whether the Acting Prime Minister has made any such statement. Senator Chipp seems to indicate that the Acting Prime Minister made a statement in the party room. I want to tell Senator Chipp that I was in the party room and although--
—It was to the Press afterwards.

—What appears in the Press afterwards means nothing. The fact of the matter is that repeatedly Senator Chipp has indicated that because something was in the Press it does not mean that it is true. Let me simply say that the Acting Prime Minister indicated to the party room, where there was a very good and constructive discussion on employment and the relief of unemployment, that the Government was in continuous deliberation on this matter and that the Government was actively preparing a variety of policies with the aim of alleviating unemployment. The Government certainly has this matter constantly under review. I know nothing of the Press statement. The fact that the House of Representatives is to resume is now established. The fact is that there is no relationship at all between the number of days that the House of Representatives or the Senate might sit and the policies for the overcoming of unemployment. Such policies in fact will be made by the Executive and the Cabinet. That is being done continuously. The Cabinet is meeting virtually daily on these problems.
—In other words, Parliament does not matter any more; Parliament is irrelevant.

—Senator Chipp is, of course, the expert in colourful, melodramatic rhetoric. What he suggests is not so at all. He has been caught out today by the incorrect statements in his question. The fact of the matter is that the Parliament has had and has ample opportunity to debate these matters. The Senate has had and has such opportunities. I repeat that this is a very serious matter. If one wants to put Australia back into a favourable trading position, one must secure an abatement of costs in this country. The rising costs in this country, which have been due essentially to a wage push in the last year, have costed us out of world markets by comparison with other member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. We were in the first quarter of high inflation countries in the days of the Whitlam Government. We then improved our position until our costs put us in the lowest quarter. Recently that position has been reversed because of the decline in inflation in other countries. We must come down in our costs if we are to match those countries. That is what the Government is trying to do.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen the booklet 'Aboriginal Health and Lifestyle' published by the Australian Medical Association? What is the aim of this booklet and how will it help to improve Aboriginal health? Does the Minister know to whom the booklet has been distributed by the AMA? Will he suggest to the AMA that it is worthy of wide distribution in the community for the light it sheds on a central problem of the Aboriginal condition in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will know that I am a member of the Australian Medical Association. I have received a copy of the booklet.
—Shame.

—I recognise that interjection by an honourable senator. I do not consider it a shameful matter. I do not regard it as anything but a matter of pride to be a member of the Australian Medical Association. This exercise in producing this booklet is the kind of positive community building action of which the AMA can be very proud. There is no personal benefit or personal advantage in what it is doing. It is designed to make available to those who are offering medical services a better understanding of what is needed for Aboriginal Australians. I think the AMA deserves complete commendation by the Senate for what it has produced and for the way in which it has been done. The AMA sought advice from those who are involved in Aboriginal affairs-in dealing with Aboriginal people, in aboriginality-and got expert advice. It has produced a document which is sensitive and informative.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the document will be distributed to all medical practitioners in Australia-26,000 people. I think Senator Martin would like to have a wider distribution. I will approach the AMA, as a result of the honourable senator's question, and see whether it will make the document available, for example, to other significant community figures, certainly to members of parliament. I would like the honourable senator to receive a copy. If this document is designed to improve understanding by one group of non-Aboriginal Australians of the problems faced by members of the Aboriginal community it is an addition to the resources we have in dealing with what is a difficult set of problems. It is something of which the Australian Medical Association can be proud. I believe it has done a first class job in producing this piece of literature.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, and follows his answer to Senator Chipp's question about the Government's employment policies. I ask him whether, on 12 September 1980, as part of this Government's pre-1980 election policy of talking up the resources boom in which Senator Sir John Carrick indulged with great vehemence, Sir Phillip Lynch said:

QUESTION.PARA: The thousands of new jobs and the billions of dollars in exports which result will be a continuing symbol of this Government's success . . . . .
I ask him whether the Treasurer, Mr Howard, said on 11 October 1980:
It is also clear that on the basis of companies' investment intentions, tens of thousands of new jobs will be generated.

Was that pre-election talk in fact this Government's greatest success in job creation? Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate expect any similar results to flow from the deliberations which Senator Chipp has asked the Government to take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1980 and 1981 various governments in Australia made and published predictions based upon the known investment and the committed investment-
—I am talking about your Government.

—I can understand why Senator Button is getting anxious now because he can see the answer in its clarity. The fact is that in 1980 the flow of investment that was indicated for commitment fully supported the statements by Sir Phillip Lynch and the Treasurer. From recollection the total amount that was envisaged and published for commitment in Australia was a figure , on the Australian Government's measurement, in the order of $32 billion or $33 billion. That year and the year afterwards the Wran Labor Government, led by the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, published authoritative documents which stated that in New South Wales alone there would be a commitment of capital and jobs in the order of $23 billion to $26 billion. I talk from recollection. In other words, something like 60 per cent to 70 per cent of this commitment was to take place in New South Wales. The Wran Government's figures showed that what Sir Phillip Lynch and Mr Howard were saying was, in the Labor Party's view, very modest indeed and that the real figure was much larger. That was the stated view of the Federal President of the Labor Party.

ANSWER.PARA: What is more, the printed document and the policy speech of the Labor Party went on to say that if the Labor Party were re-elected New South Wales would have such abundant electric power, which would be the cheapest in Australia, that it would be able to attract such capital that there would be full employment in New South Wales. We are talking about the major industrial State of Australia which accounts for 40 per cent of Australian industry. I was asked whether the two Federal Ministers made certain comments and whether they were a distortion of facts. Far from a distortion of facts, the evidence from the major State, by a Labor Premier, was that it was an underestimation of the evidence that had been put forward. That Premier, the Federal President of the Labor Party, said: 'Re-elect the State Labor Government and we will get full employment in New South Wales'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit of a fib-unusual for a knight of the realm.

—'A bit of a fib' suggests that I am telling a lie. I repeat that the policy of the Wran Government, as stated quite clearly, was that it would create full employment with the cheapest electricity. On the judgment of experts that State now has the dearest commercial and industrial electricity in countries of the free world. It has growing unemployment, and what the Wran Government said was wrong. The answer is: Since 1980-81 companies that have committed investment in this country have abated that. The Chemical Bank of America, in a very recent statement analysing investment in Australia, stated that these figures would not be proved wrong in this decade and that there would be some slippage of a year or two in their actual implementation. The Bank stated that investment in Australia in this decade would be as much as or more than had been foreshadowed. The Premier of New South Wales and one of the most prestigious investment bodies in the world, the Chemical Bank of America, supported the fact that that diagnosis was true.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The question which I directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy related to the policies and responsibilities of the Federal Government in which he is a senior Minister. In view of the fact that he said the predictions made by Sir Phillip Lynch and Mr Howard were totally justified at the time, I ask whether in the same Press statement Sir Phillip Lynch also stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . a new investment survey is a further demonstration of the futility of the Opposition's attempts to deny the current upsurge in investment projects . . . Obviously Mr Hayden's doubts about the reality of the resources boom are not shared by his own Federal President-Mr Wran.
Does the Minister agree that Sir Phillip said that and acknowledged at that time that those figures were not accepted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Sir Phillip said that or not. Let me say that he accepted it. The fact of the matter is that there was full evidence in 1980-81, based upon the stated investment programs-not some hearsay- of the companies concerned. Sir Phillip Lynch and Mr Howard made a far more modest estimate than the Labor Party made at that time. The Labor Party said that through its Premier and Federal President. Nothing that Senator Button can gainsay gets away from the fact that there are published booklets showing that the Labor Party claimed at that time far more investment trends than ever the Commonwealth Government did and that the Commonwealth Government's estimates were very modest compared with the Labor Party's estimates of that date.

—I direct a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Given the continuing instability in oil supplies, as evidenced by respectable forecasters predicting equally glut and shortage as being certain in the medium term future, and due to the social unrest and economic troubles of significant overseas producers, can the Minister say how Australia's oil and gas exploration is proceeding and hence the position of our domestic resources of this crucial material?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think at the outset I should say that neither Australia nor the world should be bemused in any way by what is undoubtedly a very temporary glut of petroleum products in the world. The fact is that all the most authoritative commentators are convinced that this will be a temporary situation and that in the latter part of this decade we will return to shortages and, indeed, to higher prices. Those who look at the Middle East and particularly at the Iraq-Iran war can look with only the greatest trepidation at the very great danger of destabilisation of a centre of one of the world's most important oil production sources. Having said that, I say that it is, of course, the bounden duty of governments which are importers of petroleum products to look towards their own sources. I have to say that in the present year, whilst there is some indication that the bonanza in development and exploration will be not as great as was forecast last year, the situation has been such that supplies have been immensely greater than they were in the previous year.

ANSWER.PARA: Petroleum exploration and development drilling in the first nine months of 1982 exceeded that achieved in the whole of the previous year. For example, in the first nine months of 1982, 117 exploration wells were drilled compared with 142 in the full year of 1981. In nine months 35 off-shore wells were drilled compared with 16 in a full year. In nine months 86 development wells were drilled compared with 41 in a full year. There were 10 off-shore development wells drilled compared with 14 in the previous full year. The total expenditure this year on exploration and development will be in the order of $2.3 billion. Whilst there is evidence that the peak of activity has passed and that there will be some settling down, nevertheless, in view of the world glut at this moment what is happening in Australia is very interesting indeed. There will be a reduced pace of activity. Nevertheless, we have made progress this year in modest--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister has spent something like 15 minutes out of the last 20 minutes endeavouring to answer questions. I refer you to your previous ruling on lengthy answers.

—Order! There is no point of order. The previous two questions were both very long and were asked in a very serious way by those honourable senators. Supplementary questions were associated with both of the previous questions. Also there were many interjections which called for and caused comment. In such circumstances the Senate could not object to the time taken to give the answers because they were related to the questions involved. I call the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

—The point I make is that although there is now some reduction in the amount of projected exploration and development, nevertheless it is conspicuously larger than it was in the past. It has been interesting that in this year we have made modest but significant discoveries of both oil and gas . In fact, one in every four wild-cat wells has had a reasonable showing. In world terms this is very encouraging indeed.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, relates to the case of a New South Wales doctor who was deregistered because he made false Medibank claims and failed to keep a drugs register. The doctor is now practising in South Australia. What measures, if any , has the Department of Health initiated to rectify urgently this highly questionable practice of dual registration of doctors whereby, if they are struck off the medical practitioners' roll in one State, they can simply move to another State where they are also registered? Can the Minister explain why it is taking so long for a national common register of doctors to come into operation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the consequences of having a federal system is that each State and Territory has a separate method of registering doctors and, I imagine, other professionals. There has been some move over the last few years to work towards the establishment of an Australian medical council, to have a common body to set standards and carry out registration. However, this would require agreement between the States and Territories affected. We would need a package to which all could agree and which they could all implement. I understand that it has not yet been possible to get to that stage. A lot of work has been done. I believe Emeritus Professor Eric Saint was involved as chairman of the body working towards the establishment of an Australian medical council. Those of us who know Professor Saint will know that he is a highly respected person. He has been trying to get people to agree to the formation of this council, which would have both examining and registration functions if it were agreed to by the various parties.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not certain that the problem set out by Senator Elstob relates basically to the fact that there is dual registration. There is nothing basically wrong with dual registration. The fault might well lie with the fact that there may have been failure to pass information between States. We would like to be certain that information regarding a doctor struck off in one State for certain misdemeanours would go to all the other registering authorities. It may be that the error lies there. I will ask the Minister whom I represent whether there is some way in which we can perform a facilitating role or at least encourage the States and Territories to make known to each other that kind of information. That may overcome the problem to which Senator Elstob has referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister represening the Treasurer to Mr Hayden's recent call for the States to freeze their charges and for the Commonwealth to compensate the States for the loss of revenue. What would be the economic effect of a prices freeze without a corresponding wages freeze?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — There could be a number of effects of having a prices freeze without a corresponding wages freeze. I do not know that what is envisaged by the Leader of the Opposition would be of very great help if the freezing of State charges were to be compensated for by the Federal Government. State charges have been instrumental in imposing a large element of cost on much of manufacturing industry as well as on families and people generally. This has urged people to seek wage increases. What really need to be taken into account at this time are the wage levels being sought and gained by those who have employment. We should look at the effect that that may have on their own continuing employment and the opportunities for employment for those who are at present unemployed. I think that Commonwealth, State and local governments, together with the trade unions and employers, all have a responsibility to see that the level of wages that is sought is consistent with the reduction of inflation and the improvement of our competitiveness in the market in which we seek to sell our services and commodities. What has been suggested by the Federal Labor Opposition, which seeks action only from the Commonwealth Government, ignores the responsibility that ought to be shared in many of these matters.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government and follows the questions addressed to him by Senator Chipp and Senator Button. Does the Government know, as it should, that President Franklin D. Roosevelt took only 27 days to create the Civilian Conservation Corps in April 1933 as part of his New Deal and that within five months after that the CCC had placed 300,000 young unemployed Americans in useful work of national importance with a strong training element. Within the next six years that program helped no fewer than two and half million unemployed persons and was a major factor in combating the effects of the Great Depression on the United States of America. If such a resolute, prompt and effective program could be got off the ground then, what is wrong with the Government that it cannot be done now? Will the Government urgently investigate instituting a similar program for Australia now?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason should note, if a parallel can be drawn between the United States and Australia on this matter, the level of unemployment in America at the moment. Of course, vastly different international circumstances influence unemployment today. I believe that unemployment in America today is running at a much higher rate than it is in Australia. I am well aware of the circumstances of the New Deal in America. I remind Senator Mason that those who understand the history of the New Deal will understand that the strength of the Democratic Party in those days was that it was able to persuade the trade union movement of America to work with the Government of the day to achieve certain ends. That was a fundamental of the success of the New Deal. Indeed, it is something that this Government is advocating very strongly in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia must work towards a return to long term, stable and skilled employment-not just leaf scraping, which was a fundamental of the New Deal. That was the actual name given to employment programs both under the New Deal and in the Agricultural Adjustment Act. Such employment can be attained only by achieving price and cost effectiveness in comparison with the world generally. That, of course, was also recognised by Mr Hayden in 1975, when he said that simply turning on money, to create employment by inflation, would not solve the problem at all; it would create more unemployment. That fundamental situation must be kept in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. This is a matter of some importance. I would like to establish a point which Senator Carrick hinted at but did not actually mention. Is it a fact that the Government has actually proposed to the trade union movement a Civilian Conservation Corps-type program and that the trade union movement has rejected it, or was that mere rhetoric on the Minister's part?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It cannot be rhetoric because I said nothing of the sort. I said that the strength of the American regime in those days was that it sought and gained a national consensus, particularly through all the affiliates of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organisations, to work with the Government to achieve a result. That is what this Government is trying to achieve at the moment by asking the trade union movement to co-operate in major wage restraint, major cost restraint and, of course, the minimisation of industrial disruption. If we can achieve those things, we will have gone a very long way towards making ourselves cost competitive with the rest of the world.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction. I preface it by saying that no doubt he is aware, as are most Australians, of the waste of time and fuel and the irritation that comes from unnecessary waiting at traffic lights throughout this country. Will the Minister for Transport and Construction set up a section of the Department, in co-ordination perhaps with mathematics and engineering departments of universities, to investigate as a high priority the synchronisation of traffic lights throughout the towns and cities of Australia in order to ease traffic flow and to save fuel? Perhaps Canberra could be used as a perfect testing area; if not, I am sure Hobart could serve that purpose.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I may be wrong but I think Senator Townley has raised this matter in the Senate on previous occasions. I am rather surprised that he has not had a suitable reply. I will undertake to refer the question to the Minister for Transport and Construction and get some further advice for him.

—I address my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. In a Press statement on 27 October he spoke of the work of the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia, a group of four Australian companies which is undertaking an in-depth study of the uranium enrichment industry for Australia. I ask the Minister: What is the percentage of foreign ownership of that group, consisting of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, CSR Ltd, Peko- Wallsend Ltd and the Western Mining Corporation Ltd?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the precise details but of course the ownership is overwhelmingly Australian. As I understand it, BHP and CSR are wholly Australian owned. I will get the percentage of foreign ownership for the other two companies. Fundamentally, this is an overwhelmingly Australian owned group, but I will get information on the precise foreign ownership.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology whether he is aware that, with advancements in the field of genetic engineering and biotechnology, there is an increasing possibility of creating deadly mutant viruses and of making gross biological weapons if adequate safeguards and controls are not imposed. What safeguards are there to ensure the safety of the public and to guarantee that research in this field is carried out under the guidance and supervision of authorised persons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not have any precise information on the question raised by Senator Watson, although I think I am right in saying that the National Health and Medical Research Council is undertaking an inquiry into matters related to the problem raised by him. I will seek a more definite answer for him from the Minister for Science and Technolgy.

—I address my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. He will recall his oft-repeated statements concerning the urgency of the States and the Commonwealth reaching agreement on amendments to the River Murray Waters Act. He will also recall the outrageous and misleading statements made by the now deposed Premier of South Australia, Mr Tonkin, and his Minister of Water Resources, Mr Arnold, that New South Wales was stealing South Australian water and delaying agreement on amendments to the Act. I now ask the Minister: Why has the urgency now disappeared in passing the legislation amending the Act, which was introduced into the House of Representatives on 28 October but was allowed to remain on the Notice Paper without debate when that chamber rose last night for the summer recess?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will know that the four governments involved-the three State governments and the Commonwealth Government-said that at the point of agreement around the table, not at the point of legislation, the River Murray Waters Agreement would be implemented by the four consenting governments and that has happened. So of course the urgency was to get the agreement around the table, which was achieved some months ago. I announced in the Senate that at that point of agreement the full force of the River Murray Waters Agreement would take effect and that the subsequent enactments of State and Federal legislation would confirm it but would not be necessary for its enactment. So the urgency was there. We arrived at the agreement, which is in place. Every element of that agreement is now functioning. The passing of the Act itself will not in any way add one tittle to the benefit of the agreement. That is fundamental. The Act is lying on the table so it can be studied. It can also be studied by the States.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been said, and I refute it completely, that the Tonkin Government said that New South Wales was delaying the matter. There was considerable delay because New South Wales in particular was objecting to a clause in the agreement, and that objection held the agreement up for some months. I totally reject Senator McLaren's statement that Dr Tonkin was painting the picture wrongly. He was not. He was immensely concerned, as all South Australian Liberals were and are, that the water that comes from the Murray and Darling- particularly the Darling from New South Wales-should be sufficient not only in quantity but also in quality to give high grade water to South Australia. That section of the agreement related to the question of getting information from the New South Wales Government of sufficient detail to enable the River Murray Commission to be able to do its work on a river water quality basis. I repeat: The agreement is in postion, it is historic in its implications and it is working totally and well.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. How can the Minister say what he did in view of a statement made in the explanatory notes accompanying the Bill? In respect of clause 2 they state:

QUESTION.PARA: The Act is designed to come into operation on a date to be proclaimed.

In my view the date cannot be proclaimed until the legislation is passed because there is no legal binding on the three State governments or the Commonwealth until the legislation is passed through this Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am astonished-not surprised but astonished-that Senator McLaren does not understand. He will know that for the past several years there has been a huge volume of off-shore legislation between the Commonwealth and the States relating to an enormous number and range of Federal -State matters that as yet have not been enacted fully by the States. Yet, over those past years, every aspect of the agreement has been carried out as though the legislation was in place. It was decided around the conference table that once the agreement was made it would have the effect of law. That has happened, and is happening now, off-shore. Every day it is working that way. It is happening now with respect to the River Murray. The explanatory notes have nothing to do with that fact. I repeat emphatically that the full agreement is now in process and the River Murray Commission is working with the full authority of that agreement.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SMUGGLING OF AUSTRALIAN BIRDS, ANIMALS AND REPTILES

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. It is reported that 107 people have been apprehended for smuggling Australian birds, animals and reptiles since 1975. The figures cited indicate that the illegal trade is increasing in volume. During its inquiry into quarantine the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources heard evidence that a large number of Australian birds die because of this trade and that smuggling is likely to increase because of the high value of these birds, animals and reptiles overseas. It seems to me that the obvious way to stop this terrible trade, or at least substantially to reduce it, is to permit the controlled export of those Australian birds, animals and reptiles which are in large numbers in Australia. Will the Government seriously consider this suggestion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am familiar with the argument that one of the inducements to smuggle birds is, of course, the very high price which is obtained for them overseas and the fact that the very high price is a function of the limited export powers. I will refer the question to Mr Peacock and ask him to give consideration to the export of birds from Australia.

—I ask the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General: Which particular forces of reaction are making the Government so obviously duck for cover on the series of family law reforms to which it previously purported to be committed? In particular, why has the Family Law Amendment Bill, which has now been buried on the bottom of the Notice Paper for over a year, not been brought on for debate, which means presumably it will not be enacted till the middle of next year? Further, why has the Government not moved to set in train the inquiry into matrimonial property law which was announced by Senator Durack as far back as October 1981? Further, in relation to the matrimonial property inquiry, why has the Government now apparently refused to appoint one of the nation's leading experts in this respect, Professor David Hambly, to head that inquiry notwithstanding that negotiations to that effect were entered into, as I understand it, with Professor Hambly some months ago, which negotiations led him to abandon his deanship of the Law Faculty at the Australian National University and a series of other research projects in reasonable anticipation that he would be running the inquiry this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans asked a series of questions relating to family law matters. With respect to the first question and the allowance of time, there has been some debating time on that legislation, I think, on the second reading. I have not examined the record.
—Three hours in 12 months.

—But it is well known in this chamber that for the bulk of this sitting a great amount of time has been occupied by Opposition business and a remarkably small amount of time has been devoted to Government business.
—Whose fault is that?

—It is certainly not the Government's fault. Concern was expressed about that some weeks ago and more time is now being devoted to Government business. It is highly unlikely that time would be available for the family law amendments during the balance of this parliamentary sitting. I shall refer the rest of the question to the Acting Attorney-General for reply.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 o'clock, I invite honourable senators and members of the public in the Gallery to stand and join with me in observing the traditional silence in remembrance of those who have fallen in defence of their country.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators having stood in silence-

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It arises from the numerous references to excessive demand on limited economic product that have been made this morning. If the Government expects its appeals for wage restraint for the common good to be taken seriously, will the Prime Minister instruct his deputy to pay back the 4 3/4 per cent Government loan which he has for one of his Canberra houses? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the question and the elements in it are irrelevant to the situation. The fact is that at present hundreds of thousands of Australians, even millions, are receiving concessional loans. There are people receiving concessional loans through banks, insurance companies, the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, the Reserve Bank of Australia, subsidiaries of Federal and State governments, the Defence Service Homes Corporation and many other institutions. It was well known, and availed of fully by Labor members at the time, that if there was a justification for having a house in Canberra, a member, a Minister, whatever the Government, could get such a loan. That was availed of by Labor Party Ministers and used by them. Now it suits them to be selective, as they have been, and as they were in the tax recoupment argument. It has no relevance at all. Throughout Australia there are concessional arrangements on loans which are widely used.

—I ask a supplementary question. In view of the reference by the Leader of the Government in the Senate to 'millions of Australians'-I think that is what he said-who have concessional loans, will he tell us how many of those with incomes of nearly $100,000 a year have a loan at a 4 3/4 per cent rate of interest? Does he believe that the Government will be seen to be having double standards while, on the one hand, allowing the Deputy Prime Minister to retain this loan and, on the other hand, demanding or arguing that everyone else should be willing to make some sacrifice for the common good?
—It is a scandalous situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not a scandalous situation when the Whitlam Government was in power and its Ministers took advantage of the loans at the rate that was going.
—They all paid them off at the direction of the Prime Minister.

—If they paid the loans off, they need not have done so . They could have accepted the loans for the full term. It is all right if the Labor Party does it; it is all right if Mr Cain does certain things; but it is all wrong if others do it.
—Answer the question.

—The interjection is: 'Answer the question'. It hurts the Opposition if in fact we show the Opposition's selectivity. The fact of the matter is that many people with high incomes in the community, particularly in the business world, are receiving concessional loans. There is absolutely no way of knowing at all to what extent this is done. It is obvious that in business, commerce, industry and in other ways concessional loans are available. It would be impossible to know the full extent but if we take the range of people in Australia receiving concessions there would be very many Australians so doing. The fact of the matter is that when Labor Ministers on high incomes sought and gained those loans at low interest rates it was all right, but it is not good when members of opposing parties were able to do that.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSEQUENCES OF DISMISSAL OF WHITLAM GOVERNMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The disastrous economic, political, constitutional, parliamentary, and administrative consequences of November 11, 1975.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seven years ago today, the legitimately elected government of this country was forced out of office by a cynical and deceptive Opposition. Now, seven years later, we stand looking at the wreckage of seven years of Fraser government. I do not want to dwell on the events of 1975 in any detail or the duplicity, cynicism and moral bankruptcy of the Fraser-led government of 1975. The history of that is well known. If it is not well known, of course, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) later on in the pursuit of the greatest exercise in intellectual cowardice which he persistently pursues in defending the Fraser Government by saying the Whitlam Government was bad too--

—Order! Senator Button, I suggest that you are getting fairly close to the mark when you refer to 'intellectual cowardice'. I suggest that you perhaps use rather more temperate language particularly in this case in referring to the Leader of the Government. I suggest you withdraw. I am aware that you are temperate in your use of language in this place and that this statement may have been an oversight on your part.
—The fact of the matter is that the continual answer to criticisms of the Fraser Government is a total unwillingness to accept responsibility for governing this country--
—Order! Senator, I asked you to withdraw that remark which may not have been intended by you. I asked you to withdraw because I sensed that the comment was one that reflected on the Leader.

—Mr President, I am indebted to you. I did intend what I said. I withdraw. The continual answer to criticisms of the Fraser Government is that, seven years ago, there was a government in power which, according to Senator Sir John Carrick and others was as bad as the Fraser Government is today. That is the alibi. What we are concerned about, of course, in 1982 is the situation of this country and the repeated refusal of Ministers in this Government to face up to realities and, as a government, to face up to their responsibilities in respect of these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: As Australian Labor Party spokesman, I do not need to remind the Senate of the great damage that was done to the political process and to the parliamentary process on 11 November 1975. I have no need to remind people about that because everybody knows about it. Senator Sir John Carrick, this morning at Question Time was talking about the importance of consensus in the Australian community- consensus to get us out of our present problems after seven years of the Fraser Government. Where was the talk of consensus in 1975? Where was the talk of consensus in 1976 when this Government came into power and abandoned all the promises which it had made which would lead to consensus?
