TALK.START.PARA: —There was a consensus. The consensus was to get rid of you.

—I am talking of the consensus in society. Senator Martyr can make his childish interjections if he wishes. But the fact of the matter is that if honourable senators opposite listen to me and understand what I am talking about they will see that there is no consensus on those matters in this country any more. The institution of Parliament and the concept of a legitimately elected government were irreparably damaged by Fraser in 1975. The important point, of course, is no longer what happened in 1975; it is that the spirit of 1975 and the values of 1975 live on in this Government. In 1977 Professor Manning Clark, giving the Boyer lectures on the Australian Broadcasting Commission, said this country had been taken over by what he called 'interest men with the values of receivers in bankruptcy'. Honourable senators opposite are interest rate men all right; under this Government we are experiencing the highest interest rates this country has ever seen. The Government is a collection of interest rate men-experts on that topic. We are experiencing the highest rates this country has ever seen. I refer again to Question Time when the double standards of this Government which gave the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) a 4 3/4 per cent housing concessional loan were raised. At that time the general interest rate was about 8 1/2 per cent. In 1974 the then Opposition moved a censure motion against the Labor Government because interest rates had gone up to 9 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: They were the values in those days and they are the values of today. The point I make is that the values of 1975 live on in the way this Government operates. As the country slides into further economic ruin every decision is governed by political expediency rather than by values. The values which motivated the Leader of the Opposition in 1975 are ones of cynicism and the desire to dominate the policies of any government. The driving ambition was to get into power, to use power, to manipulate it, and to use the institutions of this country to maintain power. The values of Fraserism then, as now, were no attempt at consensus, but at divide and rule, cynicism and political expediency.

Let us look at the 1977 election, for example. It is said with what I call intellectual cowardice by spokesmen in this Government that all the responsibility for the present economic chaos in this country lies, first of all , with overseas factors or, secondly, with the trade unions. When honourable senators opposite justified an early election in 1977 the Deputy Prime Minister said: 'We have to have an early election so we can show that we can stand up to the unions'. He was accepting his responsibilities then. What has happened since ? Has the Government succeeded in that aim? Of course, it has not. That was the sort of proposition which was floated at the time. What we have in this country is government by scapegoat, government by alibi-alibis which were not conceded to the Whitlam Government in 1974 and 1975 although, as Senator Jessop said in the Senate yesterday, we are now seeing the biggest international recession since 1974-75. At that time the Prime Minister said that if the Ministers were honourable men they would stand up and admit that it was their responsibility and not the responsibility of overseas factors. Not too many honourable Ministers are saying that sort of thing today.

In the 1980 election there was another example of scapegoat politics, illusion politics-the resources boom which was promising tens of thousands of jobs. Dishonesty was displayed in those suggestions. There have been international alibis all the time. But there are no alibis for a government which was elected to power in 1975 on the assumption that it could do better, and which assumed responsibility to do better. There is no alibi for a government which has uniquely succeeded in having an enormously high inflation rate and the highest levels of unemployment since the Great Depression at the same time. There is no other government with that record of success-if one likes to call it success. This Government is unique in producing those two factors at the same time, together with an enormous overseas debt for this country.

All these matters cannot be denied after seven years of this Government. What was done instead was to try to set groups against each other in this society. We do not hear much today about the dole bludger syndrome. That was the stunt in 1976 and 1977. Will the Government call half a million Australians dole bludgers in 1982? I do not think so. The suggestion that has continued since the beginning of this Government is that all the problems of this country can be laid at the door of the unions but the Government has no wages policy. Mr Peacock says that, I say it, and it has not been denied by Government Ministers at any time. The Government has no wages policy. The wages explosion which took off in Australia in 1981 was the direct result of the Prime Minister giving more importance to going to the royal wedding than to dealing with wages issues in this country, as he should have done.

The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission abandoned wage indexation in 1981 and the Government did nothing. It has done nothing since to try to restore a centralised wage fixation system in this country, which would have produced much better results in terms of inflation and equity. We have seen continued cowardly attempts to confer on everybody else the responsibilities which governments ought to assume. Governments are elected to govern. It is no good Senator Sir John Carrick saying at Question Time that Mr Wran was wrong too . These sorts of statements are petty-minded alibis. His responsibility is as a Minister in the Commonwealth Government of Australia. We stand here today in the wreckage of Fraserism, seeing a Government bereft of ideas and presiding over an economic crisis and vast social inequities.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said this last week and the week before.

—I will say it next week, too. It has to be said a lot to get it into thick heads. As I said earlier, the Government is presiding over an economic crisis and vast social inequities as a result of its policies. In the midst of the economic ruin of the present the words which I quoted of Professor Manning Clark have an uncannily prophetic relevance. When the Prime Minister won the election in 1975 he said that it was his task-his task-to restore growth-
—And he did so.

—No. It was his task, he said, to restore growth, to provide jobs for everybody who wanted to work, to provide prosperity for Australians and to provide sound economic management. I ask Senator Lewis-the very noisy chap that he is-to say whether the Prime Minister has fulfilled his task. Senator Sir John Carrick will say it was not his task at all, it was the responsibility of Neville Wran or somebody like that. But it was the task of the Prime Minister and of the Government to do those things because that is what it said it would do and that is what justified the abysmal performance on 11 November 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the statistics. In 1975, the rate of unemployment was 5 per cent ; in 1977, 5.5 per cent; in 1982, for the last quarter, 7.4 per cent. Now it is 7.8 per cent. The inflation rate for the year at the end of the September quarter in 1975 was 12 per cent. That is the last quarter for which we have figures. In 1977 it was 13.1 per cent; in 1982, 12.3 per cent. Those are the figures of a government which said that it was not so much concerned about unemployment, as it would fight inflation first. As I said last week, as Senator Lewis knows, the Government should pick on something smaller because it is getting hell beaten out of it in its fight against inflation first. The Government really ought to try to pick on something smaller because it is not doing much good in that area. The promises of economic management have collapsed around the Prime Minister's ears. There is no better example of that in Australian society than to quote the words of J. K. Galbraith when he was discussing the sort of half baked monetarist policies of this Government. He said:
Under monetarism the rich need more money as an incentive. The poor need less as an incentive.

That is what has happened under this Government. Of course, the international comparisons for this country are alarming. Australia is rapidly sliding down the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development scale in relation to its economic management and performance. It was eighth on the list in 1976 in terms of gross domestic product. It was fifteenth on the list in 1981 and going down. In six years of government that comparative change came about. The comparisons with Austria, Germany, Japan and other countries do no credit to this Government .

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the home ownership in those places?

—I do not know. The honourable senator might as well ask me what the divorce rate is or something else. I am talking about the key indices of economic management. The simple point is that in comparative terms the economic policies of this Government have failed and have resulted in national disaster. Let me say a brief word about taxation. Under this Government, taxation has become an enormous vehicle for social division. The effect of the tax changes since 1975 has been to place a greater tax burden on lower and middle income earners. The average rate of taxation for those on high incomes of around $30, 000 or more-the Mr Doug Anthonys of this world-has fallen since 1975-76. I said those people on incomes of $30,000 or more. The percentage of tax paid by pay-as -you-earn taxpayers has risen as a percentage of total tax revenue. The percentage of company tax has fallen, of course, for reasons pointed out in the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.

SPEECH.PARA: As Professor Mathews said, if this Government had collected the revenue, if it had shown as much keenness and zeal about collecting the taxation revenue of this country as it had showed in messing about with minor cuts in Government expenditure, then the balance of payments situation would have been better, the interest rate situation in this country would have been better and there would not be the vast division between rich and poor which has arisen as a result of this Government's policies. Of course, there are political consequences as well as the tragic economic consequences of what took place on 11 November 1975. They are consequences which are reflected in the debasement of political life in this country, for instance, the incapacity of this Government to obtain a consensus in society because nobody trusts it; the total ad hockery of every policy which this Government embarks upon. We do not talk about these issues as much as we ought to. But the fact of the matter is that in the last seven years there has been no real government imagination or initiative to do anything to develop new industries in this country or to restructure existing industries. The Government lumbers on from by-election to by-election hoping that something like a resources boom, a trade union strike or something else will turn up to help it through the next election. Time is running out for all those things. They will not work any more. They worked for two or three elections, but they will not work any more. That is a tragedy for the country but it is a greater tragedy for the Government because the consequences will be seen next year. There have also been no constitutional initiatives by this Government. My colleague, Senator Evans, of course, will be dealing with those matters. But what--

TALK.START.PARA: —Pathetic.
—I am sorry. I did not hear what the honourable senator said.
—I said 'pathetic'.
—Order! I suggest that honourable senators let Senator Button finish his speech.

—I say by way of conclusion: If we look back over the last 10 years of Australian political history, at the new initiatives that have been taken in Australian politics-the sorts of things which have led to a change in very minor ways in the liberality and quality of life in this country-we will see that they are all initiatives taken by the last Labor Government. The case against the last Labor Government, of course, was that it ran into a period of economic difficulty and so on. We on this side of the House do not dispute that for one minute. All we say is that the ongoing things of importance and relevance to this country, which are the little things which can be regarded as improvements, were all initiated in that period. For example, freedom of information legislation, legal aid and law reform, expansion of broadcasting--
—That puts food into people's mouths!

—Yes, I agree. They are all small things, Senator. But honourable senators opposite cannot point to anything like that which their Government can claim as an achievement. All that they can claim after seven years in government is that somebody else is responsible, that it is not their fault. They just keep their backsides on the white taxi seats which is their right because of some curious event which happened on 11 November 1975. One has to look at the realities of the performance of this Government. Over seven years it has been one of gradually accelerating disaster because of a lack of imagination, initiative and concern about the real issues. The cynical manipulative issues which developed in 1975 still remain the values of the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 November 1975, exactly seven years ago, the Whitlam Labor Government was dismissed because of its misconduct in office. Subsequently the people of Australia elected the Fraser Liberal Government with massive majorities in the three Federal elections in 1975, 1977 and 1980. It has been a popular pastime of members of the Australian Labor Party over the seven years to respond to the injunction 'maintain your rage' of their former leader-they are now tearing him apart in the United Nations; they want to disown him-by saying that there was a very serious incident on 11 November 1975 that touched the constitutional and parliamentary institution. They have argued two things. I think it is a good thing that we have an opportunity today to remind people of what happened on 11 November 1975. The argument of the Labor Party is that the Governor-General acted improperly and the then Opposition took improper action by blocking Supply.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal with these two important points. I will seek leave in a moment to incorporate in Hansard the official media statement of the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, on 27 February 1974, as printed in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, announcing the appointment of Sir John Kerr as the Governor- General in terms that indicated that the Labor Party believed he was eminently equipped to be the Governor-General in all respects. That statement was repeated and re-endorsed totally by the Labor Party throughout the ensuing months. The Labor Party knew that Sir John Kerr had been a member of the Labor Party in the past. It believed that Sir John Kerr would do its bidding. It acknowledged to the world that he was uniquely equipped to understand consitutional problems at State and Federal levels. Mr Whitlam's statement said that. The Labor Party therefore endorsed Sir John Kerr as the ideal kind of Governor-General. I repeat : It appointed him. I repeat: It knew that he had been previously a member of the Labor Party.

The Labor Party's error was believing that a man of that kind of intellect and that kind of probity would be the lackey of the Labor Party. The error was not that of the Governor-General; the error was that the Labor Party believed that because it appointed him he must do its will even though he knew it to be wrong. I seek leave to incorporate that statement by Mr Whitlam in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
APPOINTMENT OF GOVERNOR-GENERAL
Media Statement, E. G. Whitlam, 27 February 1974

It is announced today from Government House, Canberra, that Her Majesty The Queen has graciously approved the appointment of the Hon. Sir John Kerr, K.C.M.G ., to be Governor-General of Australia. He will take up office at the end of June this year when the present Governor-General, Sir Paul Hasluck, relinquishes his appointment.

Sir John has been Chief Justice of New South Wales and Lieutenant-Governor since 1972. He has had a distinguished career in both the law and public administration. After war service with the Second A.I.F., Sir John was the first Principal of the Australian School of Pacific Administration. He then followed a distinguished career at the Bar in New South Wales, becoming a Queen's Counsel in 1953. In 1966 he was appointed a Judge of the Commonwealth Industrial Court and a Judge of the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory. He has also served as a Judge of the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory and has held other Australian judicial commissions.

Sir John has held a number of executive positions in the legal profession, including President of the New South Wales Bar Association, President of the Law Council of Australia and foundation President of the Law Association of Asia and the Western Pacific. He has also served on a number of Government bodies, including, in 1968 as Chairman of the Committee on Review of Administration Decisions, and in 1970 as Chairman of the Committee on Review of Pay for the Armed Services. In 1971 he conducted an inquiry into the salaries and allowances of Members of the Australian Parliament.

Sir John was appointed C.M.G. in 1966 and K.C.M.G. this year. Sir John's significant attainments in the field of law and administration have given him a familiarity with Australian Government and State Government affairs and he is of course, well known throughout Australia. All Australians will join me in congratulating Sir John and welcoming him and Lady Kerr to their high appointments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make clear the only reason that members of the Labor Party are maintaining their rage. Indeed, Labor members in the passage on that day said to me: 'He couldn't do it. He couldn't do it. I do not believe he could do it'. They believed that, having been a member of the Labor Party in the past, he would be subservient to their will and not do his duty in the law as he saw it. They failed in that judgment. He did not fail. He acted, as constitutional lawyers over the years have indicated, superlatively correctly. Indeed, it was the Labor Party's misjudgment which brought about the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Now let us step to the next argument, that it was wicked of the then Liberal Opposition to oppose Supply. Everybody knows that. Labor Party members have said that 100 times. Now they are weakening. Every new statement by Senator Evans weakens it. Of course, recently Mr Keating said: 'Given a chance, we would bolt and we would reject Supply'. Let us have a little joy about this. It was a sin to reject Supply, was it? I will now read to the Senate the statement on 18 June 1970 by the then Senator Lionel Murphy, speaking as the official spokesman of the Labor Party on the policy of the Labor Party on money Bills and Supply.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was the Leader.
—He was the Leader, I am reminded. I quote from Hansard of that date. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate is entitled and expected to exercise resolutely but with discretion its power to refuse its concurrence to any financial measure, including a tax Bill. There are no limitations on the Senate in the use of its constitutional powers, except the limitations imposed by discretion and reason. The Australian Labor Party has acted consistently in accordance with the tradition that we will oppose in the Senate any tax or money Bill or other financial measure whenever necessary to carry out our principles and policies.
He said that members of the Labor Party would reject any tax or money Bill or any financial measure if it suits them. He continued:
The Opposition has done this over the years, and in order to illustrate the tradition which has been established-
That is, the tradition of rejecting Supply Bills-

with the concurrence of honourable senators I shall incorporate in Hansard at the end of my speech a list of the measures of an economic or financial nature, including taxation and appropriation Bills, which have been opposed by this Opposition in whole or in part by a vote in the Senate since 1950.

For the joy of the Senate I will seek leave to re-incorporate in Hansard the list of those many Bills, including Appropriation Bills, which the Labor Party in Opposition sought to oppose. So the two things-the two absolute arguments on this-go. The Labor Party said that the Governor-General was pre-eminently suited as a jurist of world renown to be the Governor-General. That was quite clear. Constitutional lawyers have indicated that, in fact, he acted with absolute propriety and probity. The Labor Party has said that not only is it right to reject Supply but also it would do that, repeatedly-and it has done so repeatedly.

What happened on 11 November 1975, to which this matter of public importance relates directly? The community of Australia had watched the tragedy of scandal after scandal, the latest had been the removal of Mr Connor by his Prime Minister for having given-according to the Prime Minister's statement-false information. The Labor Party had, in fact, corrupted the constitutional and parliamentary processes by calling a completely unconstitutional Executive Council behind the Governor-General's back and without his knowledge. This is the party that is now talking about constitutional, parliamentary and administrative procedures. In fact, the Whitlam Labor Government, without telling the Governor-General, held an Executive Council meeting. It did so quite illegally. For what purpose did it do that? To get through the Khemlani loan-a completely contemptuous situation. The Labor Party did not tell the Governor- General that the Khemlani loan was such that it would have bankrupted Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are without shame. You are a sanctimonious hypocrite without shame.
—Order! Senator, I ask you to withdraw those words.
—I withdraw.

—I can understand that the recitation of the facts of 11 November 1975 must hurt the Labor Party. Once this has been said I never want again to hear this nonsensical alibi. Bear in mind what members of the Labor Party are trying to do. They will never admit to themselves or to anyone else that they were defeated because of their own mismanagement, misbehaviour and scandals. They want to suggest that they were beaten by the umpire. They were indeed beaten by the umpire three times-at the ballot box in 1975, 1977, and 1980. They are saying that they were not beaten at all, that it was all a constitutional impropriety. What I have said today has properly exploded that. In those years there had been the devastation of the Khemlani loans affair, the devastation caused by Cairns, and all the mismanagement, bungling and allegations of impropriety. There were the quarrels over Connor and, of course, the demotion of the Minister for Labor and Immigration. All this at a time when Australia needed good government. Labor Party members talk about the consequences. The consequences were that the Australian people looked at those years and said: 'The Labor Party failed miserably in office on every score. It must go out and we are going to keep it out'. They have done that and will do so .

SPEECH.PARA: So let us not talk again about 11 November, except in its true perspective-a situation in which an eminently qualified and internationally recognised jurist, the Governor-General of Australia, acted with full propriety. He did not behave like the lackey of the Labor Party. The Opposition of the day did what the Labor Party had said was its official policy-to reject Supply when that opportunity occurred. The then Opposition did what the Labor Party had done repeatedly. That is the background. We are asked in this discussion on a matter of public importance to look at the constitutional, political, parliamentary and administrative aspects of the events of those days. The people of Australia have already done so at the ballot box. They have said: 'We will not have a bar of your unconstitutional and unparliamentary behaviour, your administrative mismanagement'.

I have traced the background. Let me come now to the hard facts. In Question Time today I believe it was alleged that I had given false information on the trend of inflation in Australia. I now cite the inflation rates. I gave the figures for the year to the last quarter of 1975, the September quarter. I said the inflation rate was 17.6 per cent for the year ended in that quarter. I have figures for the June quarter. They are official Treasury figures. Let us hear Opposition senators say they are lies, fibs, or whatever they like to say. In 1970-71 the inflation rate was 4.8 per cent; in 1971-72 it was 6.8 per cent. Now we come to the three years of the Labor Government. In 1972-73 the inflation rate was 6 per cent; in 1973-74 it was 12.9 per cent. It had doubled. In 1974-75 it was 16.7 per cent. What do I hear about untruths? Then the Labor Government was dismissed. Inflation in the June quarter of 1975 was running at 16.7 per cent when it had been between 4 per cent and 6 per cent when the Labor Party came into office. It nearly tripled. In the financial year 1975-76 the inflation rate was 13 per cent. In the next year, 1976-77, it was 13.8 per cent. Those are the years of the Fraser Government. In 1977-78 it was 9.5 per cent; in 1978-79 it was 8.2 per cent. Those figures are against the rate of 16.7 per cent during the Labor Government's term. In 1979-80 the inflation rate was 10.1 per cent; in 1980-81 it was 9.4 per cent; and in 1981-82 it was 10.4 per cent. I seek leave to have those figures incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—Before leave is granted I ask the Leader to add to that table that inflation was running at 25 per cent in 1950 under the Menzies Government.
—Order!
—The highest ever.

—Order! Before I call for leave to be granted, I point out to Senator Gietzelt that I have seen his name on the speakers list. He will have his opportunity to speak a little later. It may pay for him to wait until then.
—I make it clear that I seek leave also for the incorporation in Hansard of Senator Murphy's list of Bills that the Labor Party opposed.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
