INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite clearly, these figures give a king hit to Senator Button because he said that there was a disastrous movement in the inflation rate after the Labor Party was tipped out of office. What have we seen ? The inflation rate, which at the end of the June quarter of 1974-75 was 16.7 per cent and soaring-in fact it rose to 17.6 per cent by the end of the next quarter-has been brought down very substantially.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Evans-Give us the figures for unemployment. Are you going to give us the unemployment figures?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me talk unemployment because we are very interested in this matter. Honourable senators will remember that at Question Time today I was accused of telling lies, untruths and fibs in giving the figures I gave. It is strange now that when I produce them and put 11 November 1975 in its true perspective we do not get a whimper because I am telling the truth about the situation. In the space of 18 months from 1973-74 wages in Australia rose by 37 per cent. That was the beginning of the wage push. Australia moved from being a country with one of the lowest rates of inflation and one of the highest rates of full employment in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in the 1950s and 1960s-the average unemployment rate and the average inflation rate were below 2 per cent-into the top bracket in the Whitlam years. That was not bad in the space of three reckless and wrecking years. What also happened? The Labor Government made a tariff cut across the board of 25 per cent.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Labor Party talks about unemployment. That wound to the manufacturing industry has never healed. In one year more than 110,000 people in Australia were disemployed out of manufacturing. Manufacturing has never recovered from the absolute shock and devastation. How can the Australian Labor Party be proud of itself when, in one year, it disemployed 110,000 people? Members of the Labor Party have deliberately said that they believed that the people overseas who make the goods and export them to Australia ought to get the jobs rather than the Australians. That is what they said. If tariffs are cut by 25 per cent- honourable senators should bear in mind that this Government is maintaining the tariffs-we are inviting countries overseas to use their workmen in the place of Australian workmen. A total of 110,000 people were disemployed. That started the fundamental rot which has taken an emormous time for this Government to recover from. The fact is that the Labor Party talks about things but in fact when one looks at them there is no truth in them at all.

Today Mr Hayden is saying we must spend thousands of millions more; in fact, let us get the deficit up. Mr Hawke is breathing behind his neck and wanting more. Mr Hayden is saying that the way to create jobs is to spend more money. Mr Hayden was the Treasurer in 1974-75. In his Budget Speech he stated:

On the economic front, inflation is this nation's most menacing enemy. We aim to curb it. Unless this aim is achieved, the nation's productive capacity will run down and job opportunities will diminish.
Our present level of unemployment is too high. If we fail to control inflation unemployment will get worse.

Let me make that clear. Mr Hayden stated the Fraser Government's policy today. The Labor Party is denying it because it is in opposition. Let us remember that today he says that we must spend more. In his Budget Speech he continued:

We are no longer operating in that simple Keynesian world in which some reduction in unemployment could, apparently, always be purchased at the cost of some more inflation. Today, it is inflation itself which is the central policy problem. More inflation simply leads to more unemployment.

Some might argue that a large deficit could be offset by a tough monetary policy-but this would mean greatly increased interest rates, disruption in financial markets, further depression of business confidence and serious company failures. That is an unacceptable option.

The very unacceptable option is the option that Mr Hayden and Mr Hawke put forward in recent days and which every newspaper in Australia, including the Australian Financial Review, condemned out of hand. In other words, the Labor Party comes along with a whimper trying to find an alibi for its failure in 1975 and trying to blame that failure on the umpire instead of itself. I am sure all honourable senators remember the quotation from Shakespeare:
The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars, But in Ourselves, . . .

That was the message of 11 November 1975. The fault was that members of the Labor Party believed that a highly equipped Governor-General, a highly respected jurist, would obey them rather than his conscience. He obeyed his judgment and his conscience.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to honour with a detailed reply the intellectually and morally poverty stricken diatribe we have just heard from the Leader of the Government (Senator Sir John Carrick). I want to make a more constructive contribution to this debate, which is about the consequences of 11 November 1975. But before I do get on to that more constructive contribution, let me just correct the record on a couple of economic statistics around which Senator Sir John Carrick built the whole of that particular morally, intellectually and factually poverty stricken diatribe that we have just heard.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the case that when one looks at inflation rates for one particular quarter and multiplies them by four-there were some bad quarters in the period of the Whitlam Administration-one can come up with the kind of inflation figures that Senator Sir John Carrick has today. But let me remind him that if the most up to date inflation figures are used as the basis for calculation for the year ending in the September quarter 1982 the inflation rate was 12.3 per cent, whereas for the most immediately comparable period in the Whitlam Administration , the September year ending 1975, the inflation rate was 12 per cent.

Let Senator Sir John Carrick not go back five or six months and pluck a figure out of the air for the June quarter. Let him take the most recent quarterly figures that are available for the year ending September this particular year and he will find that the inflation comparisons, in fact, run the other way. The selective indignation is contemptible here as it is in so many other instances with Senator Sir John Carrick. Let us take the unemployment figures, which he did not deign to give us in anything like that degree of detail because he could not. In that case the comparisons are very odious and invidious. The current unemployment rates are 7.8 per cent actual and 8.2 per cent seasonally adjusted. Let Senator Sir John Carrick and those who defend him compare that with the unemployment rates that existed at any period in any quarter of the Whitlam administration and make a comparison there. Let us calculate the index of misery by adding together indexation and unemployment and comparing that index as it stood in any period of the Whitlam administration with the way in which that index stands now-right up over 20 points with an 8.2 per cent unemployment rate and a 12.3 per cent inflation rate. The record of this administration is absolutely abominable by reference to any economic criterion.

But let me go back to some of the other consequences of 11 November with which this matter of public importance is intended to deal and let me focus on the constitutional, parliamentary and administrative implications of the putsch of 11 November 1975. The dismissal of the Whitlam Government 7 years ago remains the most traumatic shock ever administered to the Australian constitutional system. I believe that democracy was put at risk by what happened on that day and by the events leading up to it in this chamber. I believe that so long as the constitution remains unamended to make impossible, or at least very difficult, a repetition of the events of that day democracy will remain at risk. That perception is shared, as we all know, not just by my colleagues in the labour movement but by many people right across the political spectrum. Some honourable senators who are whimpering at the moment share, if they are intellectually honest with themselves, a similar perception about the structural weaknesses of our present constitutional system which makes possible this kind of instability. Many of the more upright and courageous Government senators have expressed their position on these matters openly and overtly, not just in a hole in the corner way when privately pressed upon to do so. Bitter as those divisions that were generated by 1975 were, bitter as those divisions remain, as extensive as the ideological divide remains on a lot of these issues, it is important to appreciate that there is a perception in many parts of the community, including the political community, that the issues at stake transcend those immediate partisan, ideological preoccupations that so many of us have.

It is important to appreciate that we do now have a situation, as a result of the legacy of the events of 11 November 1975, in which the Senate has the power, not only on paper but also in practice-one that is likely to be exercised-to bring down the Government of the day by blocking Supply, even when that Government has a clear mandate and a clear maintained majority in the other House. The Senate, an institution which is less democratic by any account in the method of its construction than the popular House, the lower House, the Senate, which has long since abdicated any claim or pretension to represent any other kind of interest in this nation as a States House, is in a position of overweening power as a result of this state of affairs. We have a situation, as a result of 1975 and the unamended constitution since 1975, of a Governor- General, himself not democratically elected, who has no claim to democratic legitimacy, entitled, it seems now, to intervene in an essentially political struggle and to strike down a democratically elected government in the way that happened. We have a situation in which, as a result of all this, we have an inbuilt, evident instability and uncertainty in our whole political and constitutional structure. It is a situation which is not doing anybody any good on either side of politics because of the continued uncertainty it creates about the way in which we go about our affairs.

What has been the contribution over the last seven years of the Fraser Government to doing something about accommodating these difficulties which we all, in our saner and quieter moments, are aware do exist? The contribution of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and his senior Ministers has been dogged, churlish, pigheaded and unconstructive in every conceivable request. There has been no acknowledgment that a problem even exists, and to the extent, on occasions, that there is a partial acknowledgment that some kind of a problem might exist, there has been no willingness to debate that in any coherent or sensible way. There has been no willingness on the part of the senior Ministers of this Government to make any constructive contribution towards reaching some kind of consensus solution.

That is evident in a number of ways which I will briefly identify. It is evident in the statements and actions of Mr Fraser and his senior Ministers. It is evident, for a start, in the performance of Mr Fraser and his senior Ministers at the Australian Constitutional Convention held in Perth in 1978 when this matter was debated and where there was a dogged, churlish, pigheaded insistence on the Court proposal for dealing with this problem, a proposal which would do no more than simply endorse and institutionalise what actually happened in 1975 and create a situation where an automatic double dissolution followed upon any indefensible exercise by this chamber of its power over money Bills. This unwillingness to look for a middle way, a consensus solution-some solution to this problem-was evident in the attitude that has been demonstrated, not by all members on the other side but certainly by the senior members of the Government, to the fixed term parliament proposal which I introduced one year ago today, 11 November 1981. With a little bit of luck and good management, we might actually succeed in finalising the passage of that legislation through the Committee stage in this Parliament today.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats have seen through that Bill.

—The Australian Democrats have co-operated in producing a Bill which, although it will not provide a total and perfect solution to the institutional problems that were created by the events of 1975 or the problems of instability and uncertainty associated with our unfixed term debate, recognises that the kind of solution which has emerged from debate in this place is one that can make a serious contribution to solving an obvious and deep- rooted problem in our system. That perception has not been shared and that contibution has not been made by the senior members of the Government on the other side of the chamber. That is a matter for shame and unhappiness for those who want some sensible contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: The attitudes to which I refer have been evident again in the 'constitutional reform' proposals, as he described them, of the Attorney-General, Senator Durack , which he floated in a major speech he made in May this year. In the course of describing his rejection of the fixed term parliament concept, he floated the possibility of a retention of the Senate's Supply blocking power but at the same time adopting some sort of convention whereby the Senate would be prevented from altering any detail of a government's Budget. That proposal is cynical in the extreme. It is the proposal of a government wanting to have its cake and to eat it too. The Government wants an exercise of self-denial by the Australian Labor Party, the Opposition, when it comes to harassing the Government on issues such as the sales tax proposals in last year's Budget, but will not involve itself in any willingness to engage in a similar act of self-denial by promising not to block Supply in the future.

The narrow-minded atitude to which I have referred has been evident again in the atitude to constitutional reform generally demonstrated by the Government by the halting and faltering enthusiasm of Mr Fraser, Senator Durack and the rest- the feet dragging of them all-in the context of setting in train another session of the Australian Constitutional Convention, a convention which did have a degree of momentum with meetings in 1973, 1975, 1976 and 1978, but which has ground to a halt during the tenure of the latter years of the Fraser Administration. We have had the rejection of any willingness to talk about changing the character of that convention to make it more democratic, more representative, more open and more likely to encourage a spirit of change in the community at large.

We have had the extraordinary attitude finally of total pigheaded, insensitive rejection by the Prime Minister of the very serious-minded attempts at cross- party, cross-community, consensus that are currently being sponsored now by the Law Foundation of New South Wales in generating a proposal for systematic constitutional review with a view, perhaps, to systematic constitutional change by our 1988 bicentennial year, a process in which several prominent members of Mr Fraser's own party here in this Parliament are contributing very constructively. This was a process which Mr Fraser described in his Barton lecture earlier this year as 'one of the most divisive proposals that can be contemplated in Australia'. Coming from the man who brought us 11 November 1975, the effrontery in that kind of statement is absolutely breathtaking. For Malcolm Fraser, the man who is to the Australian Constitution-as I have said in the past -what Attila the Hun was to the Roman Empire to advance the proposition accusing of divisiveness those of us who are attempting in a very constructive and public spirited way to find some grounds for consensus is carrying cheek to the point of breathtaking grotesquery.

The constitutional legacy of the events of 1975 is a profoundly unhappy one. I hardly need to labour that point any more. But it ought to be appreciated that that unhappiness is evident in a number of other dimensions as well, such as the parliamentary dimension. The attitude to and the consequences of the divisions and bitterness of 1975 have made themselves manifest in the way in which we conduct this Parliament and in the way in which the institution of parliament has-far from flowering under the Fraser Administration -crumbled almost into cynical collapse. It is very close to collapse in many ways because of the actions of the Fraser Government.

Let me refer to several instances. A very current one is the cynical manipulation of the parliamentary timetable. I instance the rising of the House of Representatives now, weeks early, in order to avoid the exposure and the scrutiny of the shoddiness of this Executive and this Administration by the Opposition. It is evident also in the sluggish way in which the Fraser Administration clamped down on and made impossible the rationalisation of parliamentary sitting hours. That was another sensible reform-promoted to a large extent by Senator Martin and others on the Government side-which was designed to get a more flexible, sensitive and civilised working environment in which the institutions of this nation could operate. But the great Monty Python kind of heel came thundering down from above in the tory party room. That was another move in the direction of achieving a sane and more civilised parliamentary institution which was crushed by the demagoguery and personal dictatorial tendencies of this Prime Minister who came to power in November 1975 .

We have had the cynical closing of the one decent experiment in the development of committees in the House of Representatives-the closure of the Estimates committees with the opportunities they presented for our House of Representatives colleagues to make a serious contribution to the analysis of Executive behaviour and administrative misbehaviour in the lifetime of this Government. That is the other major legacy and consequence to which I want to refer in winding up my remarks on the events of November 1975-the administrative consequences, and legacy, that this putsch of November 1975 has left the nation. We are talking administratively about a Government which came to power claiming, again as I have said, with breathtaking effrontery, to make up for the alleged incompetence or maladministration of the Labor Administration. It has proved to be the Government which has given us the tax evasion scandal, as revealed by the Costigan and McCabe reports. It is the Government which has given us the medifraud scandal which is being revealed in the current hearings of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. It is the Government which has given us the meat substitution scandal and the crude and vulgar attack from Mr Fraser on the judicial umpire which followed that. It is the Government which has given us the Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd scandal-and everything that has been associated with that-which was revealed, again, by one of the Government's chairman-led committees, Senator Rae's Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

Part of the wreckage of this Government's maladministration and Executive impropriety has been visible in the resignations, suspensions, dismissals and forced early retirements of over 20 Ministers from this Government. Other things have not been so visible. They have had to rise to the surface like bubbles breaking as gas from the fetid pond that represents the quality of this Government's administration. Bubbles have come up through the Finance and Government Operations Committee. Other bubbles are coming up through the Public Accounts Committee. Bubbles have risen through the slime from the reports of Costigan and miscellaneous other reports of that kind.

One way or another the truth is being revealed in a piecemeal way about the vaunted quality of administration, and the legacy in this respect which the Fraser Government has left to us. So, far from having a government which has saved the nation, we have a government which has plunged this country into economic despair in an unprecedented way-unprecedented since the Depression. It has made an unprecedented contribution to the index of misery, however one calculates it. We have a government which, far from saving this nation from bad government, has produced mismanaged government on a scale that is unprecedented in the history of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —No doubt those people who read Hansard and appreciate the long-winded, polysyllabic rhetoric and imagination of Senator Evans will think that his was a good speech. If only those of us who were sitting in the chamber could have recorded his artistic gesticulations we would be able to show that that was really his only contribution to the debate. What on earth the parliamentary sitting hours have to do with the events of 11 November 1975 is beyond honourable senators on this side of the chamber. I do not propose to go over the reasons for the events of 1975. Those of us who lived through 1974 and 1975 will never forget the reasons for what happened on 11 November 1975. Those people in the community-there are now very many of them-who were not old enough at that time to recall what happened frankly do not need to be reminded. That is what the Australian Labor Party is trying to do today. The matter proposed to the Senate for discussion as a matter of public importance today is, in effect, a call to maintain the rage.
—Look how angry they are, the whole lot of them.
—As my colleague Senator Martyr says, look how angry they all are. He is being sarcastic; he is referring to the empty benches on the Opposition side.
—We make enough noise.

—I agree with Senator Evans, he and his three colleagues are making enough noise. Senator Evans referred to the so-called constitutional crisis. I have said repeatedly that that is a euphemism for a political crisis. It was one of those rare occasions when this Parliament managed to summon up the courage to stand up to the Executive Government. It seems that whenever and wherever it happens, be it in Australia or in another country, as soon as a parliament has the courage to take a matter into its own hands and stands up to the Executive Government of the day there is a crisis. Senator Evans can call it a constitutional crisis: I can call it a political crisis. It is a crisis because it is a contest between the legislature-the parliament-and the Executive Government, and it is a constitutional political crisis which sometimes goes to a political death. That is precisely what happened in November 1975, and with all good reason.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally-it has taken until 1982-a member of the Australian Labor Party, a senator in this place, has got round to admitting some of the things that happened in 1975. I refer to a speech made by a Victorian colleague, Senator Robert Ray, who is a member of the Opposition. On 13 October 1982, at page 1363 of Hansard, he said:

The Australian Labor Party does not claim to be totally clean. I think the lowest point in Labor Party history was the Iraqi breakfast when the Labor Party tried to borrow overseas money to pay for its election debts. None of us in the Labor Party is proud of that.
I repeat what he said: 'None of us in the Labor Party is proud of that'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That was said by Senator Robert Ray, an ALP senator for Victoria. To my knowledge that is the first time that has been admitted in this Parliament . In fact, I think it is the first time it has ever been publicly admitted. At long last a Labor senator has had the courage to say: 'We are not proud of it'. I do not think honourable senators opposite are proud of bringing forward this subject today to maintain the rage. From observing the situation in the chamber at present, clearly there is less opposition now. As I was saying, when there is a crisis between the Executive Government and the parliament, the legislature, it is frequently because the government does not have the numbers in the Parliament. That was recognised by our founding fathers when they drew up the Constitution. They recognised that that would occasionally happen and they provided the solution. The solution is that the people should decide the matter. That is what happened in 1975. The conflict was resolved by an election. The Labor Party could have called an election if it had wanted but it refused to do so until ultimately it forced the then Governor-General to take steps to call an election in accordance with the Constitution to enable the people of Australia to decide the issue. Notwithstanding the rhetoric of Senator Evans, that was the fundamental principle in the Constitution when it was drawn up and it is a right and proper principle.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard today Senator Evans and others talking about the so-called failure of the Fraser Government. I refer them to a letter from a Mr A. K. Sandell of North Balwyn published in the Age of 2 November this year. It seems to me that Mr Sandell has a good grip on the constitutional problems of the country and on what the Labor Party should be involved in. He wrote:
. . . it would be disastrous if we made it impossible to remove a failing Government before its term expired except by violent revolution.
Is that not true? He continued:

If the Labor Party really believes its rhetoric about the failure of the Fraser Government to produce policies which will rescue Australia from its present predicament, then it is its obvious democratic duty to take whatever steps are available to it to remove that Government--

So he issues a challenge to the ALP. If the ALP believes its own rhetoric why does it not take steps to remove this Government? It can do so. The Labor Party, with the Democrats, has the power in this chamber to remove the Government, but it does not have the courage to do so. Mr Sandell went on to say:

I accuse Mr Hayden, Mr Hawke and Mr Chipp of being afraid to unseat the Government at this time, of hoping that conditions outside Australia will make governing less difficult in 12 months' time, and of concealing their lack of guts and the poverty of their remedies with a self-righteous plea that it is wrong under any circumstances to block Supply.

Again, he has put his finger right on the pulse of what is happening here at present. Senator Evans misunderstood, as he always does, many things. He misunderstood what Senator Sir John Carrick was saying about the consumer price index figures. I will now put him right by saying that the figures cited by Senator Sir John Carrick were the June annual figures-not quarterly figures-as provided by the Treasury. They are the official figures. They show that until 1973 the consumer price index inflation rate was 6 per cent. Twelve months after the Labor Party came into office, inflation rose to 12.9 per cent, which was double the 1973 figure. In 1974 it rose to 16.7 per cent. I have heard Senator Gietzelt complain about honourable senators on our side referring to an annual inflation rate of 21 per cent, a figure arrived at by multiplying the quarterly figure by four. I accept his criticism of honourable senators on our side who cite a figure of 21 per cent. We do not have to cite a figure of 21 per cent when the figure for the year ended 30 June 1975 was 16.7 per cent.

Of course, ever since the Fraser Government took office it has undoubtedly attacked and reduced inflation. At the same time as it has faced the problem of a world wide and increasing depression, it has managed to maintain social service benefits for the unemployed, for the sick and for those in need. Those are the reasons for high taxation, the relatively high consumer price index and the relatively high interest rates. These levels remain high because the Government is showing humanity in these areas. Of course, the Labor Party knows this. These are difficult times and in difficult times people seek instant solutions and scapegoats. The Labor Party is endeavouring to provide them with instant solutions of the sort of nonsense that My Hayden recently came up with but for which he was dealt such a demolishing blow by the editorial of the Australian Financial Review of 27 October, which stated-these are not my words or Liberal words but those from the editorial:

. . . it is easy for the Labor Party to make grandiose promises about spending stimulus through tax cuts or higher pensions and benefits, . . . to make capital grants for job creation, to maintain industry protection regardless of the viability of industries, and to maintain real wages.
It is easy for the Labor Party to say this. It continued:
This is what the Leader of the Opposition proposed in Parliament yesterday.
I ask honourable senators to listen to what the editorial then said:
It is a recipe . . . for economic disaster, . . .

The Labor Party blames the Fraser Government for Australia's economic problems but gives no solution. Instead it comes up with a recipe for economic disaster. Let me say what disappoints me about the debate today. Rather than encouraging this hatred and division within this nation, the Labor Party Opposition could be today proposing some sort of bipartisan or consensus approach--

TALK.START.PARA: —I have done that.

—Senator Evans claims to have done that. He has never been anything other than divisive from the first day he came into this chamber. In fact, before he came into this chamber he was publishing articles in newspapers which were totally divisive and he has maintained his divisiveness ever since. I say to you, Mr President, that the Labor Party could quite easily be talking about some sort of consensus approach. Yesterday Senator Walsh made a speech on a matter of public importance.
—Who?

—Senator Walsh. He is a Labor senator from Western Australia. He made a speech from which I would like to quote some of his words. He was talking about Keynesian remedies being supplemented by an effective prices and incomes policy. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia, federal governments have almost no coercive powers in the area of prices and incomes control.

He recognised that as being one of the major problems of any government, whether it was an ALP or a Liberal-National Party government. That would be one of the major problems in Australia. Now there may be a solution to some of our economic problems. We have a continuing world depression and that is difficult to cope with. But what else is happening is also creating problems in Australia, and that is the continuing demand for increased wages and less working hours. We could be coming up with some sort of consensus approach. If we suggested to State and Federal parliamentarians and to top level public servants that they should take a cut in their salaries, maybe we could then call upon professionals such as solicitors, doctors, barristers and lawyers and dentists not to increase their fees. We could issue a national call as a consensus with a bipartisan approach, but the ALP is not interested. All it does is attack this proposal. I say to you, Mr President, that we could have some sort of consensus approach whereby both parties-we could even include the Australian Democrats, although they have not been here today to take any interest in what is going on-could take some sort of consensus approach, a national call for a general cut in salaries at a top level and then a request to all the workers of this country not to seek wage rises or reductions in working hours. It may very well be successful. At least it would be a bipartisan consensus approach. I put that forward to the Opposition and clearly it is being rejected by its members, showing that they are not all interested in the economic problems of Australia. They are only interested in taking some political advantages of the difficulties being created in this country by world-wide problems and the actions of certain extreme trade union leaders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In case the Senate does not know, we are debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous economic, political, constitutional, parliamentary, and administrative consequences of November 11, 1975.

Because this is an important day for Australia and for the Government, I think it is proper that we should use this debate to review the sort of tone set by this Government in its past and present performance.

I remind the Senate that in the first three months after the Australian Labor Party won the 1972 elections members of this Government, Ministers now in this place, very consciously and improperly sought to bring about the downfall of the Whitlam Government. They sought to put the Government in a besieged position. I would remind the Senate that Senators Cotton, Withers, Guilfoyle, Webster and Carrick did everything possible in those early months, before any of the problems that have been referred to in this debate arose, to create obstacles and to obstruct the Government, which had won office for the first time in 23 years, in its proper task of administration and leadership of this country. As a result of that, within 15 months-in April 1974-Supply was delayed to such an extent that a double dissolution took place. As my remarks will subsequently suggest, that course was rejected by the Australian people and the Whitlam Government was given a second mandate. However, the same sort of obstruction and conspiracy continued. The Senate was again used in the latter part of 1975 for the purpose of bringing down the Government.

That Government was brought down as a result of a coup that was illegally and improperly engineered in a conspiratorial way by a Governor-General who can be described only as a drunk and besotted individual who had links with the Santamaria movement in this country, which hated the Labor Government, and links with an intelligence organisation. He conspired with a disloyal, opportunist, unscrupulous and immoral leader of the Liberal Party to bring into fruition the course of events that are now known as 11 November 1975.

What has happened in the subsequent period? For seven years this Government has had the responsibility of bringing about a state of economic prosperity, development and growth. It has failed dismally to do that. The Fraser Government , with which we are concerning ourselves today, is shown to be a government of corruption, hypocrisy and dishonesty which has to face scandal after scandal. A review of events since 1975 shows this to be the case. I would like to detail some of the key elements which make up the basis of the Fraser Government. These elements become clear if we pay attention to the statements that were made by then Opposition spokesmen in 1975. Just look at what Mr Fraser had to say. On 22 March 1975 the Australian newspaper contained an article headed 'Labor has the right to govern; Liberal leader takes pressure off Whitlam' in which Mr Fraser is reported as saying, prior to the double dissolution of 1974:

I generally believe that if a government is elected to power in the lower House and has the numbers and can maintain the numbers in the lower House, it is entitled to expect it will govern for the three-year term unless quite extraordinary events intervene.

As the party forming the government of the day-that is, the party which has the numbers in the lower House-we were asked to believe Mr Fraser and the Liberals. We were asked in March 1975 to trust the Opposition parties which less than a year before had forced the Labor Government to an early and premature election and which had engaged in a continual process of obstruction before and after that election.

I will give an example of that sort of obstruction. On 21 March 1974 the then Attorney-General, Senator Murphy, replied to a question. It is important to quote what Senator Murphy had to say then having regard to what Mr Fraser and Mr Anthony have said in recent times, that we have to consider the possibility of a premature election because of obstruction in the Australian Senate. This is what Senator Murphy said on 21 March 1974:
The honourable senator made a third request about the divisions which have taken place and about the results of the divisions demonstrating the obstruction by Opposition senators.
He was referring to senators of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Country Party of Australia. He continued:

I think I can comply with that request, and I will inform the Senate about this matter. There have been a number of divisions. On 6 March there were 8 divisions , and the Government was defeated 8 times. On 7 March there were 10 divisions and it was defeated 10 times. On 12 March there was one division and the Government was defeated. On 13 March there were 3 divisions and it was defeated 3 times. On 14 March there were 4 divisions and the Government was defeated 3 times. On 19 March there were 3 divisions and the Government was defeated 3 times. On 20 March there was one division and the Government was defeated.

Senator Murphy was referring to the autumn period of 1974. Yet the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) have the audacity, the gall and the effrontery to suggest that the Senate is playing an obstructive role when, in fact, we have dealt in a negative way with only four pieces of legislation by this Government in seven long, hard years. None of those was included in the mandate of the Fraser Administration. We make no apology for refusing to increase sales tax on the necessities of life, for refusing to apply tertiary fees for secondary students, and for refusing to impose penalties in regard to social security benefits for wives whose husbands may in some remote way be involved in industrial disputation. The only other such piece of legislation-it is currently before one of the Senate's committees- is that dealing with loans for students. So we can see what sort of hypocritical and dishonest government we have.

Let us again turn to Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. In October 1975, Senator Guilfoyle had resiled from Mr Fraser's earlier stated position that a government should be allowed to run its full term and carry out its program. On 22 October of that year, she said to the Senate:

We have no hesitation in saying to the Australian people that this Government has shown the dishonesty which requires it to face them for their verdict. We are using the mechanism of the elected senators in this country to force this Government to the Australian people. It is a situation where a government without integrity is too dangerous to be allowed to remain.
Senator Carrick had discovered this principle also. On the same day, while speaking on the Appropriation Bills, he told the Senate:

We come to the situation in which our responsibility is this: If we are satisfied that this is the most dishonest government, the most corrupt government and the government of the worst economic disaster in history, it is our bounden responsibility to bring it to the electors.

What is the position? As compared with unemployment in November 1975, we have now in November 1982, double the number of people out of work. We have an inflation rate which is approximating 14 per cent. We have the highest interest rates in Australia's history. We have economic downturn and a lack of confidence throughout the country.

Just look at the sort of scandals with which this Government is faced. We have had to have Ministers sacked for misleading the Parliament or for impropriety- Messrs Withers, Garland, Moore and MacKellar. We have had corruption of the highest order, including corruption in respect of tax-as brought out by the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. This Government has paid precious little attention to the wholesale rip-offs that have taken place. We cannot be really sure how much money has been ripped off because every second day the Treasurer (Mr Howard ) ups the amount of money that might have been lost. Certainly, somewhere between $1 billion, as he admitted in Parliament yesterday, and $5 billion, which has been suggested by others, has been lost by the inaction of this Government. If that is not corruption, I do not know what it is. It has failed to plug the holes that enable the wealthy to evade their tax responsibilities.

The Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd scandal, was of major magnitude. This Government saw fit not to take any action against the appropriate Minister. The meat substitution scandal has destroyed our reputation in overseas markets. In the last couple of days Mr Hunt-the former Minister for Health-admitted that the Government was losing at least $100m a year as a result of Medibank fraud. Evidence has shown that past Ministers such as McLeay and Garland have been involved in all sorts of behaviour indicating that we have a government whose honesty is very much under challenge. Yet it is suggested that the Government of this day is entitled to the confidence of the Australian people.

We have had indecisiveness about an early and premature election. As a result of the scrutiny of the Appropriation Bills we have learned of attempts by the Government to use taxpayers' money in the promotion of Government programs. Senator Carrick seems untroubled by all of this. He said:
The simple fact is that this Government-
He was talking about the Labor Government of 1975 and I will refer to what he said then and to the position today--
has been a government of abysmal misconduct and behaviour, a government which has had to sack one of its Deputy Prime Ministers and an Acting Prime Minister for misleading the public.

All of those allegations were not made about any personal impropriety of those Ministers or their personal integrity but about mistakes in public administration. That is not the record of recent Ministers who have been unceremoniously sacked as a result of public pressure, public disclosure and public debate in this place. This Government cannot say that it is handling the economy of this country in a satisfactory way. Of course, Senator Carrick is constantly on his feet talking about high inflation. Everybody knows that the next consumer price index figures will show a further increase in inflation. Everybody knows that today's figures are expected to show at least another 40 per cent increase in the unemployment figures. Everybody knows that our small business sector and the building industry is in a state of crisis which has not been seen for around 50 years in this country. In the cold light of today's facts the Fraser Government cannot stand up against such criteria and evidence.

The behaviour of the Fraser Government is blacker than anything that Senator Carrick and the other apologists in this debate can dream up in their rush to try to defend the Government and justify the conspiratorial attitude that it took in 1975. There is no doubt that this Government always seeks to blame everybody else. It has blamed the Whitlam Government that was in office for three brief years and which was forced into two elections in those three years. It has blamed the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and judges who have been appointed by it to carry out inquiries. It blames the workers. It blames the whole world for the recession or the depression. In fact, it blames everybody but itself.

Despite the unholy arrangement and alliance that took place during 1973, 1974 and 1975 the Government has the audacity to suggest in this place that the trade union movement and the Opposition should sit down, establish a consensus, and assist the Government. The only way in which this Government can be assisted is to be removed from office and a government of integrity elected in its place-a government that will activate itself in the interests of the Australian people in every sense of the word. We have a government now that has seen interest rates rise in recent times by 50 per cent, a government that cannot control inflation and a government that admits it has to get the Parliament up early because it is unable to provide solutions to today's problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the extaordinary mishmash of a speech that Senator Gietzelt just read to us there were some very strange statements which I will take issue with for just a couple of minutes before I get on to the subject of the matter of public importance. We had a reiteration of many things that we have heard in the Senate over the last seven years on a subject that has a fatal fascination for the Australian Labor Party. As long as the Labor Party chooses to look back seven years that fascination will be fatal. However, one remark by Senator Gietzelt made even me sit up and take note-that was the allegation that the dismissal of the Whitlam Government in 1975 was a result of a conspiracy between the Governor-General and Mr Santamaria. That is about the only new thing that I have heard today. It is a very interesting point.
—And the groupers.

—Senator Martyr has just reminded me of the term 'the groupers'. Apparently it was the groupers who did this. If that is as much wisdom as Senator Gietzelt has gathered in the last seven years in Opposition--
—What about the CIA?

—Did I leave out the Central Intelligence Agency? I beg the honourable senator's pardon. That does not help Senator Gietzelt's case very much but it adds a little extra colour to his speech-colour that contrasts strongly with the lack of substance. For the benefit of his speech writer I will comment on a couple of the things he got wrong so that he can get them right next time. Senator Gietzelt got it half right when he referred to the fact that the Whitlam Government was re-elected in 1974. What he needs to remind his speech writer is that the people of Australia chose not to give the Labor Party a majority in the Senate. The lament in Senator Gietzelt's speech about the Whitlam Government's not getting its own way all the time in the Senate should have taken account of the fact that this was a result of the choice of the Australian people. Even Senator Gietzelt cannot allege that Mr Santamaria had a hand in that Senate election result.
—Or the CIA either.

—I tend to regard the CIA as of minor importance in the subject, for understandable reasons. It is very strange indeed that Senator Gietzelt should say in tones of ringing indignation that Liberal spokesmen, in the Senate and elsewhere, improperly sought to bring about the downfall of the Whitlam Government after its election in 1972. That is the first time I have ever heard it suggested that there is something improper about an opposition trying to bring about the downfall of a government. I thought that was the role of an opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed having sat here in government for seven years watching the Labor Party in opposition I would have thought that that was what it has been trying to do for that time-imperfectly I will admit.

Senator Evans in his speech chose to use three words which apparently he must have had in the Press release he read to us. His three words in relation to the Government and various of its actions were, 'dogged', 'churlish' and 'pigheaded' . I suggest that Senator Evans ought to consider those words and their application to the Labor Party in government, in opposition and in the debate here today.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Martyr

TALK.START.PARA: —He says those words each morning as he looks in the mirror.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sentor MARTIN-I appreciate Senator Martyr's wit but this really is a serious subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —What, maintaining rage? It is a joke.

—It is important that we treat seriously the Labor Party's attempts to maintain rage so the people of Australia will be able to put their actions into some sort of proper perspective. As Senator Lewis said, these difficult times call for statesmanship from people in politics. It might be relevant, when talking about the economy as the Labor Party has chosen to do at length today, to consider some of the factors that affect the Australian economy . It might consider the fact that we have declining commodity prices. The Labor Party might admit that there is declining world trade and that the drought in Australia has had a dramatic effect on our country's earnings overseas. However, for the Labor Party to admit that would be to face the fact that exports support the economy of this country. We cannot put some political barrier around Australia, say we will fix up everything internally by propping up high wages and high costs within Australia, find some way of financing them-heavens knows which way-and that way we will all be right. The Labor Party is still insensitive to the profound importance of our primary industries in Australia. People in rural areas and provincial cities overwhelmingly rejected Labor Party policies when it was last in power. If the Labor Party continues with that sort of insensitivity to those fundamental factors and the economic health of this country then, I dare say, it will be overwhelmingly rejected again at the election next year.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Opposition and those honourable senators who have spoken today and those few who have chosen to listen to the debate that when honourable senators opposite bring up the subject of the consequences of 11 November 1975 and whip themselves into a lather about that day they should divert their attention for a couple of minutes and think about the implication of the consequences of the elections of December 1975, December 1977 and October 1980. The implication is that the Australian people have rejected the Labor Party. They have rejected its policies and its proposals for Australia. Since 1949 the Australian people, in their own particular wisdom, have elected Liberal governments for 30 years out of 33 years. They have elected Labor governments for three years. In elections the Australian people have shown a 10:1 preference for Liberal governments over Labor governments. Nevertheless, the Labor Party in the Senate still apparently regards Liberal governments to be an interregnum. The reason the Labor Party considers them to be an interregnum, although they have been in office 30 out of 33 years, is that it still does not find it necessary to examine seriously those alternative policies which are consistently rejected. Senator Evans might say that the public is dogged, churlish and pigheaded in its consistent rejection of Labor Party policies. It is just possible, though, that the Australian public considers that the Labor Party is dogged, churlish and pigheaded in insisting on putting forward the same recipe for economic disaster at election after election .

The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button), in some very florid rhetoric which did him credit but not his party and its policies, said that this Government is presiding over an economic crisis and socal inequities which are consequences of this Government's policies. Senator Button, as the senior spokesman of the Labor Party in this chamber of Parliament, paid no attention to the factors that I mentioned earlier that are impinging overwhelmingly on the Australian economy at the moment. I refer to commodity prices, world trade and the drought in Australia. He swept aside and ignored those factors. He referred to what he said were the consequences of government policies. He said that all economic problems and the social problems that flow from them are the fault of the Government. So long as Senator Evans has a mental block that extends so far as the shoreline of Australia he does not have an argument fit to justifiably put to the Australian people.

Of course Senator Button talked about consensus. He rubbished our views on consensus. I will deal with that in a minute or two. Senator Button and the Labor Party would do well to look at where the areas of consensus in the Australian community can be found. He should not try to turn everything into an area of division. Those Labor Party policies which are being reiterated yet again in a lead up to an election next year have been soundly criticised by many economists. I should like to quote from the Australian Financial Review of 27 October. In considering whether one ought to look at the Labor Party's policies as a credible alternative government the editorial stated:
The real danger is that the Labor Party might achieve power in the belief that it has answers to Australia's problems which do not take account of the constraints.
They are the constraints to which I have referred. The editorial continues:

In this climate it is easy for the Labor Party to make grandiose promises about spending stimulus through tax cuts or higher pensions and benefits, to avoid the need to increase government charges at a time when government enterprises are running huge deficits, to make capital grants for job creation, to maintain industry protection regardless of the viability of industries, and to maintain real wages.

This is what the Leader of the Opposition proposed in Parliament yesterday. It is a recipe not only for economic disaster, but also what is worse, given the need for a strong democratic system, for the ignominious collapse of yet another Labor Government if the ALP should win the next federal election. . . .

At the same time as proposing to maintain the real wages of the employed labour force at, inevitably, the expense of new investment and private sector employment creation, the Labor Party in Parliament yesterday proposed to increase government expenditures on social welfare benefits and job creation. How are these to be financed?

It is not enough to talk about more effective collection of tax from high income tax dodgers. Although there are undoubtedly large sums involved, they are nothing like the billions which the fantasies of some members of the Opposition would have it.
Those words, I remind the Senate, appeared in the editorial of the Australian Financial Review. It continued:

This leaves the Labor Party with a fiscal program which promises nothing but unemployment and inflation on a larger scale than we have now, and the prospect of further involuntary devaluations of the Australian dollar as we are locked into a devaluation/inflation spiral. . . .

With mounting unemployment and active protest by the unemployed, it is only too easy for the Labor Party to opt for easy package solutions which it freely promises will cure all problems without pain.

However, the Labor Party needs to consider whether it can deliver in terms of effective policies which will actually benefit the Australian economy. If it cannot, it is doomed to repeat the pattern of long period of Liberal government, interspersed with occasional disastrous short periods of ineffectual and disintegrating Labor governments.

They were the comments of an external observer. In the context of more spending, with some fantasy of where the money will come from for that spending, it is worth reminding the Labor Party what the current leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, said in 1975 when Treasurer in a Labor government. In his Budget Speech he stated:

It is not possible to provide more and more government services or transfer payments from the Budget without ultimately having to pay for them through cutting back after-tax earnings via increased taxes.
That is the solution Mr Hayden sees for the economic prescription which the Labor Party insisted on repeating to us today. Mr Hayden then said:
It is not possible to get quarts out of pint pots.

In its criticism today of the Fraser Government's record in the last seven years and its comment on the problems that face the country today, the Opposition harked back to the old, tired and frequently rejected policies that it has held for years-policies which even Mr Hayden disowned in 1975.

Senator Button attempted to rubbish consensus-a consensus which this country needs. he asked: 'Where was consensus in 1975?'. I suggest to Senator Button that in 1975 there was a consensus by the Australian public which the Labor Party then ignored at its peril. There was a consensus about the Labor Government's activities in relation to the loans affair and its economic policies. The electorate ultimately delivered its verdict and showed what was the consensus of the Australian public. It rejected the Labor Party in December 1975, and has continued to do so ever since.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation again highlights the extent of tax evasion and avoidance practices in this country and the development of those practices during the period of the Fraser Government. In fact it is instructive to look at this report of the Commissioner of Taxation in the light of his previous reports for the years ending 1979, 1980 and 1981 which document the growth of the tax evasion industry. The Commissioner points out in this report for the year ended 30 June 1982 that an analysis of income tax objections lodged by tax avoidance scheme participants reveals that in that year 24,972 potential taxpayers were identified as having been involved in 'blatant, artificial and contrived schemes'. Some $1,035m had been assessed in that period as due by participants in attempted tax avoidance schemes and, under administrative challenge, that amount of revenue still remains outstanding. There is a further $465m in tax owed to the Commissioner of Taxation by stripped companies.

The Senate has already heard today, in the course of an earlier discussion, reference to Professor Russell Mathews's speech at the Institute of Political Science seminar in January of this year. Professor Mathews drew attention to the fact that if the Fraser Government had devoted as much attention to collecting revenue as it had to so-called limitations on government expenditure there would be no need for any increase in taxation in this country. Professor Mathews was, of course, talking about taxation increased by stealth. He also referred in that paper to the implications of the revenue lost through tax avoidance. The important point I wish to make in respect of the Taxation Commissioner's report is that for four years now the Commissioner has complained of his incapacity to deal with tax evasion schemes because of a shortage of staff and because of a deliberate policy imposed on him by the Government. That matter is again referred to in the annual report for the year 1982. At page 21 the Commissioner states:

It is noteworthy that, in revenue terms, overall results for the year were marginally ahead of the 1980-81 year despite a significant drop in the numbers of cases completed by all programs brought about largely by the decrease in staff ceiling in 1981 and the need to devote additional resources to tax avoidance activities. That greater revenue was obtained from fewer completed cases tends to confirm the view expressed last year that tax evasion appears to be increasing. This is, of course, a matter of considerable concern to me.
Earlier in that section, under the heading 'Tax Evasion and Fraud', he stated:
Enforcement programs to detect income tax evasion and fraud continued to be carried out during the 1981-82 year in the form of investigations . . .

He referred to the slight increase in revenue gained by that increase in activity. As I said, the Commissioner has complained in his last four reports about the inadequacy of staff and the imposition of a policy by this Government on him which has prevented the collection of tax from many people whom the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has described in the most derogatory terms and who should be paying taxes but who are avoiding their tax obligations. That emphasises two facts about the Government: Either it is not genuine and bona fide in its stated intentions about tax evasion or it is incompetent. There is no other choice left if one reads the reports of the Taxation Commissioner over the last four or five years. I do not know which description the Government opts for as the favoured description of its activities or inactivities in respect of the collection of tax revenue; that is up to the Government to decide. But there is no alternative conclusion. It is now admitted that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Prime Minister knew in 1977 that blatant frauds were taking place and nothing has been done about them. That situation is documented. The ignoring of the Taxation Commissioner's reports in that context reveals the incompetence, negligence and lack of will of the Government in relation to this issue.

That is the only point I wish to draw from the Taxation Commissioner's report. The rest of the report is devoted to rather technical and detailed material, to taxation review boards and matters of that kind.
