DEBATE.TITLE: DRIED FRUITS EXPORT CHARGES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 September, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall take the time of the Senate only briefly. I take the opportunity on the first reading of the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill, which is a money Bill, to make some further remarks about a question which I asked in the Senate yesterday. That question concerned fraud involving international airline tickets. I do that because this morning I have been contacted by New Zealand television with a request for an interview. I was informed that apparently the Minister for Civil Aviation in New Zealand this morning either has made a statement on this matter or has been interviewed by New Zealand television on this matter. New Zealand television has asked me whether I could explain details of the scheme. I have taken this opportunity to raise this matter so that I can get the details into Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been informed that a multimillion dollar fraud involving tickets for international flights has been discovered in the Melbourne and Sydney offices of Qantas Airways Ltd. I have been informed also that other airlines are checking to ascertain whether they have been defrauded. Apparently criminal prosecutions are likely against several previously reputable travel agents as a result of the fraud. The scheme has taken advantage of the 30 per cent exchange rate difference between Australian and New Zealand dollars, that difference, of course, being in favour of Australian dollars.

What the travel agents have been doing is importing ticket coupons from New Zealand and tailoring these tickets to the travel requirements of their customers who start their international journeys in Australia. The tickets have coupons written for the Wellington-Sydney, the Christchurch-Sydney or the Auckland-Sydney sector to prove that the passenger started his flight in New Zealand. I have been sent some duplicates of tickets from New Zealand which prove this point. One ticket that I have shows that the journey Christchurch to Melbourne is written on the ticket as 'open'. Then the ticket provides for travel from Melbourne to Auckland, Auckland to Los Angeles, et cetera; all the details of the flights are given on the ticket. At the end of this ticket the details are filled out for a flight from London to Melbourne with the section from Melbourne to Christchurch left open. Of course, the Australian passenger who boarded the aircraft in Melbourne will not go back to Christchurch as shown in the details of the ticket. The coupons for the two sectors that I have been talking about are torn out, leaving the carbon copy, to make it appear as if the ticket is already partly used.

Because the Australian dollar is worth 30 per cent more than the New Zealand dollar, travel agents can sell these tickets for less than the normal Australian price, often charging the passenger the New Zealand price plus half of the difference between the two prices. This is still substantially less than the full Australian price. The fraud arises because the airline whose ticketing the flight coupons are written on redeems them in New Zealand. It then gets paid in New Zealand currency, effectively at a rate substantially lower than the applicable fare level in Australian dollars. That is how this fraud scheme has been worked in detail.

The reason why I raised the question yesterday is that I have been led to believe that not only are the travel agents who sell these tickets liable for prosecution but also there could be a case in which people who have knowingly taken part in this scheme, airline passengers themselves, would be liable for prosecution. It does not worry me if some of the smart operators get caught. If people knowingly buy the ticket, that is their fault. I would submit that probably many people who have been involved in this fraud, if they were caught and had to pay the full price of the ticket, would be in a position financially to pay the full price. What concerns me is the person travelling on an international airline for the first time who really cannot afford the money and does not know the applicable fare rates. He or she may go to a travel agent and be told by him: 'Here is a ticket to a particular place. It will cost you X amount of dollars'. According to the advice that I have been given, if on presentation of that ticket to the airline in Melbourne or Sydney it is found to be wrongly issued, that person is liable to be charged the full fare. Because he or she did not travel from New Zealand to Melbourne or Sydney in the first place , the amount would be quite substantial. That person, unknowingly, could then be placed in a situation of serious financial embarrassment.

That concludes the remarks that I wish to make on this matter. I have taken this opportunity to get the details into Hansard as they are required by the New Zealand authorities who are looking at this matter today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill. By tradition, of course, on the first reading of such a Bill, honourable senators may raise other matters that they consider to be of some importance. I inform the Senate that I do not intend to talk about the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill. I intend to raise something else -again just briefly, because time in these debates is very short-that I think needs raising and will need raising frequently because of the low level of awareness of governments and, indeed, of individuals in Australia of the problem .

SPEECH.PARA: In recent times I have had occasion in a number of venues to make some reference to the position of women in Australia. I want to take some areas of their situation as I see it today which I think are urgent for government attention and for public debate so that the situation is appreciated, the implications of the situation are appreciated and some action can be taken. I note that the Minister present in the chamber is the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). Whilst I am aware that the Minister does not reply on a first reading debate, I am pleased that he is here because some of the things I have to say I think are particularly applicable to his area.

Women in Australia today are in a situation which has historic origins. It is not very long ago, only 20 to 30 years ago, that the expectations of women in Australia and the expectations of the parents of girls were very particular. The expectation was that girls would marry, probably not very long after leaving school, that they would have a family and that they would not re-enter the work force. The expectation between leaving school and marrying and having a family was that they would work for a short time. But, since they were not likely to need training and skills which were to take them through life to provide them with a home or with any of the pleasures that a superior economic position provides Australians with, as it was not considered that they would have to provide those aspects themselves, education was not considered a priority for girls.

It is not very long ago, indeed less than 30 years ago, that most girls in Australia were educated only to the age of 13 years, that is, to a level of only basic competence in literacy and numeracy. Those girls of 25 years ago are now women, some of them still in their 30s, certainly many of them in their early 40s and over, who face a very different Australia from the one that their parents thought they would have to face and that they thought they would have to face as they grew into adulthood and made choices in relation to marriage, employment and education themselves.

The situation simply is that in Australia most women over the age of 40 years have a level of education which is not much above just basic literacy and numeracy. However, we have an increasing divorce rate in Australia and we have increasingly a situation in which women are head of the household and are responsible for providing for the economic and other welfare well-being of the children of this country. As I have indicated, those women are not skilled or well educated and, therefore, are not fitted to enter the work force seeking high or even reasonable remuneration in jobs which would enable them to achieve individual goals, such as home ownership to provide for their own old age, or some of the benefits of the generally high standard of living in Australia that they might seek for their children.

I would like to mention some of the comparisons in the rates of employment between men and women where there is only one adult head of household to show how the situation breaks down. The figures for 1981 showed that of the sole heads of households who were men, 82.5 per cent were in the work force-12.1 per cent were not in the labour force or seeking work. On the other hand of the sole heads of households who were women, only 37.6 per cent were in the work force. I do not believe that that indicates that those women would not like to work and would not like to earn something a little above what they receive on the supporting parent's benefit and the benefits associated with it. In fact the result of a survey carried out in 1978 by the New South Wales Council of Social Service was, in very general terms, that women with dependent children were as negative about not working as those who did not have dependent children. In other words, those who had dependent children would have preferred to work in the same proportions as those who did not have dependent children. These women have indicated that they would like to work but the structures of our society make that virtually impossible. The structures impinge on that historic situation, to which I referred a few minutes ago, that very few of these women finished their education with skills of a level which would carry them into any satisfactory position in the work force. Not only do they lack employment skills but also they lack confidence.

Those of us-I think that includes every honourable senator in the chamber now and most honourable senators generally-who, since finishing our education, have been continuously in employment do not always understand the effect that being out of employment for extended periods has on morale and confidence. For women who took themselves out of the work force because they were bearing children and rearing young children that extends to a very significant period. I am not talking about just those who are on an extended period of unemployment because of economic circumstances; I am talking of those who, for 10, 15 or maybe more years, voluntarily did not seek paid employment in the work force or voluntarily did not seek to put themselves in a position of having to please a boss or gear themselves to a task that was outside their homes. It becomes an enormous psychological hurdle for women at the age of 40, who might have left the work force in their early twenties, to re-enter what has by then become an alien and, they might feel, probably even an unknown atmosphere. It is all the more so when they know, through reading advertisements in 'Positions Vacant' columns and applying for jobs, that because of their lack of recent work experience and their general lack of skills really they are regarded as basically unemployable by those who have jobs at their disposal. Whatever confidence some of them may have summoned up to try disappears very rapidly. It becomes very easy for them to remain on a pension although they may well have had a feeling that they would have preferred not to.

The reasons for wanting to go into employment are not just economic and are not just related to the fact that one can get a higher income than the amount which one receives on the supporting parent's benefit. It also has a lot to do with personal dignity. Attempts to achieve the level of personal dignity that is associated with paid employment of a reasonable level are very short lived for very many women. The figures that I gave much earlier showing the contrast in the position between men and women with dependent children I think proves that. It is not enough to assume, just because one parent is looking after dependent children, that therefore that person cannot exercise the option of going into the work force. Men do when they have dependent children and they do it more than twice as successfully as women who have dependent children.

The figures for women on their own without dependent children also bear out my thesis. Those figures show that only 33.3 per cent are in the work force, an even lower percentage than for those with dependent children. In my opinion that is a legacy of that employment situation to which I referred. The older women in their late forties and their fifties who have been out of the work force while they had dependent children reach a stage where their children are no longer dependent and they may well try to seek to re-enter the work force. But they find on their own-on a widow's pension or on some sort of superannuation that might have been left to them by their husbands-that, in the view of current employers, they are absolutely unemployable. Therefore, only 33.3 per cent-one- third of them-are actually in the work force. It is very sad to think that at that stage of life, when one has many years of vigour and industry ahead and one would like to be earning as much as possible to provide for old age, when the option of work might not be so readily available for personal reasons, one is doomed to a pension existence and does not have the option of extending one's capacity to work.

Figures relative to the position of sole parents in an Australian Capital Territory survey showed that 90 per cent of sole parents live solely on the supporting parent's benefit. In most cases where there is a single parent situation that parent is a woman. This shows that a very high rate of women are transferred on to the supporting parent's benefit when they are having children. The indications of the New South Wales survey to which I referred are that that is not because women want it that way. They might want it another way.

I suggest very briefly that governments, be they national or State, ought to look at this matter with some urgency. Some people like to pay great attention to the amount of money that we are paying out in pensions. They refer particularly to the supporting parent's benefit. We are all familiar with those people in the community who insist that it is all because of a mob of immoral young girls who are having babies in order to support themselves. But the truth does not support those allegations at all. The truth is that most of them would probably prefer to be in employment and not on this type of social welfare-an area of social welfare that admittedly is growing very rapidly and about which we ought to be concerned. We should not be concerned about whether we can take that benefit off these people and let them fend as best they can without recognising that many of those people-women in particular-are not in a position to fend for themselves.

I have already referred to the historic legacy of education. I do not think it is something that we have to live with forever. However, the structure of our education system, particularly our schools to which those people would have to return, militates against the entry of adults. I am very attracted to the community college system in Tasmania, where it seems that from mid-high school on there is a loosening-up of the old institutionalisation of our high schools. That sort of loosening-up, which on the basis of the information I have been given has not had any deleterious effect in Tasmania would, I think, enable many adults-in this case women who are looking after young dependent children-to go back to school through the day, and under those sorts of optimum conditions get a more soundly based high school education which will give them the confidence to attempt either higher education or to try to seek employment. I would like to mention one other small factor because I think it illustrates my general claim that governments do not understand the factors of this modern society as it has developed in the last ten years. They may mean well but they do not understand because they think in terms of the effects that old policies which are continuing policies have, and the hopeless position in which they put people.

I will instance very briefly, as I have in other places. Quite commonly I get inquiries to my office from women with young kiddies who receive the supporting parent benefit and who urgently have to find new accommodation. I have found the Queensland Housing Commission to be very co-operative in attempting to find them accommodation quickly because it recognises the urgency of such a situation. However, invariably the house is in Beaudesert or somewhere like that. There are housing commission ghettoes of single parents, particularly mothers, in that position where they are distant from employment, from education, from public transport and indeed from jobs. The positioning of those women in those sorts of housing commission acreages does not give them any option. They become locked into the pension until they are of an age where they have lost hope. I believe it is urgent-quite obviously, it is urgent for economic reasons, but it is also urgent for personal reasons-that the Government should face the reality of the new Australia that we are now versus the Australia we thought we were preparing ourselves for 20 or 30 years ago and not just turn its back on or dismiss as too hard the enormous human casualties that are occurring amongst women in our community, some of them as young as in their 30s but also those older.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time allocated to me to speak to the motion for the first reading of the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill 1982 I wish to raise the subject of a tragedy which I hope I will never have to raise again. On 30 September this year a Cessna 205 aeroplane departed from Mount Isa en route to Atherton, which is a distance of roughly 411 nautical miles. It was scheduled to arrive at Atherton at 6.25 p.m. but it never landed, certainly not in that location. The Atherton airstrip is unlit and has no navigational aids for bringing in planes in times of squally weather or cloud. On this particular date a smoke haze covered a large portion of north Queensland , which made visibility fairly bad in a number of other areas also. The points that I want to highlight are why the equipment was not available, why more activity had not been shown by those in authority and why governments, both State and Federal, have absolved themselves of all responsibility for the tragedy that took place.

SPEECH.PARA: At 6.20 p.m. on that date the pilot reported that he was lost and he made initial radio contact with a ham radio operator at Edge Hill, which is a suburb of Cairns. He was not picked up by official radio because, apparently, the official radio was not manned. His last report came in at 8.40 p.m., which was two hours and 20 minutes later. At that stage he was running out of fuel and he still had not been properly located. He reported that he was disoriented and totally unable to locate the Atherton Airport. On Tuesday, 19 October, Ray Jones , the State member for Cairns, put a series of eight questions to the State Minister for Transport to try to ascertain what went wrong. The questions were well framed and the Minister's terse reply was in three paragraphs, as follows:
In answer to the Honourable Member, all of the matters raised by the Honourable Member are directly under the jurisdiction of my Commonwealth counterpart.
According to information conveyed to me, the aircraft in question was on a private flight at the relevant time and therefore was not subject to any State issued Air License.
May I suggest that the Honourable Member direct his question to my Commonwealth counterpart.

That is not much comfort to someone who is trying to dig deeply into the problem to see what actually went wrong. But, because of the official bungling, five lives were lost. They were the pilot, two children aged eight and six, and the children's father and grandfather. At 6.30 p.m. the pilot reported that he was completely disoriented and still could not locate Atherton.

This raises a number of questions. Firstly, was the meteorological station at Cairns unmanned at the time? I believe it was. Secondly, as the plane obviously kept in semi-continuous radio contact, why was not the instrument landing system at Cairns, if it still operates, activated and radio used to bring in the plane, particularly as the plane apparently went down within a radius of about 36 kilometres of Cairns? Thirdly, did the plane crash into the sea near Feather Reef, which was the first theory that some of the bureaucracy had? Fourthly, was it also possible that it crashed into some other area, perhaps in the rain forest covered mountains? I heard one report of a plane, obviously in difficulty , in the Kamerunga area but as far as I know that was not even searched.

Another problem is that the staff of the Cairns Airport weather office has apparently been reduced from five to three. Along the north coast, there are a number of stations where, because of the activities of the razor gang, this sort of reduction of staff will take place. So this particular instance may be repeated many times over, particularly in squally weather with the onset of the wet season, which is only a few weeks away.

Another question that has to be raised is: Why was the plane allowed by the authorities to depart from Mount Isa with such a fine margin before last light and with the termination of the flight on an unlit landing ground? The expected last light on that day, because of the haze, was about 6.40 p.m. The estimated time of arrival was 6.25 p.m. Seas in the area on that evening were very rough, with strong south-east winds ranging from 20 to 25 knots, so that a small plane going down in the sea probably would have sunk straight away. If it had landed with its nose down it is possible that the front of the plane would have been pushed in and a large amount of water would have taken it down straight away. The only thing that might have saved it, if the tanks were not ruptured on impact, was that there was no fuel. That might have given it some bouyancy.

I ask this question of the Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife): Is it a fact that light aeroplanes which fly over water either by accident or design are not compelled to carry life jackets or life rafts? The official explanation for this , as I understand it, was that as the plane took off from Mount Isa and did not usually fly over water, almost certainly it would not have been carrying any rescue gear. I think a reply should be available as to whether this Cessna 205 was in fact carrying any sort of life raft or life jackets.

Delays need explanation. When at 6.20 p.m. the pilot radioed that he was lost, there were some very strange delays. The naval vessel HMAS Townsville did not commence a search until 10.40 p.m. In fact the Navy was not advised that there was an aeroplane in trouble until 9.30 p.m. This was 50 minutes after the plane had disappeared. When HMAS Townsville took off it was instructed to make a circular search 32 kilometres to the north and south of Cape Grafton. On the night of 30 September the coast watch at Canberra was on standby, as well as coastguards at Innisfail and Cairns. Some of the first signals that came back were taken by officers at the Townsville Airport. On the next day, 12 aircraft from Cairns and Townsville were despatched to take part in the search. It was finally called off about a week later. A number of ships and boats were also engaged in the search, including the local police boat, HMAS Townsville and some of the prawn trawlers. But the Queensland Government is allowed to escape by saying that it is not its responsibility. The old man who is the Minister for Transport has apparently adopted that attitude ever since. The Queensland Government could not care less. Apparently, the Queensland Government did not get involved at any stage with the search aspect.

I pose these questions and I hope that the Minister will take them seriously: Why does Atherton not have a track guidance system or some sort of aid to help planes in difficulty, particularly at the approach of last light or straight after last light? Why was a plane cleared for takeoff with an estimated time of arrival dangerously close to last light? Taxpayers pay millions of dollars for coastal surveillance. When a tragedy was about to occur with a two-hour margin- nothing was done until the plane disappeared-one wonders what advantage there is in setting up any sort of surveillance at all. Nothing was heard as to whether the air surveillance people were used. In fact, I have been always highly critical of the civilian surveillance that we use around our coastline.

I recite again the occasion when I was in a far northern motel having breakfast one morning. I asked a gentleman at the table what he did. He told me that he was an observer and that he did not know much about the place. He did not know anything about aeroplanes but he had some slight knowledge of ships. He said that he probably would be able to identify them. In any case he said: 'We are not staying out too late today. We have a party in Cairns tonight so we are getting back early'. This meant that a whole strip of coastline was missed out while they went back for their grog party. Again that highlights the necessity, of course, to have proper and competent people doing this job, people who are trained and disciplined, such as people in the Royal Australian Air Force and the Navy.

I ask these further questions: Were search and rescue operations not available because it was a public holiday in Queensland? It was the day that was gazetted as a public holiday for the opening of the Commonwealth Games. This sort of complaint has been heard before. It is said that if an enemy wants to land by either plane or boat in Darwin the best day to come in is Saturday, Sunday or a public holiday when, apparently, radar as well as all other safeguards are unmanned. Cairns is notorious for unusual weather. I recite these past events to emphasise again what can go wrong unless search and rescue operations are set in train immediately. On 3 October 1975 a Heron aircraft en route from Mount Isa to Cairns-actually it started off in Alice Springs; at one time there used to be a regular flight across that route-got into murky weather and crashed into a cane paddock near Holloways Beach which is just north of Cairns. There were 11 persons, including passengers and crew, on that plane. All were killed. A few weeks after that-getting closer to the monsoon season-I was coming in from Weipa one night. Again I was on a scheduled commercial flight in a small plane. We went very close to coming to grief in the same way. The aerodromes behind us were out because of the weather and we could not return to any of them. So, we had to keep attempting to make a landing at Cairns. We finally got in. There are three rather dangerous landings that I have had at that airport-once on a charter flight and on two other occasions on regular aeroplane flights. All were emergency landings.

It is too late now to save the lives of the persons involved. But the massive sums of money that were obviously unsuccessfully used in this search after the event could have been better spent in advance in making sure that all of those stations were adequately staffed. If we are to continue to cut back staff there will be more tragedies of this nature. The money could also be spent on putting some sort of landing aids at Atherton Airport and other small aeroplane landing areas around other small towns in the far north of Queensland. It could be better spent in setting up navigational aids at various points so that in particular small planes which get into trouble at least would be able to make contact and be guided to some safe landing spot.

I cannot over-emphasise the fact that there seemed to be a totally unco- ordinated operation. In two hours there should have been an opportunity for a proper search and rescue operation to be carried out. But because of a series of mini tragedies associated with the major tragedy none of these things came into operation at the time they should have. Had we had proper manning of stations in the Cairns area the ham operator would have been merely a supplementary person in the search to try to save that aeroplane and its five passengers. I feel particularly sad about the fact that two tiny children-a six year old and an eight year old-were killed on that flight as was their father. So, there is a family now wrecked by tragedy. I hope that the Minister will take note of the points that I have raised and endeavour-even if we are in a time of economic crisis-to provide the necessary aids and the necessary organisation for a search and rescue operation that can be implemented not in one, two or three hours' time but within minutes of when the first distress call is received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take advantage of the first reading of the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill to draw the attention of the Senate again to the developments around the Nugan Hand bank and white collar crime. This Government claims that there is a need for a special crimes commission to handle these sorts of major rip-offs and major areas of criminality that are obviously taking place in Australia. This is the third time I have utilised such an opportunity. Of course, I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden), the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) and I during this year on numerous occasions have called for a proper judicial inquiry, particularly into the nefarious and subversive activities of the Nugan Hand organisation. I remind the Senate that in a paper presented to both Houses of Parliament on 20 April 1982 by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and the Solicitor-General, Mr Byers, following numerous submissions made by the Opposition, we have this rather unusual response from the Government. The Government sought the opinion of the Commonwealth's law officers. Here again one has only to say how deficient is the information given to the law officers by the Commonwealth Government having regard to the reports that were placed before the Parliament at that time. I refer to the statement put down in this place by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). The statement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Law Officers have formed the opinion that an extension of the terms of reference of the Royal Commission-

Of course, we are referring to the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking of which there is another volume; volume 2 was tabled today in the Senate and earlier in the week in the House of Representatives-
Is warranted to cover allegations of:
Nugan Hand's involvement in drug dealing, beyond any association with the Clark group;
Nugan Hand's laundering of money, and association with organised crime;
Interference with earlier investigation of Nugan Hand.
The Government's report states:

The Government has noted the Law Officer's conclusion that the need for a specific inquiry into any foreign intelligence agency links has not been established. There have been firm United States denials about CIA involvement with Nugan Hand. The Government intends, however, that the extended terms of reference will be wide enough to allow the Commission to investigate Nugan Hand links with any organisation.
I quote from another portion on the same page. It states:

As the Minister had indicated to the House, the Government has had repeated assurances from the United States Government that there was no connection between the CIA and Nugan Hand. On 26 March 1982 the Public Affairs Division of the CIA took the unusual step of issuing a statement responding to allegations about links between Nugan Hand and the CIA and operations by the CIA against the Labor Government. It emphatically denied those allegations. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the text of a cable handed to the Government by the US Embassy referring to the statement by the Public Affairs Division of the CIA.

That is part of the law officer's report. Now I would like to refer to page 299 of volume 2 of the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking dealing with one of the principal operators the man whose name is associated with the bank, Michael Hand and the United States of America intelligence services. It states:

There seems to be little doubt that Michael Hand became involved with U.S. military intelligence activity during his military service in Vietnam and South East Asia (1964-7) if not before that time. His subsequent business activities in Australia in the late 1960s and early 1970s with members and former members of the C.I.A. controlled airline Air America (formerly Civil Air Transport) and C.I.A. connected Continental Air Service (C.A.S.) and Agency for International Development (A.I.D.), lead to the strong inference that Hand's intelligence activity was with the C.I.A.

There is some evidence to suggest that Hand retained his U.S. intelligence ties -whatever they might have been-throughout the 1970s and probably into the 1980s. For example, in handwritten notes Nugan made to himself exploring the business prospects for Nugan Hand in South East Asia, apparently between 1977-9, Nugan wrote: 'Mike good Vietnam specialist (C.I.A.) tough physically'. Other examples which support this view are Maurice Houghton, his relationship with Hand, his role in Nugan Hand and his apparent connections not only with U.S. intelligence personnel but also with personnel in Australia's own A.S.I.O.

The same report at page 409 deals with Mr Houghton. Honourable senators might recall that he was given a clearance by Australian Security Intelligence Organisation agents and, quite coincidentally and unusually, he was given a character reference by two former Hungarians, Messrs Charody and Strasser, who were party to a major development organisation in Sydney. He was bailed up at Sydney Airport. This man Houghton is clearly known to be involved in white collar crime, drug running and all of the other nefarious activities of the Nugan Hand organisation. Mr Justice Stewart said about Houghton:

On the information available it is probable that Houghton was associated with U .S. intelligence personnel in South East Asia and Australia, and had some type of association with personnel in Australia's intelligence agency, A.S.I.O. Hand too had an involvement with U.S. intelligence services and there seems to be little doubt that this common background was the very root of their relationship . Though that is not to say that their relationship was one of intelligence activity.

I indicated earlier that there was a great deal of derision in the Government ranks when I referred to the fact that there was abundant evidence that the Central Intelligence Agency had a vested interest in the overthrow of the Whitlam Government. There was similar mirth when I made suggestions about Mr Santamaria. The records show that Mr Bartholemew Santamaria saw Sir John Kerr only a few days before the coup of 11 November 1975 took place. So let us not have any illusions whatsoever that the CIA and Mr Santamaria who has agents in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation were not involved in some part of that conspiracy to overthrow the Whitlam Government. Let us not have any doubt that, in respect of this report about drug trafficking, the Joint Task Force and the activities of Nugan Hand, the CIA is lying about its involvement in the internal affairs of countries throughout the world. The record shows that it has been involved on a world-wide basis in destabilising governments that it believes are not friendly to its interests or governments which have some economic reason to curtail the activities of American business interests. There is no doubt at all that the CIA, even though it is now a popular whipping horse, was involved in these activities.

There is abundant evidence available in the United States Congress, in a film on company business and in books, that the CIA was involved in the murder and assassination of leading members of governments that it considered were not friendly to its interests. Let us have no doubt about that. The CIA was involved in the overthrow of former Prime Minister Mossadegh in the 1950s. That assassination finally led to the problems that exist in Iran today. Let us not seize upon this as something of little consequence or of little moment. It is a matter of considerable concern that this report confirms that there is every reason to believe that that organisation had an ulterior motive in the events of 1975 and the overthrow of the Whitlam Government, having regard to the fact that the Whitlam Government was required to renegotiate the agreements relating to American installations and bases in this country.

I believe this report is a most welcome addition to the sum of material on the activities and the criminal links of the Nugan Hand Bank. One newspaper reporter suggested yesterday that the bank seems to have been involved in every other form of illegal and subversive activity except banking. That seems to be beyond any doubt at all. I recall that when I first raised these matters some of my colleagues whose support and friendship I enjoy from time to time were somewhat incredulous that there should be this sort of organisation operating in Australia when I pointed out their links with the Narcotics Bureau in this country. This report indicates that, in fact, a lot of that evidence has now been made public.

This report brings together many of the fragments of information relating to Nugan Hand. It gives us an accurate background which is an essential prerequisite for an objective understanding of the past and present day drug and other activities, legal and otherwise, in or affecting Australia, of those under investigation and perhaps the operation of the drug trade generally. This report gives us a more complete picture of Nugan Hand's activities. The picture will improve, of course, when the confidential material which has been deleted from the report becomes available. The report shows clearly that the Opposition's long held concern with Nugan Hand has been warranted. It confirms what Mr Hayden , Mr Bowen and I have said. It highlights a number of important matters that I would like to highlight again. It highlights a significant linkage of drug- related and organised crime in Australia. It highlights that a number of senior crime figures are related to this organisation. It highlights a need for investigation of the link between intelligence agencies, particularly the CIA and ASIO, and drug-related crimes. It highlights the neglect of the Government of this important matter which can be counterposed in the Opposition's concern and a need to expand the terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission properly to take into account the spread and linkages of organised crime in Australia.

If one looked at those links throughout the report one would see confirmed the broad links that operate in the Australian drug world. Listed at pages 484 and 486 of the report is a schedule of drug traffickers known to have had dealings with Nugan Hand. It reads like a who's who of the drug crime world. Names like Murray Riley, James Sweetman, Andrew Lowe, Mr Wainwright, the Mr Asia syndicate and other people are mentioned. The extent of these things cannot be overstressed. Experts have argued that these links have existed. The Opposition has long put that view. Only now, in late 1982, are these arguments being confirmed as a result of this report. This is shown in chapter 16.

The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, raised the Nugan Hand-CIA link in Parliament in March and April this year. The Government did not take his comments seriously. As recently as Tuesday, the Government was seeking still to downgrade the issue in the House. The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) quoted a statement from the CIA at some length as he did in April this year. The CIA naturally denied that it was involved in these sorts of activity. Therefore, the Government does not take the matter seriously. It will be to its everlasting regret if it does not carry on the work and look at what was done by people like Colby, Yates, Black, Vasey, Holgrean, Pauker, Houghton, Hand and all of those who have been substantially involved in the Nugan Hand organisation and whose links with the CIA are clearly outlined. Mr Hayden raised these matters, as did I. The activities particularly of Bernard Houghton and other matters have been raised in a series of articles in the National Times. All of these matters have been glossed over in the past.

The Government's response to the mounting evidence has been to ignore it, to sweep it under the carpet. Yet now, as this information comes to light, we have to say that the Government misled the Parliament when it produced that report earlier this year. It simply denied it. The Government has extended the terms of reference of the royal commission and obviously further links will be uncovered in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to refer to the prices and incomes policy which is currently being put forward by the Australian Labor Party, at least in name. In fact, apart from the occasional references to a prices and incomes policy in the Parliament and the odd Press release, Labor has done very little to explain its policy, how it will work and what it is designed to do. It is one thing to say that we should have control of prices and wages and it is quite another thing to say at what level prices and wages should be pegged and what rate of increase is commensurate with the other economic goals. It is one thing to say, as is stated in a joint Press release of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Dolan:

SPEECH.PARA: The components of a prices and incomes policy are agreed between the parties rather than imposed by the Government . . .

It is yet another to explain how that agreement is to be reached, or even, if such an agreement is attainable, why the policy is necessary in the first place. It is stated that the policy is 'directed towards equitable redistribution of income as well as basic economic objectives'. That does not explain whether the two are reconcilable or how the two concepts are defined in the first place. In other words, it becomes apparent that once the prices and incomes policy is stripped of its rhetoric very little of real substance remains.

From the little that one is able to glean from the announcements made from Mr Hayden and Mr Dolan, however, one thing is immediately apparent: The policy, to say the least, is one sided. On the one hand it promises 'a pricing authority with legislative criteria to assess price rise proposals by corporations within its jurisdiction'. That is, to control prices there will be a sort of revamped Prices Justification Tribunal with the power to decide whether a certain price increase is justified. When it comes to wages, we are promised a centralised wage fixing system in which full cost of living adjustments will be advocated as well as the maintenance in real terms of over award payments. We are also promised that wage and salary earners will share in national productivity gains 'either through increased real incomes or reduced hours, or an appropriate combination of both'.

The implication of the Labor prices and incomes policy is very clear. On the one hand it would establish a mechanism by which prices would be controlled and on the other it would rely on promises and handouts to gain the co-operation of the trade unions to ensure that wages remain under control. In this form the policy is nothing more than an admission that the Labor Party remains the anti- business party which is prepared to establish controls over the freedom of action of the business sector while taking no such action in respect of the real and main cause of Australia's economic problems-the uncontrolled demands of the trade unions. In this form the policy guarantees that real incomes will continue to rise. It would not have had the support of the trade union movement, even to the limited extent it does, if it had not contained such a promise.

Having identified business as the enemy in the present economic climate, Labor would set up new Government machinery to ensure that business cannot respond to increased costs, including wage costs, without the permission of a Prices Justification Tribunal. However, the sell-out to the ACTU does not end there. Under Labor's prices and incomes policy, prices would be controlled in such a way that 'unnecessary cost increases are not reflected in higher prices'. Labor spokesmen claim that that will discourage payment of wages beyond that warranted by increases in prices and increased national productivity. In part I agree because the employers will be discouraged from paying increased over award payments because they will not be able to demonstrate to the Prices Justification Tribunal that the corresponding price increase in any way is warranted. But it does nothing, as indeed is the case of the entire incomes policy, to prevent unions making demands for such wage increases. If it had done so, what would have happened? The Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union Assistant Secretary, Laurie Carmichael, made it very clear when he stated:
If and when I do discuss the substance . . .
He was referring, of course, to the trade union-ALP agreement-
I shall be taking the position that real wages must rise and not merely be maintained through indexation.

Carmichael is not interested in the capacity of business to pay for these real increases in wages. He made it clear that his union, the AMWSU, was not interested either. So in order to give the false impression of even-handedness in its prices and incomes policy the Labor Party says that under a centralised wage fixing system 'there shall be no extra claims except where special or extraordinary circumstances exist'. Those special or extraordinary circumstances are not defined in Labor's policy statement in any way. Of course, they are not intended to be. They are an escape clause for the Labor Party when it finds that the unions do not feel bound to accept a Labor Government's decision on wages, just as in 1974-75 when the unions wrung out wage increases of 25 per cent, the largest annual increase in the history of Australia, under a Labor Government, of which the present Labor leader was the then Treasurer. They are an escape clause designed to give the Labor Party an excuse for caving-in to union demands when the sort of scepticism of prominent trade union leaders expressed about the prices and incomes policy is translated into action. Crucial to Labor's claims is the attitude of the unions, especially since from the wages side the policy has no teeth to enforce moderation. But the strong indication from the trade unions is that they have reservations about the policy. Laurie Short, the Secretary of the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia, stated:
It would be very difficult to get every union in Australia and every employer to agree in a period of either full employment or massive unemployment.

Although unemployment is presently very high, I think it would be untrue to say that it has become 'massive'. In this instance it seems, that the Federated Ironworkers Association believes such an agreement would not exist. Others have expressed similar reservations about a social contract where taxation relief and prices control are traded for wages restraint. I refer honourable senators to Ken Carr of the Federated Furnishing Trade Society of Australia. He made his union's position very clear when he stated:
We are completely opposed to social contracts and we will have to express that view at any A.L.P. or trade union forums.
The Secretary of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia, Pat Clancy, made his point even more clear when he stated:
. . . we don't believe it's possible to have an incomes policy that gives wage justice to the ordinary worker.

The FIA and the BWIU and the joint federal secretary of one of Australia's largest unions, the AMWSU, at the Federal Labor Party Conference last July, stated that they also do not believe that the prices and incomes policy will meet their plans for future wage demands. The reason is that none of these unions is committed to restraining wage demands to restore some of Australia's competitiveness in world markets. Last year wages rose by an average of 15.2 per cent. In Japan the comparable figure was 4 per cent, in West Germany it was the same and in the United States of America it was 6 per cent. While much of the rest of the world is climbing out of its inflationary path-inflation rates in Japan, West Germany and the United States are 3.1 per cent, 5.1 per cent and 5.9 per cent respectively-Australia's annual inflation rate, based on figures for the September quarter this year, was 12.3 per cent. It is no coincidence that wages growth and inflation are both considerably higher in Australia than in three of our major trading partners because excessive wage demands are now the mechanism through which the inflation rate is being fuelled.

Last year Australia's trade deficit was $9,097m. In 1979-80 Australia posted a small deficit. I believe this graphically demonstrates and illustrates the effect of inflation on our competitiveness. It is no secret that the effect of this loss of competitiveness is eventually felt through business failures and increased unemployment. They are inevitable consequences of inflation, especially when inflation is high in one country while its trading partners enjoy lower inflation rates and greater stability in wages and on the industrial relations front generally. The fact is that the trade unions do not seem to be interested in these facts. If they were interested they would have offered wage restraints, which have presently not been demonstrated. They might even be expected to join the Labor Party, which is after all the political wing of the trade union movement, in its social contract-in its prices and incomes policy. Jack Garland made the position of one of Australia's largest unions very clear when, in July of this year, at the ALP National Conference he stated:

If one modicum of this proposal . . . is to be seen only as total wage restraint without clear understanding of the working people of this country that it is based on the proper premise that there must be automatic quarterly adjustments to wages and . . . allocations, probably annually, of productivity increases where those increases occur, then in fact we will not reach first base .

The Hayden-Dolan statement of 20 August this year makes it clear that in its desire to reach first base all those demands and more will inevitably be met. In fact, the element of wage restraint has been almost completely removed from Labor's social contract by threats of union non-co-operation. What is left is control of prices only or, to put it in another way, a fundamental attack on the ability of employers to meet the increasing wages bill which the unions have as good as promised will be forthcoming.

There are two specific problems which ought to be considered in respect of this policy which the Labor Party has devised: Firstly, its relationship to the capacity-to-pay principle and, secondly, its effect upon inflation. The capacity -to-pay principle was well defined by the Vernon Committee of Economic Inquiry in 1965 when it wrote:

. . . the capacity to pay the proposed wage increase means that the expected performance of the economy will enable the proposed wage increase to be absorbed by the increased national output. In other words, the proposed increase will not of itself be expected to result in a change in the price level.

That would seem to be a very clear and proper enunciation of how wage increases should be structured. However, by advocating full cost of living adjustments, as reflected in the consumer price index, increases which go beyond the increased national output are promised. The CPI reflects increased State and Federal Government charges and cost increases for such items as petroleum products, which have no relationship whatever to national output. Employers will have to meet increased wage costs arising from factors which bear no relationship to the factors which the Vernon Committee defined as appropriate in considering a wage increase.

Under the Labor Party's prices and incomes policy such price rises will be built into the wage growth component. It is simply a formula for further erosion of profits, for a further erosion of the capacity of business to employ, to expand its output, to enter new markets and generally to develop in the present economic circumstances. A prices and incomes policy, as it has been proposed by the Labor Party, is also a recipe for built-in inflation. Changes in tax scales to shift substantially the taxation mixture, as well as reductions in indirect taxation, can only mean increased government borrowings to finance the extravagant promises which Labor has already made. Proposals that any future taxation increases should be put to the trade union movement for ratification will virtually ensure a narrowing revenue base for government, promoting further government borrowings and increased inflation. Most importantly, by building into future wage movements the full effect of the CPI, including the impact on the CPI of external and government influences, Labor is building into the Australian economy a certain and permanent inflation situation.

Labor's proposal has no real checks on wages-only on prices-and when the wages pressures become too great for industry to bear either the prices machinery will break down or, if it is too rigid, business failures will result. The Labor Party has implied, rather naively, that prices and not wages are the source of the present inflation. Otherwise it would have sought to control both prices and wages. Instead it has sought to strike a bargain with the unions along the lines of the social contract which operated in Britain between 1974 and 1979. The experience of a prices and incomes policy there is well summarised by the Labor Government's Chief Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Joel Barnett, who wrote:

. . . we went much further in the way we co-operated under the terms of the quaintly titled Social Contract, supposedly enshrining a new relationship between government and unions. To my mind the only give and take in the contract was that the government gave and the unions took.
Elsewhere Mr Barnett explained the effect of the social contract in Britain in disarmingly frank terms. He said:
It may have helped secure our election victory but it did nothing to prevent- some would argue it ensured-the 27 per cent growth in earnings (in 1974).

The British prices and incomes policy, which was described by a Labor Government Minister as disastrous, helped bring the British economy to its knees. The same sort of wage chaos would also result in Australia. Labor's prices and incomes policy is not a credible alternative economic strategy. It is an attempt to secure an election victory by promising a situation of unencumbered wages growth . It has been recognised as such in the community. The Australian newspaper, in an editorial, claimed that:
. . . the most reckless piece of political chicanery is the Australian Labor Party's supposed pact with the ACTU.
Put simply it means that many thousands of trade unionists who might otherwise have hoped and expected to keep their jobs will find themselves without them.
Max Walsh, in the weekly magazine Australian Business, summed it all up with a very neat turn of phrase. He stated:
The Australian Labor Party has its own special brand of snake oil-it's called a prices and incomes policy.

It is a snake oil designed to charm the electorate but the reality of the matter is that, like previous attempts to control wages and prices both here and overseas, the appeal will quickly wear off when the real costs of such a policy have to be met in terms of lost jobs and higher inflation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time I have available to me on this, the first reading of a money Bill, I want to refer to something that occurred in 1975. It is not what we debated earlier today but rather a report which was put down in that year entitled 'Open Tertiary Education in Australia'. It was the final report of the Committee on Open University to the Universities Commission. It is a pity that, given the problems of 1975, this report received so little attention at the time and was left to languish for the succeeding seven years. In the last few days I have raised again the notion that Australia, if it is to do anything in relation to tertiary education and making education available to all sectors of society-in other words, to the problem of liberalising university entrance and intake-must look again at open tertiary studies. I believe it is very useful in 1982-even more than it was in 1975-to consider this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: If one reads the 1975 report on open tertiary education in Australia one is indeed struck by how far, in the short time since, we have moved in communication technologies. For example, there is in the report an offhanded reference to video and a rather desultory discussion about microfiche, which is ruled out as being far too expensive. All the projections that the report made at that time were for way off in the future. However, in 1982 we find that not only have we gone way beyond those rather futuristic possibilities that were mentioned in 1975 but also now have available to us, in hundreds of thousands of homes around Australia, the very basis needed for university or tertiary education studies.

I will mention only two ideas which suggest that this is a possibility. Firstly , in all tertiary studies-certainly the Open University in Britain has borne this out-there has continued to be a great reliance on the printed word. Of course, a microfiche reader enables one to have within one's grasp a fairly voluminous library at very little cost, certainly very little postage cost. A microfiche reader is now available for about $US20. Also, in the last year the British have developed a positive microfiche, as distinct from the negative microfiche which normally people know about. The positive microfiche is read by a different and much cheaper technique.

The second matter I raise concerns the availability of video. One of the major problems with video in 1975 was the enormous cost and fairly poor quality of reproduction. However in Australia the Australian Broadcasting Commission network has a large number of hours-I think in most States some eight or ten a day-which are unused. I refer to the period generally from 11 or 12 o'clock at night to the time when the early morning shows begin. That down time could be employed for the broadcasting of a range of educational material. One could set the normal on-off switch of a video machine to record these programs for later play-back. In other words, we do not have to look-as the intent was in 1975-at the enormous cost of either putting up a whole new communications channel or running these types of programs in prime time, the opportunity cost of which would also be enormous.

I suggest those two examples show that in 1982 technical and technological communications facilities are such as to make available to Australia the opportunity that we have not had in the past. The availability of such courses would depend upon academic contribution. In Australia we already have in place adequate academic staff engaged in distance education. I refer, of course, to the existing units of external studies in a very large number of universities and colleges of advanced education. By employing academics in external studies and setting up a central technological body to bring the two items together, we would have a viable proposition.

What I mean by that is that the academics from the external studies units in universities and CAEs would provide the academic input. The centralised organisation, the technological input, would be provided by a group-presumably it would be based initially on existing facilities such as those able to be provided by the ABC but I hope it would very rapidly develop its own facilities- of producers, directors, script writers, graphic artists and other skilled communicators. These people would take the academic input and, in conjunction with the person who has developed that academic course, take it through from go to whoa. After they had dealt with that course they would have a package which was able to be communicated to the vast bulk of Australians. On overseas experience, the time that would take would be from nine months to 12 months per course. Therefore, it would probably be necessary in technical terms, in relation to staff appointments, superannuation and a number of other matters, to provide the open tertiary education institute or open university with a charter to enable those types of co-operative ventures to come about. It would seem far simpler to provide the institute with a charter, as a university, to enable it to offer degrees based on co-operation between a large number of institutions.

I believe we are now at a point in Australia where we ought to look at the notion of providing open access to education institutions. We have a fairly highly educated population. Not all people are able to undertake full or part time studies. Many people are not capable of undertaking conventional external studies. The conventional external study program tends to be based very much on the ability to succeed at normal education institutions. If one looks at the success and failure rate between full time students who undertake full time study and those who undertake external studies the logical conclusion which one would draw from the statistics is that those groups of people are probably homogeneous in their makeup.

I am looking at a range of other people in the community who ought to be allowed to attempt higher education studies. The sole criterion should be that they reach the standard required by the institution when they sit for their examinations at the end of the first year. This type of opening-up would provide to those people who are seeking a degree-based course an opportunity which is unavailable at the moment. It would provide those who are not seeking a degree with a general education in a variety of areas which would, I believe, be suitable and beneficial. I notice that the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) is in the chamber. Perhaps at some stage he will be interested in opening up again this debate on the notion of open university in Australia.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts I present the 201st report of the Committee in substitution of the report presented on 28 November 1982, and the 202nd report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the 202nd report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As the report on the selection and development of senior managers in the Australian Public Service was tabled some time ago in the House of Representatives and has received widespread comment-I am pleased to say favourable comment-in the Press, on this occasion I do not wish to read the whole of the statement which accompanies the report. For that reason I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The 202nd report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is unusual as it has broken new ground by addressing problems of Public Service personnel policy. In its 1980-81 annual report, the Committee advised the Parliament of the need for an inquiry into the selection and development of senior public servants. The Committee has feared for some time what has become manifest since, that in some areas the management of the Public Service is not meeting the demands of government. I must emphasise that the Committee does not denigrate the valuable contribution of many dedicated loyal and efficient officers at all levels in the Service but believe that reforms are necessary to ensure that senior officers are able to give of their best in the service of Australia.

The Commonwealth Public Service is the nation's largest employer. Through it, the Commonwealth Government manages an extraordinarily complex organisation engaged in a wide range of activities as diverse as defence and foreign affairs, construction, consumer protection, health, education and social welfare. Such diversity provides flexibility in applying systems of management and personnel policy which the Committee believes are often neglected. The Australian political system is based on the principle of responsible government, in which Ministers are accountable to Parliament, and ultimately to the people for the conduct of public administration. The Commonwealth Constitution vests all legislative power in the Parliament, and the executive power in the Ministry, assisted by Departments. Yet it is a fact of contemporary political life that the government now includes the public service, with which the Ministry shares executive power. Under the Australian democratic system, power must not be severed from responsibility. By responsible government, we mean not only that the Ministry is responsible to Parliament, but also that the public service, through senior administrators, are answerable not only to Ministers but also to Parliament for their management of the resources provided by Government through the Parliament.

One must acknowledge that the Ministry and Parliament are legitimately empowered to determine the political parameters within which public policy is to be administered. However, within those parameters, senior public servants exercise a host of management functions relating to the delivery of programs that provide services to the public. A major factor in the degree to which the Commonwealth government can successfully respond is the performance and motivation of senior public servants. The Committee believes that if Parliament is to make them accountable for this management, then Parliament itself has a duty to outline the type of management it considers appropriate. At Federation, the task facing the public service was relatively simple. In addition to the Treasury, only 5 Commonwealth departmental responsibilities are mentioned in the Constitution. As a result of a substantial increase in the number of Departments , the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government to administer policies of great complexity has grown. Although Ministers remain responsible to Parliament for their departments, recent events have highlighted how difficult it is for an individual Minister to personally direct all activities relating to policy in the department. Thus there is a need for Parliament to redefine the relative responsibilities for accountability by Ministers and public servants. Under these changed circumstances, the Public Accounts Committee believes that improvements have to be made if the political system is to be kept within the spirit of responsible government.

The focus of this report is upon selection and development of senior managers and their Department Heads; a written appraisal system; external recruitment; on -the-job development; mobility; special development programs and courses; and the role of the Public Service Board in this field. However, it should not be thought that it is only public servants that require more careful selection and more thorough training. The Committee notes that Ministers also require managerial skills. Consequently Ministers, and potential Ministers, should have much greater opportunities for training in management and policy skills. While this may be difficult to achieve, the ideal should be attempted. The essence of good management is taking responsibility for an organisation, even though the details of directing its activities are delegated to others. This Inquiry convinced us that current senior staff selection and development practices need to be changed if the Public Service is to meet the challenges of the 1980's and beyond.

The Committee has recommended that the First and Second Divisions be replaced by a Senior Executive Group, within which promotion would be to a personal grade or level, rather than to specific positions, leaving department heads to allocate-and reallocate-specific tasks. These promotions would be made on the basis of general management, policy and administrative skills, rather than the requirement of a specific job. Departments would have much greater flexibility to design their top structures to accommodate the strengths and weaknesses of particular senior executives (thus a department would have freedom to promote an individual to a higher level without necessarily adding to the breadth of his or her responsibilities, and also to reduce the role of an officer with limited abilities).

Consequently the Committee believes that the concept of permanency should be redefined so that: senior career officers have permanency within the public service but no claim to a specific rank or position indefinitely; and the holding of senior rank within the senior executive group depend upon consistent and satisfactory performance of duties, together with the needs of the department and the service. This means that an officer could be required to accept a demotion should the appraisal report(s) indicate an inability to maintain the acceptable level of efficiency and effectiveness at that level. Under some circumstances, officers may wish to take a demotion in order to have less responsibility, a choice not currently available to them. The Committee expects that the PSB would be the appropriate body to develop guidelines for the implementation of these recommendations. We would assume they would include adequate provisions for appeals and preservation of accrued superannuation at the higher level.

I wish to express the appreciation of the Committee to the Members of the Sectional Committee, Mr D. M. Connolly, M.P., Mr M. J. Duffy, M.P., Mrs R. J. Kelly, M.P. and Mr G. E. J. Tambling, M.P., who compiled this report. The Committee also wishes to thank Dr A. P. Gallagher, who made a significant contribution to the report as secretary sectional committee while on secondment from the Department of Education; those from both the public and private sector who appeared as witnesses and many others who gave advice and assistance. We believe this to be one of the most significant reports presented by the Committee in recent years and urge the Government to give its recommendations early attention. I commend the report to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to read the last section of the statement in acknowledgement of the members of the Committee who prepared the report. That section states:

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to express the appreciation of the Committee to the members of the Sectional Committee, Mr D. M. Connolly, M.P., Mr M. J. Duffy, M.P., Mrs R. J. Kelly, M.P. and Mr G. E. J. Tambling, M.P., who compiled this report. The Committee also wishes to thank Dr A. P. Gallagher, who made a significant contribution to the report as secretary sectional committee while on secondment from the Department of Education; those from both the public and private sector who appeared as witnesses and many others who gave advice and assistance. We believe this to be one of the most significant reports presented by the Committee in recent years and urge the Government to give its recommendations early attention. I commend the report to honourable senators.
I move:
That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTER-PARLIAMENTARY UNION CONFERENCES: MANILA AND HAVANA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the official report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the spring meetings in Manila and the sixty-eighth Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference in Havana in 1981. I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a member of the delegation that went to Havana in September last year. As a result of the meeting I would like to make a few comments on the importance, as I see it, of the IPU to Australia at the moment. Nine countries set up the IPU in 1889. Australia joined the IPU in 1956; there were then 39 members. Last year in Havana there were 99 member countries. As honourable senators can see from the holding of the conference in a place such as Cuba the guidelines, which state that all that a country has to have to become a member is a parliament according to its constitution, mean that any country which has any sort of parliament at all can join the IPU. It can be any sort of parliament as long as it is elected by the people. The parliament does not have to have a multi-party system. It does not have to sit for more than a day or two a year, as happens in Cuba. Many of the member countries do not have a vestige of an idea of what a democracy is all about.
—It sounds a bit like Queensland.

—I am sorry I bothered to pick up the honourable senator's interjection. If the honourable senator had been in Cuba he could not possibly have made that interjection. It is an incredible situation that at the moment the democracies which go to this sort of international conference are completely outvoted on every motion. We are able to win very few motions that are put. I believe it is imperative that we understand the objectives of the IPU. The stated objectives of the IPU are:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . contributing to international understanding and peace, the strengthening of parliamentary institutions, and support for the objectives of the United Nations.
