I am quite sure that everyone from the democracies which attended the IPU in Havana-including the Australian delegates-would query whether those objectives were undertaken in any way at all. I want to give some indication of the sort of thing that happens at these conferences. We could not get the simplest motion through that Inter-Parliamentary Union which, as I have said, exists to contribute to international understanding and peace. An item was raised which read:
Violations by Israel of the resolutions of the United Nations and the Inter- Parliamentary Union through its behaviour in the occupied Arab territories and its attacks against Lebanon . . .
I sought an amendment to that item. My amendment read:

Security Council resolutions 242 of November 1967 and 338 of October 1973, calling on all parties to enter immediately into negotiations aimed at establishing a just and durable peace in the Middle East;

All I was asking was that that conference show its concern for the problems in the Middle East by asking all parties to get together, negotiate on and aim at a durable peace in the Middle East. It seemed to me that that was a fairly moderate amendment to ask the IPU to accept remembering that its main objective is to foster international understanding and peace. But no, my amendment was not accepted. In fact, it was defeated. It was rejected by 28 votes to 26 votes with 2 abstentions. It seems to me incredible that such a very moderate amendment asking all parties to get together was defeated. I finally did get an amendment passed by leaving out the Security Council. The Security Council happened to be regarded by most of the member nations present as a bit taboo. The paragraph I proposed to insert reads:
Calls upon all parties concerned to enter immediately into negotiations aimed at establishing a just, comprehensive and lasting peace in the Middle East;

It was a rather similar amendment. Again that amendment was knocked back. It was suggested that if I added the words 'including the PLO' the amendment would go through. The amendment called upon all parties, so there was really no need for the words 'including the PLO' to be added. But as it was a means of getting the amendment passed I agreed to have the words 'including the PLO' added.

I believe another issue throws some light on this subject. It was referred to on page 97 of our report. We point out that there was strain and confrontation within the Inter-Parliamentary Union during the Havana meeting. Dr Castro addressed the delegation. It is customary for the leader of the host country to welcome the 1,000 delegates who go along to these Inter-Parliamentary Union Conferences. Dr Castro spoke to us for two hours. We were a captive audience. He abused the United States; he abused the British; he abused all the Western democracies. In what was hardly a host-like way, he created tremendous strain and confrontation, as is mentioned in our report.

Again, we had a situation involving the chairman of the plenary session. Canada moved an amendment to a motion put by Nigeria about concern for human rights in El Salvador. Canada then added the amendment 'and in Afghanistan'. The amendment was accepted and there was quite a deal of debate on it. The motion was then to be put to the vote. The chairman of the plenary session, a Cuban, decided he did not like the amendment and said that he would not ask the nations to vote on it. Instead he insisted upon the original motion being put first, and only if that original motion were defeated would the amendment be put. As one can well imagine, delegates from the democracies took points of order. Australia took points of order on numerous occasions on whether or not amendments which had already been accepted ought to be put first, before the original motion. This took a couple of hours. In the end, after we had pointed out so many times that it was against all meeting procedures, the Cuban chairman just ended up saying: 'Well, that might be the way you do it in your country. I'm chairman. It's not going to be done here and I'll take the vote on the original motion'. The vote was taken. On that occasion I refused to vote on the motion relating to El Salvador.

I do not intend to say any more about the conference in Havana. I have pointed out that many of the democracies had severe reservations about the way the meetings were conducted in Havana. Many have voiced those reservations. I have serious reservations about the value of Australia's participation in the IPU. I admit the conference has some things going for it. We do meet people from other countries; we do talk and create friendships. But I have great reservations about the value of the sessions to Australia. I would like there to be further discussions and further debate from other members who have attended these sessions. I think it would be valuable for this Parliament to make some decision as to whether we continue to send delegates to IPU conferences.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report of Member of Australian Delegation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to present a statement and to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a statement prepared by me, as the Senate's representative, on the Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference held in Rome in September 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
REPORT BY SENATOR ALAN MISSEN, SENATE DELEGATE TO THE AUSTRALIAN DELEGATION TO THE INTER-PARLIAMENTARY UNION CONFERENCE AT ROME-SEPTEMBER 1982
As the only Senator included in the delegation from the Australian Parliament, which attended the IPU Annual General Meeting at Rome, Italy in September 1982, I now make this report to the Senate.

I understand that the 1982 official report by the Australian delegation has not yet been prepared and indeed will not be tabled in the Parliament until 1983, indeed the 1981 Delegation Report has not yet been tabled or debated in the Parliament.

I have consulted other members of the 1982 Delegation as to the contents of this Report and believe that my observations are supported by a number of the House of Representatives delegates. However I accept full responsibility for the conclusions and, as I believe they call for urgent action by the Australian Parliament, I now table this Report and seek to have early debate on its contents.

This Report contains observations of and conclusions formed from attendance both at the IPU Seminars at Lagos, Nigeria (April 1982) and the IPU Annual General Meeting at Rome, Italy (September 1982). The critical conclusions relate primarily to the method of operation of the IPU, indeed to its very existence, but do not reflect on the excellent efforts of the host nations and their IPU Sections in the provision of conference arrangements and other social events. These will no doubt be fully recognized in the full report of the Australian delegation to the Parliament.
Function of the IPU

Experience of the two 1982 conferences leads to the inescapable conclusion that the IPU fails in its primary purpose of promoting and enhancing democratic parliamentary systems. The expansion in membership, which the IPU applauds, has now led to some 98 nations joining the IPU, yet the number of genuinely democratic parliaments in the world does not exceed 30. Consequently, the delegations from pro-Soviet and other authoritarian regimes have a numerical dominance and turn the debates and decisions of the conference into a 'mini- United Nations' gathering where mouth-pieces of totalitarian governments can carry outrageously one-sided resolutions (e.g. Lebanon and Israel; anti- colonialism and Falkland Islands). In the course of debate and in voting on these resolutions, the western European delegations, in particular, adopt a spineless attitude and often abstain from voting on the more offensive resolutions.

The continued participation of the western and other democracies in this farce only gives respectability to dictatorships employing the forms (but not the substance) of parliament and they make every use of it for propaganda purposes.

In fact little or no attention is paid in discussions to the main problems of parliament in maintaining its real influence over governments, with the possible exception of the meetings of Parliamentary officials which takes place simultaneously with the main conference. I understand these meetings of officials concentrate mainly on the more abstruse aspects of parliamentary procedure, but rarely consider the real problems e.g. the relevance and effectiveness of Parliament, its central position in government, and the resistance to Executive dominance over Parliament.

I recommend to the Australian Parliament that we immediately enter into negotiations with the U.S.A., Great Britain, European and other democratic States to secede from the IPU and form a new Union of genuinely democratic parliamentary States, which will concentrate on the promotion of the parliamentary system and the adaptation of Parliament to the needs of modern government.
I urge this action on the Australian Parliament for the foregoing and also the following reasons:
Method of Procedure of IPU

The IPU has, for some time, been considering the ''Erickson'' plan, a very mild suggestion of reform of the procedures of the conferences. However, even this proposal has met with opposition and it will not, in any event, overcome the real weaknesses of the IPU. It will indeed reduce the items for discussion at the two yearly conferences but the present tedious form of debate in plenary sessions would be retained.

The particular feature of the conferences is the long series of prepared speeches, largely of a propaganda or national promotional type delivered over long hours of the conference. In contrast to the previous Conference in Cuba, ( where I understand the Chairmanship was outrageously partisan) the general conduct of the Lagos and Rome conferences was fair. Yet the tedious procedures ensure that there is little or no debate in the real sense of the word (except in the smaller drafting committees at Lagos). When the resolutions are presented to the plenary sessions, one speaker is allowed for and one against any amendment although ''points of order'' enable some other interventions. The tedious roll-call voting takes up hours of the conference time.

The debating sessions are consequently unconstructive, without real exchange of views and most voting is shaped by prior meetings of factions (such as the so- called ''Committee of 10''-actually 22-western nations, meetings of the Soviet bloc, and the Arab group).

The inconsequence of debate was illustrated by the ''welcome'' of Yasser Arafat to intervene in the debate and speak to the conference. He is a figure who, as I pointed out to the conference, was totally irrelevant to democratic parliamentary institutions.
Nature of Resolutions

The passage of resolutions at the IPU conferences has little consequence and leads to no observable follow-up (apart from reports to national parliaments). On the whole, they deserve little respect as they fall into two categories:

(a) Resolutions of a ''motherhood' nature, full of cliches, platitudes and empty rhetoric, with often the irrelevant inclusion of buzz words like ''peace'' , ''disarmament'', ''colonialism'' or ''zionism''.

Study of the Rome conference resolutions on environment and on world hunger will show that they make up, in their tedious length, for an almost total absence of content or the facing up to real problems.
(b) Resolutions where vituperation prevails and the Soviet and its allies have successfully exploited anti-American, or anti-Israeli sentiments in the conference.

Resolutions at the Rome conference on anti-colonialism and a special resolution on the Lebanon-Israel situation are classic examples of this, being absolutely one-sided condemnations that would be a disgrace to any deliberative assembly.

Interestingly enough, the U.S.A. delegates were absent, apparently at a party, when an anti-British condemnation on the Falkland Islands was carried by a majority of 4 votes (and the 22 U.S.A. votes accordingly could not be counted). Again, on the last day when final resolutions were adopted, the U.S.A. delegation had already flown home, giving no encouragement to those opposing these resolutions. If the U.S.A. is to continue membership in this charade, its delegates should at least be there for the voting. I am relieved to report that a majority of the Australian delegation voted against most of the offensive resolutions (while the rest abstained).

With regard to resolutions described in (a) (motherhood resolutions) the avid desire of western delegations to seek compromises is ever present. It leads to the results that no-one is really offended by the ultimate resolution, but one wonders whether the effort is really worthwhile.
Conference Controversies

During the week of the conference in Rome there were constant negotiations and intrigues over the appointment of a new IPU President (as if it really mattered) . The western-supported Belgian candidate failed to 'get up' and ultimately the Soviet-supported Finnish candidate won the post (and Finland was awarded the next conference site). Westerners feared, possibly with good reason, that the Finnish President would be too much under Soviet influence, but the officials of the IPU are too inured to compromise to make this any real change in the situation.

The other great controversy was over the site of the next annual meeting in September/October 1983. South Korea made the only offer and one might have expected little opposition, but the North Koreans, and the rest of the Soviet bloc, went to inordinate lengths to stop a decision being made. Ultimately they were voted down and South Korea's offer was accepted.

One might observe, particularly from Lagos, that the great cost and trouble of accommodating and entertaining between 1000 and 2000 delegates and their spouses is an excessive demand on the economies of some host nations. The time, effort and expenditure is worthy of a better result.
Resolutions on Parliamentary Institutions

The Juridical, Parliamentary and Human Rights Committee (Australian representatives: Senator Missen and Mr Klugman) produced a resolution that did not fit the two classes earlier described. In Lagos, we were able (despite Soviet and Bulgarian objections and threats) to secure the adoption of a general resolution that did uphold the balance of power between Parliament and Government, called for scrutiny of government actions (particularly in foreign affairs) and upheld democratic elections, free media, rights of opposition parliamentarians and decentralized control. Despite further Soviet attempts at Rome to 'degut' the proposals, the resolution remains undamaged and constituted one of the Soviet failures at the conference. One problem was that the original 'topic' for discussion was so confused that it led to controversy and part of the topic was ruled irrelevant by the Chairman.
Australian Representation

Senator Ryan and Mr Mick Young, M.P. (A.L.P. representatives at Lagos) decided, probably for good reason, that their positions as A.L.P. spokesmen required their presence at Canberra, and they withdrew from the Rome delegation. As the A .L.P. did not then include a Senator, the consequential attendance at Rome consisted of 8 Members of the House of Representatives and one Senator (and no women). I have found it impossible, to date, to find out how this allocation is made. The delegation was, as a consequence, somewhat unbalanced but all Australian delegates played an active and useful part in the deliberations, within the limits of the conference procedures.
Conclusion

I am aware of the traditional justification, adopted by most delegations ( including many Australians) that the IPU serves some purpose in bringing together diverse nations, promoting friendships and exchange of ideas. It does so, to some extent, although it also leads to an 'old boys' attitude, with many delegates coming to conferences for their own benefit, year after year, (some up to 20 years in a row. In contrast, the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, though limited in its membership, does concentrate on parliamentary needs and reforms and is educative for inexperienced parliamentarians.

To the extent that such exchanges are useful, they would prevail in a genuinely democratic parliamentary body to which other nations could aspire to join. At present, the mere existence in a country of a formal representative body (even if it is a one-party state lacking free debate or opposition) is enough to admit that country to IPU membership.
But the cost of our continued promotion of this mock parliamentary body and the propaganda it provides for 'parliaments' that are a mere parody of democracy is too great a price to pay.
ALAN MISSEN 3 November, 1982 Senator for Victoria

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I would like to make some brief comments on the statement. It is not what one might regard as the usual statement from someone who has just come back from a conference. I have listened with interest to what has been said already today by Senator Walters in regard to the previous conference, which had the further disastrous disadvantage of being in Cuba. Ours was in Rome and one could say it was run with reasonable precaution so far as the rights of delegates were concerned. But it still showed up, as I trust my statement will indicate, the futility and uselessness of this body to which we have been sending delegates for some years.

I have made this statement knowing full well that the report on the 1982 conference probably will not emerge in this Parliament for another year. We have just seen that the 1981 conference document was put down in the House of Representatives yesterday and here in the Senate today, well over a year after the conference took place. That is an indication of the significance and urgency of those conferences. It is clear that no start has been made on the official report of the 1982 conference. I came back to this country determined that we should set on the way, in the manner I have recommended in my statement, the idea that Australia and the Western powers ought to secede from this organisation and set up a genuine democratic inter-parliamentary union which is concerned with parliaments and is not concerned to masquerade as a mini-United Nations or to spend its time with such irrelevancies as inviting out of the blue Yasser Arafat and others to come to address the conference. I want an organisation concerned with parliamentary purposes. The fact is that the IPU is an organisation with nearly 100 members from alleged parliaments. In most cases they are not parliaments; they are just playthings of the government. The representatives who come to the conference, like the Iranian delegates and others, are merely spokesmen for governments which bear no resemblance to those which observe parliamentary practice as we know it.

It was interesting to read in the report presented by Senator Walters the remarks which Mr Barry Cohen M.P. made at the conference last year. He said that Havana would be his last IPU conference, and he wanted delegates to know why he would never participate in such a farce again. I say the same thing. I assure honourable senators I shall never attend any such conference again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because you will not be selected; that is why.
—I do not know about that, Senator. One would be amazed at the people who continue to attend these conferences for 20 years. It really is an old boys' gathering.
—In the United Kingdom it is.

—It is not just the United Kingdom; it is the United States and other countries as well. Delegates go back time and again. Mr Cohen, in his remarks about the conference, said that if the IPU continued as it had in the immediate past it was possible that the genuine democracies would walk out of the organisation and form their own association. He, for one, supported such a move. I must say I entirely agree with him. I trust I have added further fuel to the desire which he expressed. The only genuine justification for this body is the interchange between members of parliament from around the world. Of course, that has some merit. Friendships are made and people do exchange some information. If we had a genuine inter-parliamentary union which was concerned with the problems of democratic parliaments and with the problems which parliaments have in keeping some control over the executives in the various democratic countries, and which was working on the updating of parliamentary procedure, we would still have the interchange with people but not the humbug and hypocrisy which absolutely dominate these conferences. At present the Western powers and delegates compromise all the way. Unfortunately that happened to some of our delegates. They compromised on the most outrageous resolutions which should have been opposed. Because they would have displeased this one or that one, they chose to abstain. Not only did they do that in the course of proceedings but also they were often absent when they should have been there to vote.

SPEECH.PARA: In this statement, honourable senators will find my reference to the United States. The United States is clearly a world leader, but is that an excuse for 22 delegates from the United States to be a party when a resolution that censured Great Britain's action in the Falklands was carried by four votes? They were not present that night. When the final disagreeable resolutions were being put through on the last day, the United States delegates had gone home a day early on Air Force 1, or whatever they call their government plane. If one is to be part of an organisation one has to be there for the votes and to take the unpleasant consequences of them. It seems to me quite clear that we have to face up to this issue. I am not suggesting in this document-I will not say any more than this-that just a walk-out by us will achieve anything. I am saying that it is time that the Western powers said to other countries that are genuine democracies: 'Can we set up an organisation which has some genuine usefulness and start afresh?' That is why I have taken the opportunity to make this statement. I hope that it will encourage debate when this report and that of Senator Walters come on for debate early next session. Both reports have a great deal of common experience across these two areas. I believe that we ought to have a full debate in this Parliament about whether we will send delegates.

It is true that the Senate sent only one delegate to this conference and that no woman represented the Australian Parliament. I was the only delegate from the Senate. I am not criticising Senator Ryan, who chose not to go to this conference. She had been to the one in Lagos, but she felt that her more important duties were concerned with her party activities instead of going to Rome. I really think she was probably absolutely right. The result was that there were at the conference one senator and eight members of the House of Representatives, which I would have thought would have been a matter of some interest to honourable senators on both sides of the chamber. That is only a minor point. The major point is that it is impossible to do anything with this body. It sets itself up as a mini-United Nations. It carries the most beastly and unreasonable resolutions and it spends very little time in genuine debate. For these reasons, I have moved to take note of the statement that I have made. I hope that we will be able to engender a full debate on this in the near future .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise extremely briefly to note with concern the report by Senator Alan Missen in relation to his participation in the Inter- Parliamentary Union conference in Rome in September of this year. It is a matter that honourable senators will need to take extremely seriously when a senator of Senator Missen's calibre and his general and well-known concern for the parliamentary institution comes to the conclusion that within that union of parliamentarians no scope can be found for expression of genuinely independent views such as would be expected if indeed they were acting as parliamentarians elected as part of a genuinely democratic process. Rather, it is the case, as I certainly experienced in Cuba in September of last year, that so many of the delegates merely express the viewpoint of the executive government to which they owe allegiance and indeed vote as a bloc.

SPEECH.PARA: It was the experience of the Australian delegation of which I was a member in Cuba that so overwhelmingly well organised were the blocs aligned with the Soviet Union, aided and abetted by nations calling themselves non-aligned but in fact mere puppets in relation to Soviet foreign policy, that we were left stranded. I think that is the point at which I would perhaps differ a little from Senator Alan Missen's conclusion. I feel that we may be nearing a stage where parliamentarians from genuine democracies may feel that, for a proper exchange of views on the matters of concern not only in relation to the relationships with the executive in their respective countries but also in relation to matters of foreign policy and other issues of major concern to the world's future, a separate forum is required-a forum of which it would be a privilege to be counted a member. Indeed, it would be a privilege much sought.

This is the case, for example, with the Socialist International to which the Australian Labor Party is affiliated at an international level. The fact is that many organisations claiming to be socialist parties attempt to affiliate themselves with the Socialist International, seeing it as a privilege and as a mark of recognition, but are denied such affiliation because they are not truly operating as genuine parliamentary parties in a political process which we would describe as democratic. There have been quite a few instances-I will not name the countries concerned-of governments setting up puppet opposition parties to get that opposition party into the Socialist International and to give an appearance of democratic activity in the country concerned. Even in the experience of Senator Missen in Rome, there was an instance, which he records in his report, of he and Dr Klugman of the Australian Labor Party during discussions of the Juridical, Parliamentary and Human Rights Committee securing a resolution-I take it that it was affirmed in plenary session-concerning the proper balance of power between parliament and government, calling for scrutiny of government actions, particularly in foreign affairs, and upholding democratic elections, free media, the rights of opposition parliamentarians and so on. In other words, with proper organisation, foresight and a lot of extremely hard work it is possible to achieve some results.

My experience in Cuba led me to believe then that it was the failure of parliamentarians from the Western democracies and the failure of my own Socialist International to organise before the IPU conference which allowed the Soviet bloc in particular to so overwhelm the voting on the resolutions of the Conference. What needs to occur is what occurs in relation to the Soviet bloc, namely, those of us who belong to the genuine democracies, to the genuinely non- aligned countries, and to such supranational organisations as the Socialist International should get together to look at the resolutions that are to come before plenary session and try to regain some of the original purpose and ethos of the Inter-Parliamentary Union. If that proves impossible, we may need to take the step-I do not think it is very far off-of leaving the IPU and forming a genuinely democratic parliamentary body to which other nations, as I say, would aspire to join.

Finally, I place on the record my disgust also with the United States delegation, because both in Cuba and apparently in Rome that delegation, which purports to represent the Congress of the most powerful nation in the so-called free world, has failed to provide even the numbers to enable votes to be affirmed which would reflect our beliefs in the nature of parliamentary democracy. The fact is that not only have numbers not been provided as they ought by the United States delegation-that would be bad enough-but also there has been a dearth of reasonable, reasoned argument from the delegation on the occasions when they have been present at plenary session. I think it is a failure of the United States Congressional delegation to give not the leadership , but the strength which ought to come from that democratic institution, which has played a large part in the demise of the IPU. I am saying that unless in the next year or two the United States of America, the genuine parliamentary democracies, the genuinely non-aligned countries and supra-national organisations such as the Socialist International get together before the plenary session of the Inter-Parliamentary Union and, without requiring bloc votes and unthinkingly falling into line, nevertheless provide a genuine coherent and cohesive voice for the aspirations of the democratic parliamentary bodies around the world, I think we ought to withdraw. I can only say that for two years now well-respected parliamentarians from the House of Representatives and now the Senate have alerted us to this problem, and we ought to take their warning very seriously and try to respond to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will be brief. Although I do not agree with Senator Missen's recommendation, I am attracted to it but some remarks need to be made about it. He recommends that the Australian Parliament immediately enter into negotiations with the United States of America, Great Britain, European and other democratic states, to secede from the Inter- Parliamentary Union and form a new union of genuinely democratic parliamentary states. If Senator Missen's recommendation is agreed to by this Parliament I would say that Australia will no longer be entitled to send a delegate to the IPU or whatever organisation is formed, because Australia cannot be classed as a truly democratic parliamentary state. The State Government of Western Australia is not elected under a democratic franchise, the Upper House in Victoria is not elected under a democratic franchise and the Queensland Parliament is certainly not elected under a democratic franchise. We have to set about bringing democracy to those three States. No doubt we will be doing something about it in Victoria but we might have to wait some months before we can set about it in Western Australia. We could wait until the end of this century before we can do something about it in Queensland. We are going to have to do something and I hope that Senator Missen will support any moves that are made in this chamber to bring about a sense of democracy in Australia so that if his recommendation comes into being we can take our place as representatives of a truly democratic country, something which Australia is not at present.

SPEECH.PARA: Words have been said about bloc votes. I was fortunate to be a delegate to the IPU conferences in Prague and in Caracas in 1979. I was astounded to hear what some of our Australian delegates had to say before they got there. They went there with preconceived ideas. They were opposed to some of the Eastern bloc countries before they ever met the delegates. They were not prepared to sit down and discuss the problems. They went there with preconceived ideas and they even enunciated them in this Parliament. I will not mention who they are. Senator Missen probably knows. One of them is now a Minister in the Government. I had the unfortunate experience of being with him and arguing with him every morning prior to the Conference sessions when the Australian delegation met to decide what its tactics would be. Every morning, immediately after breakfast, there was an argument on his attitude to the people of the other nations which were represented at that conference.

We cannot legitimately level criticism at other countries whem some of our own delegates go to the conferences with preconceived ideas and without being prepared to sit down and listen to the problems which affect other countries. I look forward to the full debate on this matter. I also look forward to Senator Missen making some move in his own party so that we can bring about a democratic system in Australia so that all of our parliaments are elected by a simple majority of the electors-whether the Government be the party I am a member of or the party Senator Missen is a member of. At least the people ought to be given the opportunity to be represented by a party in a democracy and have the Government elected democratically.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

He made the statement that the Parliament of Queensland is not elected by a democratic franchise. The franchise for elections in the State of Queensland is exactly the same as it is for Commonwealth elections.
—It is not.
—The franchise is the same.

DEBATE.TITLE: ANNUAL REPORTS OF DEPARTMENTS AND AUTHORITIES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-My statement on the annual report of the departments and authorities is a fairly lengthy statement running into 12 pages. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The first six reports of the Senate Committee on Finance and Government Operations on 'Statutory Authorities of the Commonwealth' were tabled on 20 February 1979, 15 November 1979, 19 February 1980, 22 May 1980 and 15 September 1982. The report of the Joint Committee on Publications entitled 'Annual Reports of Commonwealth Departments and Statutory Authorities' was tabled on 13 September 1979. The Government has reviewed and is now responding to the recommendations in these reports relating to annual reporting arrangements and to the Senate Committee's observations and comments on the annual reports of specific authorities mentioned in its third, fourth and sixth reports.
Wider issues relating to statutory authorities (raised particularly in the fifth Senate Committee report) are still under consideration.

The reports of both the Senate Committee and the joint Committee contain recommendations directed towards ensuring that annual reports are submitted to Parliament expeditiously and maintain a high standard of quality and integrity in the information they impart and hence fulfil their potential as accountability documents to the Government and Parliament.

In the case of statutory authorities, the Senate Committee recommends the enacting of an 'annual reports Act' while the report of the Joint Committee included recommendations that new legislation to establish an authority should include specific reporting provisions and that reporting provisions in existing legislation should be defined and improved whenever such legislation is being amended.

The Government agrees with the recommendations requiring the timely submission of annual reports and with the objective of achieving a high standard of quality and integrity in reporting. However, the Government is not convinced of the need to introduce new legislation solely to achieve this objective.
Legislation And Guidelines For Authorities

Instead, the government has decided that it will introduce, in the next Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, an amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act to require all major statutory authorities to submit timely annual reports. The amendments will ensure that:

All major authorities submit annual reports as soon as possible and not later than 6 months after the end of their financial year (unless a shorter period is provided in the legislation of an individual authority), and that Ministers table authorities' reports within 15 sitting days of receiving them;
any extension of this deadline must be accompanied by an explanation of the reasons tabled in Parliament.

The three month period proposed most recently by the Senate Committee for non- commercial authorities is too short a period to include in legislation-although the Government would expect it would normally be met.

The only two major statutory authorities which the Government proposes be exempted from these legislative requirements are the Australian Security Intelligence Organization and the Office of National Assessments: National security considerations require that the special reporting arrangements now applying to them remain.
The recommendations relating to form of financial statements are still under consideration, as mentioned earlier.

The Government has also examined the specific requirements for non-financial information that both the Senate Committee and the Joint Committee have recommended be included in statutory authority annual reports. The Government has drawn up a set of guidelines which, as well as supplementing the proposed legislative requirements, specify the non-financial information authorities are to provide in future annual reports and, as these matters directly concern the Parliament, I seek leave to incorporate the guidelines in Hansard.

The Government will draw to the attention of Commonwealth authorities the arrangements now available for the publication of annual reports at times when Parliament is not sitting and will encourage authorities to make use of this mechanism for their annual reports when those reports cannot be prepared in time for tabling when Parliament is sitting. Authorities will also be advised of procedures for making copies of such reports available to all members and senators.

The Senate Committee also recommended that if an authority were unable to meet the deadline for presentation of its annual report, an 'interim report' should be provided and tabled. The Government does not propose to require such reports as a general rule as it believes this could lead to confusion through having ' interim' and 'annual' reports tabled. Authorities would not be prohibited from tabling interim reports and, in some circumstances, would be encouraged to do so . However, if unable to meet the deadline for submission of an annual report, an authority will now be required by law to advise the Minister, who shall report to the Parliament, of the reasons for the delay.
Guidelines For Departments

Besides making recommendations on reporting arrangements for authorities, the Joint Committee on Publications put forward proposals for departmental annual reports. The Government had already approved a set of guidelines for such reports and a copy of these was provided to the joint Committee. I now seek leave to have a copy of the guidelines, with some additions and alterations in line with the Committee's proposals, also incorporated in Hansard.

The Government will also require departments to report as soon as practicable ( if possible, in time for Estimates committees' consideration), and certainly well within six months of the end of their reporting period.

The Joint Committee also made a number of recommendations concerning the physical production of annual reports and related aspects. The Government agrees , in principle, with these recommendations, which will be drawn to the attention of departments and authorities and will be kept in mind by the Australian Government Publishing Service.
The Senate Committee's Observations On The Annual Reports Of Specific Authorities

Turning to the Senate Committee's observations and recommendations on the annual reports of those authorities which the Committee found cause to mention in its third, fourth and sixth reports, particular attention was paid to some technical difficulties which led to delays in presentation.

These included difficulties related to the conversion from a cash accounting system to an accrual system, the procedures involved in approval of the form of financial statements and the audit of the accounts and financial statements, and the capacity of the Australian Government Publishing Service to provide for the design and to co-ordinate the production of annual reports.

To a large extent, the Senate Committee itself recognised that explanations for past delays had been given and appropriate action had been taken. The Government sees no need to rehearse further the histories of particular difficulties. However, I wish to draw attention to the statement made by the Minister for Primary Industry in the House of Representatives on the future preparation of annual financial statements of the Australian Wheat Board (Hansard 1980, page 1534). In any case, the guidelines I have mentioned are also aimed at the prompt provision of annual reports by Commonwealth bodies.

Honourable senators, the Government trusts that the new arrangements and proposed legislation will improve the overall performance of Commonwealth departments and authorities in their reporting to the Parliament.
GUIDELINES FOR THE CONTENT, PREPARATION AND PRESENTATION OF ANNUAL REPORTS BY STATUTORY AUTHORITIES
Introduction

These guidelines are intended to cover generally the annual reporting requirements for statutory authorities (incorporated or unincorporated authorities established by or pursuant to a law of the Commonwealth or of the A. C.T.) and are subject to refinement in the light of experience.
Reports of small unincorporated authorities and office holders within the public account may continue to be included in the related departmental reports where it is practical to do so.

The guidelines do not, of course, override statutory requirements imposed by the legislation on individual authorities, but to the extent that they require a higher standard than does the legislation, they should be followed by all such authorities.

All authorities are to provide annual reports as soon as possible after the end of their financial year, if possible in time for the estimates debate in the Budget Sittings. At the very latest, reports should be submitted within six months (unless a shorter period is provided in the legislation of an individual authority). An explanation will be submitted to Parliament if the deadline has to be extended in exceptional cases (the new deadline is to be mentioned in the explanation). Ministers will ensure that reports are tabled within fifteen sitting days of receipt.

Where there is a requirement for a form of financial statements to be approved by the Minister for Finance, authorities should commence negotiations with the Department of Finance early enough to allow issues to be resolved without delaying the annual report. Authorities also need to bear in mind the need for reasonable time to be allowed for completion of auditing of the financial statement within the six month deadline.
Report Contents

Reports should be the means of providing a wide dissemination of information on authorities, with special attention being given to making available material that might not otherwise be made public as a matter of course.
Application of these guidelines to those authorities engaged in commercial competition with the private sector is subject to the need to protect commercially sensitive material.
The following information is to be provided in future annual reports:
(i) Enabling legislation: A clear statement of the legislation (if any) under which the organisation operates.

(ii) Responsible Minister: To be shown. A description of any statutory powers of direction which the Minister has over the authority and details of the exercise of any such powers, subject to the need to protect confidential information, to be included.
(iii) Powers, Functions and Objects: To be detailed.

(iv) Membership and Staff: A list of the members of the body and their terms of appointment, together with listing of senior executive staff and a statement of the total number of staff employed by the organisation. In addition, the basis for staffing of the organisations should be identified. The address and phone number of the information officer should also be included.

(v) Financial Statements: All Government bodies should provide statements which adequately disclose financial aspects of their activities. For example, where the form of a body's financial statements is approved by the Minister for Finance, the approved form must, of course, be followed; where an unincorporated body has no specific financial responsibilities and no financial reporting requirement exists, it might be appropriate to disclose departmental receipts and expenditures relevant to its operations, while avoiding unnecessary duplication of the information contained in the annual Financial Statements prepared by the Minister for Finance. The requirement for adequate disclosure will extend to bodies incorporated under companies legislation if the Commonwealth is sole owner or shareholder; this will not affect the need to satisfy the reporting requirements under company law. The Department of Finance and the Auditor-General's Office are preparing guidelines which will assist Commonwealth undertakings in preparing financial statements; an exposure draft entitled 'Proposed Guidelines for the Form and Standard of Financial Statements of Commonwealth Undertakings' was issued in August 1980. The Exposure Draft has been considered by the relevant Parliamentary Committees.

(vi) Activities and Reports: A description of the principal programs and activities of the body noting objectives and reviewing achievements. Information on interaction with other authorities, departments and State and international bodies should be provided as should a list of publications during the reporting period.

(vii) Operational Problems: A description of the major problems which have arisen in the body's activities, including details of requisite Government action to overcome such problems e.g. the amendment of the enabling Act.

(viii) Subsidiaries: Details of subsidiary companies formed, or interest acquired in existing companies, are to be provided. It is a desirable practice to include the annual report of such subsidiaries as are controlled by the parent authority with the report of that authority, where this is feasible.
GUIDELINES FOR DEPARTMENTAL ANNUAL REPORTS
A. General Principles

(1) Reports should be the means of providing a wide dissemination of information on the activities of departments, with special attention being given to making available material that might not otherwise be made public as a matter of course. Undue repetition of material already widely publicly available should be avoided; reference to the source and availability of such material may be appropriate.
(2) The reports should provide an account of departments' more significant activities and any background information necessary to an understanding of these .
(3) Reports should be oriented towards administrative, managerial and operational aspects of departmental activities.

(4) Ministers will be responsible for tabling annual reports in the Parliament and otherwise publicising them. The detailed content of reports will be the responsibility of Permanent Heads who should consult as necessary with their Ministers.
(5) Where comments are made impinging on the operations of other departments and authorities, special care should be taken to see that all views are presented in a balanced way.
(6) Reports should be concise yet present all information necessary for an understanding of the matters covered. Some reports, especially those from policy oriented departments, may be quite short.

(7) As reports are to provide information on the operation of departments rather than to promote them, modest standards of production are desirable and appropriate. Relevant AGPS Guidelines should be closely observed.

(8) If practicable, reports should be prepared on a financial year basis and should be available if possible for the estimates debates, in the Budget Sittings. When there are difficulties getting reports finished in time for the estimates debates departments should provide an interim statement in A4 duplicated form for the information of the Parliament. Departments currently producing annual reports on a calendar year basis may continue to do so.
B. Contents
(1) Standard information such as:
a top structure organisation chart, including regional offices and associated bodies, with an indication of those that report separately to the parliament

a brief outline of the main functions of the department, highlighting any changes consistent with the Government's policy on access to information, an indication of further sources of information, including other publications, policy information and policy discussion papers and references to submissions to various advisory mechanisms, committees of inquiry, etc. with adequate bibliographic details and address and phone number of information officer

selected financial information associated with the administration of programs and the operation of the departments; this information should be consistent with financial information published in the Budget Papers, and the Financial Statements prepared by the Minister for Finance
statistics in annual comparative form, on main programs administered and departmental administration, including staffing
a list of senior officers (at divisional head level and above)
information relating to the Freedom of Information Act (covered by separate guidelines issued by the Attorney-General's Department)
reference to the activities of smaller statutory and non-statutory bodies responsible to the Minister where separate reports are not produced by these bodies.
(2) Optional information such as:
a description of programs, particularly those involving direct services to the public, including significant developments during the year and reference to the principal Acts administered
reviews of objectives, processes and achievements, including information on management improvement activities
personnel development activities
systems and legislative changes significantly affecting the department

the effects of administrative review mechanisms (Ombudsman, Administrative Appeals Tribunal, etc.) on the organisation, operation and workload of the department and any consequent changes in procedures and decision making processes.

Nevertheless, I would point out that during these current sittings the Government has been able to respond to reports from the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts and the Senate Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories and, of course, the response I have just made to the reports of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and the Joint Standing Committee on Publications. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a few matters in relation to the estimates for the Department of the Treasury. The first matter relates to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. During the hearings of Estimates Committee C I asked Treasury officials whether they could supply me with a comparison of the forecasts of the OECD and the eventual results. I was somewhat prompted to do so because a Minister, in a three-month burst, waved around an OECD report as living proof that the Australian economy was not only in a healthy position but also was going to get healthier.

SPEECH.PARA: I wondered at the time what the validity of the OECD forecasts would be and how accurate they were. I also wondered about the degree to which we should take notice of them. I will take just one or two indicators out of the answers supplied. The first one relates to economic growth. In 1979 the OECD overestimated the rate of economic growth in Australia by 1.75 per cent. In 1980 it overestimated the rate of economic growth by 0.95 per cent. According to the last available figures for 1981, it overestimated the rate of economic growth by 1.65 per cent.

I was a little suspicious about that. As the OECD had overestimated the rate of economic growth, I thought it might have been consistent and overestimated the rate of inflation. However, looking at the figures for 1979, I saw the OECD underestimated the rate of inflation by 1.75 per cent. It underestimated the rate of inflation by 1.6 per cent in 1980 and by 0.15 per cent in 1981. These comparisons do not necessarily mean that the OECD is in any way a poor predictor of economic trends.They do not mean that it does not do valuable work, that we should not be a member of this body. It costs us $140,000 per annum plus the cost of trips to be a member. In the last five years the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has never qualified or amended OECD draft reports. I am not saying today that we should pull out of the OECD. All I am saying is that Ministers should not come into this chamber and regard the OECD's predictions as absolutely accurate. They should not wave details of them at the Opposition and say that the points that Opposition is making about the economy are not correct because the OECD has said other things. Of course, in the last three or four months Senator Sir John Carrick has not been doing that in here because the disparity between the OECD predictions and the end result in Australia has been too great. So he has gone back to his normal pastime of berating the Whitlam Government when answering questions.

The second matter I wish to raise very briefly under the Treasury item concerns the Taxation Advisory Committee. I did not know then the purpose of this Committee and I still do not know what value it really serves. The Committee held nine meetings with the Treasurer to June 1982. I think it costs about $10, 000 to get this body together, and this is probably not an exorbitant amount, but I cannot quite understand the purpose it actually serves. I know that it has been established for the purpose of advising the Treasurer. However, I do not see a need for such a committee as we have a Taxation Office which costs probably upwards of several hundred million dollars to run and which provides advice. I asked the Commissioner of Taxation for his comments on the Taxation Advisory Committee. However, consistent with being a good public servant, he just blushed and said nothing. I take that to mean that the Taxation Office itself is not too wrapt about the Taxation Advisory Committee.

Another matter that one could raise in respect of the Treasury is a particular allocation of $1.5m. This matter was pursued at some length by Estimates Committee C. I am sure that my colleague Senator Gietzelt will expand on some of my remarks. A $1.5m allocation has been put aside for what is called, I think, publicising Government decisions. The actual border line between publicising Government decisions and Government propaganda is a fairly shaky one. It is very difficult to anticipate in advance whether the $1.5m was to be used in genuine propagation of Government policy or whether it was to be used for electoral purposes. The first question I asked and pursued during the examination of this matter by Estimates Committee C was how the $1.5m was arrived at. No explanation was given. We spent some time asking for an explanation but we still have not got one. However, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle did say on 13 September when I asked that question:
Because the figure is $1,500,000; that is why, the figure of $1,500,000 was decided upon.

When we asked what criterion was used by which it could be decided upon we were informed that, as we have never had this sort of allocation before, there were no guidelines. I still do not know from where the $1.5m came. We still do not know the reaction of Treasury officials. In particular we do not know what remarks were made to the Treasurer by Mr Stone when he suddenly had this $1.5m lobbed on him.

I do not have any objection to governments advertising Budget decisions. I do not have any real objection to their advertising new health schemes. But I do object to campaigns such as the $300,000 one launched just before the Victorian election that are blatantly political. That campaign was so political that when the State Secretary of the Labor Party in Victoria took the matter to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal the advertisements were banned in the blackout period because they were obviously political. We have to ask whether any of this money will be used during an election period and whether, from the moment writs are issued, any of this $1.5m will be spent on Government advertising. Of course , it is quite clear to me that the Government intends to advertise some of its programs that it believes are more appealing. We will not see the Government dipping into this $1.5m to advertise its less popular Budget measures. I believe that we have not been given sufficient explanation as to why this item has been set aside. One explanation which I think has some credence is that the Government's attitude has been actually to dip into funds in an ad hoc manner and spend them on Government propaganda-sorry, Government information-and this is just a way of formalising that procedure. However, we have to go to another section of the Estimates to understand the relevancy of the $1.5m, and that was the $10,000 spent on the post-Budget survey. I do not think that we would ever have seen the post-Budget survey, the questions or the answers, if we had not raised it in the Estimates Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether Tony Eggleton would have.

—In reference to that question, we asked in the Estimates Committee whether a copy of this particular Budget survey was sent to Mr Eggleton at any stage, and, as far as I know, we have yet to get an answer. I should like to be as sure of winning Tatts as I am that he was one of the first persons to get this survey. But the rationale behind this survey is that it was carried out because governments, having to commit so much money in government propaganda, really know where to slot it in. I would accept that as a fairly rational argument-that one holds a survey and finds out where the target areas are, and that is where one puts the thing. But I have read this survey. In my view, it is a taxpayers-paid, Liberal Party survey to gauge public reactions on what the impact of the Budget was, and nothing more. Reading through the various questions asked on how acceptable the Budget was, I would regard it as a valuable tool in planning an early election campaign. If we are to understand the $1 1/2m allocation in Treasury and that $10,000 being spent on the post- Budget survey, it was all in the context of an early election. It was allocated for that.

SPEECH.PARA: Some people might say that that is the government's right, that the Government has the right, if it wishes, to commission a survey and to put $1 1/2m of taxpayers' money away to spend on election campaigns. But where that does not read true is in this Government's fanatical opposition to public funding. Every time we have had a debate in this chamber on whether political campaigns should be funded, what happens? We are told from the Government side of the chamber that that is dipping into taxpayers' money and is virtually robbery from the taxpayer by political parties. But what we have in this country is a very one- sided dipping in-by governments. I have been made more aware of this issue by what is starting to emerge in the Victorian Government since Labor acceded to the Treasury benches there last April. We are just starting to find out the amount of public relations campaign funded by the Liberal Party, all aimed in the lead-up to an election time. We are just starting to dip into the Department of Economic Development to find out where the funds were and where they have been milked out to projects that do not meet any of the criteria of that Department. Whether or not the Department of Economic Development is a Liberal- dominated department, it is the Department that dished out the money. These two particular instances could fulfil the same sort of aim.

In relation to the post-Budget survey, as I have said, I do not think that we would ever have seen a copy if we had not pressed for it. The survey was done by Burke Marketing Research. It was a telephone survey, and it was done, I think, on 19 and 20 August. It was first mentioned, though, by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) on 3 February 1982 in a ministerial statement that it was thought that this would be a good idea. As I understand it , the survey went out to tender and the lowest tenderer won the job. One of the questions we asked was: Why was it not a written survey? Why was it a telephone survey? I think the answer was given that unless it was a telephone survey, people's views of the Budget would be distorted a couple of days after the Budget. Looking at the actual results of the survey, one finds that it really sought to get the general awareness and attitudes towards the Budget. Its findings were quite interesting. Its only specific conclusions, however, for the $10,000, was that the Budget was liked for family and personal provisions and disliked for lack of economic contribution. There were certain State variations. Tasmania and South Australia generally supported the Budget; Queensland was 50- 50; New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia had a generally negative reaction.

As well as these telephone surveys, however, we are having community issues surveys. I am far less clear about the cost of these surveys and what sorts of areas they are going into. If the Government is to be genuine and say that these surveys are done to help the Government, it will not mind publishing them the moment they become available. It will not mind sending copies of the surveys, not necessarily to every member of Parliament but at least to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) , so that we can see that government funds are not being misused.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only when we asked for it was a copy put in the Library.

—Senator McLaren mentions that in the Estimates Committee we asked for copies of these things. The reaction of the Minister was quite generous and he said that they would be made available. However, I believe that when the staff of Estimates Committee C went to the Department and tried to get hold of copies of them, they were unavailable. It made one copy available in the Library, so the members of Estimates Committee C had to go there to photocopy this thick document.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary on this matter-I know that Senator Gietzelt will probably expand on some of the points that I have made-I should like answers to the following questions: Will any of the $1 1/2m be spent during an election period, from the moment when the writs are issued? Secondly, will all other surveys undertaken by government departments and paid for out of the public purse be made available to all members of Parliament on request? I do not say that it should be a mandatory issue of all these surveys to members of Parliament, but they should receive copies when they request them. Thirdly, will the community issues surveys as well be made available? If those questions were answered and assurances were given, some of the problems relating to the matters I have raised could be solved. I just hope that we do not get into a Victorian situation, as we did earlier this year, where it is estimated that $2.1m, I think, was spent by government departments promoting themselves and in turn trying to promote the Liberal Party Government back into power in Victoria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was referring to the Estimates Committee consideration of the Government's departmental information activities. As I had indicated, considerable concern was being expressed in the Estimates Committee about the increased amount of funds that was being required and the way in which these funds were being allocated in a fashion that made it impossible for the Parliament to appreciate how much increase in publicity was being made available in the Budget for 1982-83. I do not think that it can ever be argued by any Government senator that the Whitlam Government, in the 1972- 1975 period-even though some honourable senators may disagree with the emphasis given in that period-was not a great reforming government, and that it had a large legislative program and set about changes and introducing much innovative legislation which was designed to redress a number of deficiencies in the community. One has only to refer to a few of them, such as the air improvement program; the Australian Assistance Plan; the supporting mothers legislation which gave social security benefits; the introduction of the Regional Employment Development Scheme; and a host of other legislative changes which were completely new in the way in which the Commonwealth Government was becoming involved for the first time.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet when that Government set about publicising these innovations and these new programs, the Opposition of that day, the present Government and particularly those who now constitute the Government front bench in this place, raised merry hell about the amount of taxpayers' money being expended in the explanation and amplification of these legislative changes. You, Mr Chairman, were in charge of the program at the time. It finally worked out to represent something less than $4m. Yet a hue and cry was raised throughout the land, led principally by the front bench that is now part of the Government in this place, that we were spending taxpayers' money willy-nilly in a haphazard and injudicious sort of way . We defended that because we believed that the taxpayers should know what new benefits were becoming available for citizens.

This Government can only be described as a standstill government and a government that is not being particularly innovative. That is pretty obvious. But we have nevertheless seen advanced by this Government over recent years the establishment of two new organisations-the Government Information Unit, and another rather strange organisation called the Information Co-ordination Branch, most of whose officers happen to be quite peculiarly members of the Liberal Party or, if not, very closely ideologically and philosophically supporters of the Liberal Government's attitude. What have we seen in the documents finally extracted from the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle)? We have seen an increase in the sums available. The document states:

At this stage of analysis of the returns, expenditure, excluding salaries and support costs on the kind of departmental information activities outlined . . . is estimated at about $40 million in 1982-83. Of this some $25 million will be spent on 'operational' information . . . with about $15 million spent on ' publicity' activities.

When we turn to the next page of the document we find an incredible contradiction because the major method of information delivery by the departments in terms of cost is paid advertising. It is estimated that in 1982- 83 about $20m will be spent on advertising. On one page of the document an amount of about $15m is mentioned and on another page an amount of about $20m. As my colleagues-for example, Senator Robert Ray-have already indicated, we were not able to obtain that sort of precise schedule stating how even the $1.5m was allocated, against Treasury wishes, in a party political way. Of course, reference has already been made to the fact that in the immediate post-Budget period the survey which the Government carried out was a clear use of taxpayers money to find out how the citizens were reacting to the Budget. As the survey showed, 27 per cent of the people thought that the Budget took away more than it gave. Of course, that is exactly the case.

More money was collected in tax than was given out in benefits. That is the situation. That sort of analysis was referred to by Ross Gittins who carried out a Sydney Morning Herald survey. That survey found:
. . . only 20 per cent of voters believed that the Budget left them better off, while 31 per cent believed themselves to be worse off.
Only 18 per cent of voters believed the Budget left the nation better off, while 41 per cent believed the nation to be worse off.
The results of the Government's own opinion poll were little better.

Clearly that survey was designed to give the Government some sort of indication of whether there should be an early election. Tuesday, 9 November was supposed to be the last day on which notice of an election could be given but there is still no clear writing off of an early election. We have had no information about this. We have had an election in South Australia. We have a by-election of 4 December. The Government is still proposing to proceed with spending that $1. 5m which Treasury officials have some sensitivity about-and quite rightly so. As my colleague said, at what point does government advertising of achievements and benefits become propaganda? I suggest that we ought to have a decision in this Senate to the effect that that $1.5m ought not to be spent until the Flinders by -election is over. Why should money of that magnitude be spent for the purpose of bringing about a desired result in respect of the Government's electoral difficulties? That is clearly its purpose in respect of the Flinders by-election . The Government and the Opposition parties have carried out surveys which show that the result in that seat will be a line ball one.

Why should the scales be tilted by spending $1.5m to promote what this Government believes are goodies? However, the surveys show that the Government goodies are not accepted by the Australian people. Clearly, if the Government can spend another $1.5m in the next few weeks it can achieve a result that it believes will be in its own interests.

I think if we are to have advertising campaigns-the Opposition does not quibble with that; it thinks that is fair enough-the Government ought to be open and frank and say that the campaign is not related to an election. If the Opposition feels that there is a component of electioneering in this matter we will postpone it to another date so that clearly the taxpayers money can be used for the purpose of providing and disseminating information on government activities in a way that will not be of political benefit to the Government. Surely that is not an unreasonable thing to put to the Senate. It is not an unreasonable approach to put to the government of the day. I believe that if the Government was fair dinkum and prepared to concede that, there would be very little criticism from the Opposition.

We have seen in the life of the Government over the last three or four Budgets a tremendous growth in the area of consultants. Hundreds of consultants are now employed by the Government. The Prime Minister has on his staff what he considers to be top advisers. He handpicked a number of people and put them on contract for large sums of money for the purpose of advising him what to do. Obviously they could not have advised him about the election because we still do not know whether there is to be one, even though the zero date of 9 November has well passed.

What really concerns the Opposition and certainly concerns me as the shadow Minister for Administrative Services is the way in which information gathering and advertising costs are padded in the Budget matters before the Senate. The Minister admits that in the documents she has made available. She said that there are considerable difficulties in obtaining precise figures on departmental information programs. Quite honestly, I do not think that is satisfactory. There is considerable difficulty here. If we are voting large sums of money-the Minister has accepted the figure of $40m and it might well be that half of that amount is quite legitimate in terms of advertising for defence forces, publishing of gazettes and all the other matters that come within the purview of normal government administrative functions-and that being the case then nobody has any argument with her at all.

We find it unsatisfactory-we can only say that it is done at the direction of the Government-that money is disbursed throughout every department so that we cannot really find out what is scheduled to be done with the money. For example, I refer to the way in which that Government Budget survey we referred to was carried out. If the money is purely for the purpose of releasing government information such as the publication of manuals, Acts and all of those matters, that is one thing. However, to think that there is somewhere between $15m and $ 20m spread throughout various departments of the Commonwealth, on which little information is available to the Senate on its spending, is, I believe, a very unsatisfactory position. It is one on which we would certainly challenge the right of the Government to expect the Senate to pass without some critical comment.

I would not quarrel with the Government's right in relation to spending the $1. 5m which Mr Stone has objected to and which the Government has spent in spite of the officers' opposition. I think the officers are entitled to express their point of view. The Government is the responsible body. The Government makes the decision. The Government should tell us how it is to be spent. It should state whether it spent $300,000 on television advertising, $250,000 on publications, $ 100,000 on newspaper advertisements, so much on radio talks and so on. If that is the way the money is spent then let us be told. It seems to me we would certainly then have some valid grounds for objection if we could show-or even if we had a suspicion-that the money was to be used in respect of publicising Budget matters in a way which would suggest that it was a Budget of goodies. It is not a Budget of goodies. It is a Budget that takes more than it gives. That has been confirmed by the Sydney Morning Herald survey, by the Government's own survey and certainly the survey that my party carried out in respect of the Budget.

Probably we are now not going to be in a position where we will be fighting another premature election. Let us face it; this Government during the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s was always associated with premature elections. One is entitled to say that if the Government does not intend to hold a premature election then perhaps it will not want to spend $1.5m. Maybe that money can be saved and spent in a more useful way, such as in the area of child care or in other areas of public expendture which the Australian people are demanding that the Commonwealth Government support.
