PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 10 November, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS LEGISLATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Senator Harradine:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — As nobody else appears to want to speak on this particular matter it falls to me to draw this debate to its conclusion. When I last spoke on this matter I was considering the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation concerning the Government's proposals for industry-based unions. I now turn to the recommendations that were made by the Committee in respect of the Government's abolition of preference proposals. The Committee considers-it pointed this out in its report-that although issues of preference and voluntary unionism enjoy a high political profile the Committee received no substantive evidence from any employee claiming to have been directly aggrieved by the operations of the preference clauses, despite the issue of widespread public invitations for persons to make submissions to the Committee. Submissions were received relating to conscientious objection rights of sub-contractors and these were referred to the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. Since the interim report which raised serious doubts about the proposed section 4B the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) has written to the Committee but these doubts have not been resolved.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee notes that the Government intends that its proposed legislation will weaken the power of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to deal with union membership disputes. The Committee shares the view generally expressed by witnesses that the proposed legislation would not be conducive to industrial peace and would further unsettle the industrial relations climate. The Committee notes-I quote from the second reading speech-that the Government also intends its legislation to 'provide a better balance in the powers, rights and duties of employers and employees'. Clearly, this legislation would fundamentally disturb this balance in favour of employers. The Committee considers that the proposed legislation is an undesirable and unwarranted intervention into the field of industrial relations, particularly at a time when high levels of unemployment have already disturbed this balance. The Committee believes that viable unions are essential for the operation of Australia's system of conciliation and arbitration.

The Committee considers that the proposals of the Government for a new section 144A of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act would undermine this viability to an unacceptable extent and it recommends that it should not be incorporated into the Act. For similar reasons, the Committee recommends that the provisions of section 47 should be retained in the Act. Accordingly, the Committee recommends that the amendments proposed by clauses 3, 4 (2), 5, 7, 9 and 20 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 should not be incorporated in the Act. In the second reading speech on the Commonwealth Employees (Voluntary Membership of Unions) Bill 1982 the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, said that the Bill:
is . . . designed to put into effect in the area of Commonwealth Government employment the principles proposed in the Conciliation and Arbitration ( Amendment) Bill.

For reasons outlined in the Committee's proposal, the Committee recommends that the Senate not pass the Commonwealth Employees (Voluntary Membership of Unions) Bill 1982. The Committee notes further-I will quote again what the Minister said -that the Government intends that this legislation should ensure 'the protection of the rights of the individual'. Some individuals are quick to recognise their perceived rights but are not as quick to recognise their duty to associate with others for the common good. That is the view of the Committee.

In addition, the Committee states that there is a distinction between personal choice based on conscientious belief on the one hand and the dictates of self- centred individualism on the other hand. Quite clearly, what the Government was proposing to do was to put conscientious objectors on the same level as those whose objection to union membership is based on self-centred individualism. The Committee rejects that attitude. The Committee acknowledges the need to retain the status of conscientious objector which is presently provided for in section 144 of the Act. However, it recommends that those who object to union membership , for example on political grounds, should be entitled to exemption provided they pay a fee for service, as proposed by the Committee's extended recommendations.

The Committee stated that the submissions and evidence it received were extensive and raised complex issues. It recommended that there be consultation between the Government and the National Labour Consultative Council before further legislative initiatives are contemplated. I suddenly seem to have lost 20 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the sessional orders a speaker is entitled to speak for only 10 minutes on committee reports.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I thought that was the case but the clock showed that I had 30 minutes. I now have only four minutes left. Therefore, time does not permit me to detail all the recommendations of the Committee.

—I would be happy to move for an extension of time of five minutes if Senator Harradine finds that he cannot make all the points that he wishes to convey, in view of the fact that he thought he had 30 minutes in which to speak.
—I would be happy to support that.
—Do you wish to move that now, Senator Robertson?
—I will move it later, if it is necessary.
—You have heard the comments, Senator Harradine. You may proceed at this stage.

—Thank you. I turn to the recommendations relating to stand- downs and I will be brief. The Committee was unable to form an opinion from the evidence whether the rights of employers to stand down employees as a result of industrial action without reference to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is consistent with modern industrial practice. However, it is the Committee's opinion, that the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982, as drafted, would erode the authority of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and deny natural justice to aggrieved and unfairly treated employees. The Committee considers that the provisions of the Bill would not contribute to industrial peace but would create industrial instability. The Committee therefore recommends that the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 which provide for automatic stand-downs, be not passed by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The major concern of employers with respect to the current stand-down provisions are perceived delays which occur in proceedings taken pursuant to section 33 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The Committee accordingly has made suggestions as to how the current Act might be amended to overcome these concerns. The Committee suggests that a course of action that would take account of the concerns underlying the provisions of the Bill would be for existing section 33A to be tightened so as to require the initial hearing of applications for the insertion of stand-down clauses to take place within two working days after lodgment. Determinations would follow as soon as possible thereafter, depending on the surrounding circumstances. A right of appeal to the Full Bench would remain in section 33A. It would be exercisable within 21 days, and appeals would have to be heard within three working days of lodgment. Appeals would not be subject to restrictions imposed by section 35 of the Act.

The Committee considers that it would be desirable for these issues and proposals to be the subject of consultation between the Government and the NLCC, and has recommended accordingly. The Committee considered other provisions of the Bill relating to common rule and casual vacancies. They are listed in the report, and I do not intend to refer to them in detail. By and large, the Committee, with some reservations, recommends their adoption. Those recommendations are contained in the report.

The Committee endorses the view that, where a State union is deregistered in its own jurisdiction for actions inimical to the interests of the State jurisdiction and the parties thereto, such union should not be able to move into the Federal jurisdiction to avoid the consequences of its actions. The Committee considered that that view was shared by all responsible participants in both the Federal and State industrial relations spheres. (Extension of time granted). The Committee considered that this view is shared by all the responsible participants in the Federal and State industrial relations systems, but submissions to the Committee cast doubt on the efficacy of the proposals under consideration. It recommended that they would benefit from further detailed study by the industrial relations community and, in particular, by the NLCC.

I am not able to canvass at length all of the report, which comprises some 130 pages, but it is clear that the weight of evidence collected by the Committee was overwhelmingly opposed to the major provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 and the Commonwealth Employees (Voluntary Membership of Unions) Bill. In speaking of the evidence it is essential to note that the Committee's work was greatly assisted by the thoughtful and well- documented submissions which it received from the industrial relations community . I had it in mind to send to the script writers of the Yes Minister program the evidence given by various government departments, and the letters received from various Ministers. I must say that some of the material upon which the former Minister based his second reading speech was simply not correct. As one example, I advert to the fact that he stated quite categorically that the industry-based union proposal represented a policy decision of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. In the regard Mr Viner, no doubt unwittingly, misled the House. The policy of the ACTU on this subject is as follows:
1. The matter of the structure of unionism in Australia is one for the unions and the ACTU to determine. Employer organisations enjoy the same rights.

2. ACTU policy is not in favour of industrial unionism as being promoted by the present Government, employers and media. The policy of the ACTU is for fewer small unions by the developing of larger unions.
3. Branches and unions are requested to join with the ACTU to correct the false impression of ACTU policy being created on this subject.

That is an example of how the Minister had not revealed to this chamber the facts concerning these important measures. The new Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) has announced a review of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, but despite this apparently the Minister has still not withdrawn the legislation. In a statement to the American Chamber of Commerce on 24 September 1982, he said:
. . . I have asked my Department to undertake a wide-ranging review of our existing industrial relations system.
He added:
I have had discussions with the NLCC on the way this study will be carried out.

I should like to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that this statement was made while our Committee was still considering the Bills which, if enacted, would have had profound effects on the Australian industrial relations system. The Minister said that the review would be undertaken in respect of 'our existing industrial relations system'. Therefore, such a review would not take into account the changes sought to be introduced by the Bills.

Why the Government has not withdrawn those Bills is beyond me. It has the opportunity to include in three of the Bills that are to come before the Senate within the next two weeks what has been recommended. Reference to the other matters should be completely withdrawn. The Parliament is entitled to ask whether legislation presented to it creates in the public mind expectations which might be largely unrealised. Such legislation could run the risk of making matters worse by fostering disillusionment directed not only at legislators but at the system of conciliation and arbitration itself. Perhaps, as one witness has said-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Retail Trading Hours in the

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 October 1982, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the report.
upon which Senator Colston had moved by way of an amendment:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate agrees with the views and the conclusions expressed in the Dissenting Report by Mrs R. J. Kelly, M.P., Mr K. L . Fry, M.P. and Senator Colston'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It falls to me to continue the debate on the report of the inquiry by the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory into retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory. As is indicated in the document that honourable senators have before them, this reference was made as a result of the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act 1981 which, in section 90, provided for the deregulation of trading hours in the Territory by the repeal of the Australian Capital Territory Trading Hours Ordinance 1962, as amended. Honourable senators will recall that on that occasion I warned of serious problems which would flow for small businesses, for employees in the industry and for the community at large, if such a deregulation were to take place. I pointed to the fact that a number of the sites are controlled by property owners who in fact have the ability to exert considerable influence on the lessees of small shops in those centres when it comes to the question of trading hours. The raison d'etre for the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review ) Act in respect of section 90 did not apply. That is to say true market forces, of course, do not apply in that particular circumstance.

SPEECH.PARA: The majority recommendation of the Committee was to the effect that the present Trading Hours Ordinance be repealed and replaced by an alternative ordinance and that a new trading hours ordinance be drafted to include the following provision :

. . . the sale of goods in the ACT be permitted at any time except that a major retailer may not open for business between 1.00 p.m. Saturday and midnight Sunday. A major retailer is defined as a retailer employing more than 100 people in the ACT or elsewhere in Australia in any number of shops.

There is a recommendation by other members that the time be noon on Saturday. There is also a minority recommendation that the present Trading Hours Ordinance be gradually reinforced and that sufficient resources be made available for this purpose.

I cannot see anywhere in the report where the Committee has justified defining a major retailer as one employing more than 100 people. Where is that contained in the report? Where is the basis for that number of 100? The only similar situation that exists in the whole of Australia in respect of the employment of 100 people is in Tasmania. That is the place which the Committee did not visit. It went to the Northern Territory but it did not go to Tasmania. Yet it has picked up this figure and defines a major retailer as one which employs more than 100 people in any number of shops in the Australian Capital Territory or elsewhere in Australia. The law in Tasmania is precisely as is suggested in this recommendation, except that the closing time is midday on Saturday, but the definition of a major store is one that employs 100 people.

One would have expected, if the Committee were at all conversant with the retail industry, that it would not have defined a major store by reference to the number of people that it employs. A very major store can have only a few employees. Surely the Committee should have considered an appropriate definition to be by reference to the criteria of floor space. That would be the correct way to have done it, particularly with technological innovations that, unfortunately , are occurring in the retail trade. I say, unfortunately, because these stores do not have to compete overseas. They are a local industry. We ought to look at the employment of technology within the retail industry to see whether it is justified under the current circumstances.

Recognising the fact that we can now have a very large store with only, say, 20 or 30 employees, the Committee surely, one would have thought, would have attempted to look at that situation and define a large retailer by reference to floor space. But it did not do that. Did it pluck the figure of 100 out of the air or did it take it from the Tasmanian legislation? I will tell the Senate how the figure of 100 employees comprising a large store came about in Tasmania. At the time there was no legislation in Tasmania governing shop trading hours. That lack of legislation was hurting the small businessmen. It was also having a disruptive influence on the lives of those in the retail trade. It was also giving undue emphasis to the very large retailers. The reason that the Committee picked the figure of 100 people-I was not one who supported the definition-was that one supermarket in Launceston happened to employ about 89 employees. Because it would have been a politically inopportune decision for the government of the day to pick any figure below 89, it picked 100.

Is that the sort of standard that we ought to be dished up by a committee of the Senate? Why should we be given this sort of drivel? We are given the definition that a large store is one that employs 100 people without any explanation that I can see in this report. One can only conclude that it is because of a political decision in Tasmania at a particular time. Surely the national capital will not be led by the nose in this respect. Surely it deserves a better consideration than that which has been provided in this report, particularly by reference to the definition of what is a large retailer. I again suggest that this matter should be referred to the House of Assembly in the Australian Capital Territory so that it can perhaps establish some sort of inquiry as to what should, in the circumstances with which the national capital is faced, be a large retailer.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not given your definition. How many square metres?

—I would be very happy to provide the honourable senator with the detailed consideration that I have given over a long period to the question of what ought to be a large shop, over a long period, considering the technology that has affected retailers. The honourable senator would surely appreciate that the definition ought to be based on floor space rather than on the number of employees. I would support a proposition to refer this matter to the House of Assembly for its consideration. I understand that someone will move such a motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I moved an amendment to the motion that was moved by Senator Reid. I seek leave of the Senate to amend the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I amend my amendment to add the words:

SPEECH.PARA: and that Mr President forward a copy of this resolution to the Speaker of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly.
My amendment now reads:

. . . but the Senate agrees with the views and the conclusions expressed in the Dissenting Report by Mrs R. J. Kelly, M.P., Mr K. L. Fry, M.P. and Senator Colston and that Mr President forward a copy of this resolution to the Speaker of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am opposed to the amendment moved by Senator Colston. The motion I originally moved was that the Senate take note of the paper. I did so because I believe that the report ought to be made available for the Senate, the Parliament and the community to have an adequate opportunity to look at it. I move the following amendment to Senator Colston's proposed amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'Senate', insert:

'is of the opinion that it would be premature for the Senate to determine an attitude to the Report of the Committee before the Canberra community has had the opportunity to consider the report in detail and before the Government has had an opportunity to respond to the Report'.

The view that I put to the Senate is that that is a more appropriate way of dealing with a report which has been tabled by the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. At this stage the Senate ought not present its view on the findings in the light of the Government's report. In a sense it is setting a lead that is in appropriate taking into account all the evidence. It is a pity that Senator Harradine did not present his views to the Committee. He did not choose to do so although we took evidence over a considerable period. I will deal with the other matters raised by Senator Harradine today at the conclusion of the debate.

This matter will be put to a vote in the Senate. Clearly, there is debate in the community about it. A lot of evidence has been given to the Committee on all aspects of the inquiry. Various points of view have been put forward. Three reports are before the chamber at the present time. One was presented by Senator Colston, Mr Fry and Mrs Kelly and another, independently, by Senator Georges. It is the view of the Liberal Party and the Government that trading hours should be deregulated. The majority of Committee members felt that deregulation was not appropriate at this time and presented another report. Obviously the Australian Democrats want full local deregulation. As I have said, I think it is appropriate that the community and the Parliament have an opportunity to look at this report in some detail before firm decisions are taken about trading hours. Certainly I think the Government should have an opportunity to respond to the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats oppose the full deregulation of shopping hours. I say that with great respect to what has been said by one of my colleagues in the House of Assembly. For reasons which I propose to give we believe that a national campaign is being waged by major retailers for total deregulation of shopping hours. Canberra is being used as the toe in the door-the thin end of the wedge. If this proposition is successful in Canberra it will be copied nationally to the detriment of small business people, particularly those who are being exploited mercilessly by people renting out supermarkets. As Senator Reid ought to know, it would be to the detriment of the local suburban or village shopkeeper. If deregulation were brought in the livelihoods of those shopkeepers would almost certainly be finished.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act 1981 was rushed through the Senate to beat a change in the composition of the House. Honourable senators will remember that that was before the five Australian Democrats took their position in this chamber and before the Government lost control of the Senate. This legislation was rushed through on party lines. During the debate on that Bill it was agreed that clause 90, seeking to repeal the present trading hours ordinance for the Australian Capital Territory, would not be proclaimed until the Committee had conducted an inquiry into the question of the implementation and possible effects of deregulation of trading hours. The Government must be disappointed with the recommendations of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory as they do not support the complete deregulation of shopping hours. Clearly, this is what the Government was hoping for-a position which is consistent with its inclination to cater to the needs and desires of big business. The Australian Democrats are disappointed with the majority report because the Committee has chosen to recommend, on the basis of what it admits is inconclusive evidence, that Saturday afternoon trading-the first step towards total deregulation-be allowed.

The report has identified all the major problems involved in the deregulation and extension of trading hours. Nevertheless, it has chosen to disregard the weight of evidence against adopting such measures to make proposals which will severely affect the competitiveness and viability of small business in the Australian Capital Territory. This will lead to the further acceleration of the trend towards casualisation of employees in retail industries and consequent loss in job security. It will lead to a significant increase in prices of goods to the consumers and force the small retailers in large shopping complexes to remain open whenever management so decides. I have heard some humbug from big business representations that have been made to us that this would not happen. Can any honourable senator really imagine a small trader in the Woden or Belconnen shopping complexes closing down while the bigger emporia remain open even if the masters of the shopping centres or complexes tell them to do so? They would find themselves out of business very quickly.

Furthermore, in making these recommendations, the Committee is clearly creating a precedent which big business can draw upon to press its case for extended trading hours in other States. The Committee admits in its report that small traders were unanimous in their complete opposition to weekend trading because of fears regarding the implications of increased competition from big business and the nature of the restrictive leases operating in large shopping complexes. The report further states:
It is difficult to support or reject this proposition.
Yet amazingly the Committee concludes on page 25 of its report:
It is the Committee's view that change in current hours of operation would not have a significant detrimental impact on small business.

In other words, after hearing evidence, the Committee admits that the unanimous view of small business is that deregulation of shopping hours should not proceed and then it recommends against that unanimous view. I sometimes smile when I see those filthy publications that come out of Liberal Party headquarters denigrating the policies of other parties. At the same time some creature over there states that the Liberal Party is for small business. Yet it allows this sort of thing to happen. Every Liberal member on the Committee recommended deregulation of shopping hours in the Australian Capital Territory. The Committee has failed to address itself to the problem of small traders in large shopping complexes being forced to trade during hours determined by the management of the centre.

On the question of the effect of Saturday trading on prices to consumers, the small traders asserted that the deregulation or extension of trading hours would inevitably result in higher prices because of the extra costs involved with longer trading hours. Even David Jones estimated that Saturday trading would cause a 1.5 per cent rise in the price of goods while Waltons estimated it would result in an increase of 13.3 per cent to the wages bill. Here we have a big trading conceding an increase in wages of 13.3 per cent. From what side of the House do we get the argument that the only cause of inflation is an increase in wages? It is from the Government side, and yet we have all Government members voting for a move that will result in an increase, according to Waltons, of 13.3 per cent to its wages bill. Nevertheless, the Committee, in its final summary, states:
. . . it is not known how any increased costs which may be associated with a change in present operating hours could be offset.
The Committee, in its discussion of the impact of extended hours on employees, accepted the validity of the unions' arguments. The Committee stated:

There is, however, strong support for the claim that in light of the experience of late night trading, deregulation with its concomitant increase in trading hours will contribute to a further decline in the number of full-time permanent positions . . .

The concern of the unions about the likelihood of an attack upon penalty rates for Saturday afternoon work is also justified since the major retailers have indicated their intention to include and consider Saturday as an ordinary working day.

That is on pages 32 and 33 of the report. Despite this acceptance of the evidence submitted by the unions and the fact that the retail industry in the Australian Capital Territory provides employment for twice as many people as does any other private industry, the Committee is prepared to make recommendations which will threaten the job security of thousands of people. In 1980 11,000 people were employed in the retail industry in Canberra.

The majority report, with a callous disregard, also dismisses the argument that weekend trading will cause disruption to the family life of employees and reduce opportunities for sporting and religious pastimes at weekends. What it would do to the family life of family businesses where a business depends essentially on the total presence of a man and wife is not mentioned. The report of the majority of the Committee is totally inadequate. Clearly it set out to justify a policy of the Government which was decided long before the Committee was requested to investigate the issue. As it turned out, the Committee found it could not justify the complete deregulation of trading hours yet its proposals signal the first step towards such a policy. Therefore, the Australian Democrats accept the minority report of Mrs Kelly, Mr Fry and Senator Colston as a more balanced assessment of the evidence presented and the needs of the community. If I understand their minority report they recommend that there be no deregulation of trading hours and that the status quo be preserved from 1 p.m. on Saturday; that is, that there be no deregulation from 1 p.m. Saturday until the ordinary hours of opening on Monday morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to Senator Reid's amendment. The Australian Labor Party does not accept Senator Reid's amendment for reasons that I will outline. Her amendment is to state that the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: Is of the opinion that it would be premature for the Senate to determine an attitude to the report of the Committee before the Canberra community has had an opportunity to consider the report in detail . . .

I cannot see any reason why the Senate should not express an opinion even if the Canberra community is going to consider the report in detail. The Canberra community has already expressed an opinion to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory in great detail. In the dissenting report which I signed together with Mrs Kelly and Mr Fry, we pointed out in paragraph 2 the number of people who had approached the Committee. I would like to reiterate what we said in paragraph 2:

An indication of general opposition to deregulation of trading hours is contained in Appendix III of the Committee's report. Approximately 4,000 shoppers, 200 small traders, the Australian Association of Independent Businesses and the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Union wrote to the Committee to register their total opposition to deregulation.

When the Committee was sitting, the Canberra community had the opportunity to put forward its opinions. We believe that our dissenting report follows the recommendations which were made by the Canberra community. Even if the Canberra community wishes to make some comment-I am not quite sure how it will make that comment as a total group-there would be no reason for the Senate to withhold its expressing an attitude to the report. Senator Reid's amendment went on to say that the Senate should not determine an attitude 'before the Government has had an opportunity to respond to the report'.

When Senator Chipp was speaking a moment ago, and certainly when I spoke to this report about two or three weeks ago, it was pointed out that the Government did not give this Senate the opportunity to express an opinion on whether the Trading Hours Ordinance 1962 should be repealed. What it did was to give to the Senate as it was composed some time ago the opportunity to do this. It used a Senate which was not composed as it is now. The new Senate had been elected but the new senators had not taken their place at the relevant date of 1 July when the opportunity was given to the Senate to express an opinion about whether the Trading Hours Ordinance 1962 should be repealed. I presume-I understand that the Government would have presumed-that if the opportunity were given to this Senate to vote on a motion that the Trading Hours Ordinance 1962 be repealed it would not pass this Senate. So I hold that this Senate should be allowed to express an opinion, an attitude, and that it need not wait until the Government has had an opportunity to respond to the report.

There is one other matter that I would like to mention. Senator Harradine made a comment about our definition of a major retailer. A major retailer was defined in both the majority report and the minority report as a retailer employing more than 100 people in the Australian Capital Territory or elsewhere in Australia in any number of shops. Because we put in the words 'or elsewhere in Australia in any number of shops' it includes all major retailers in the Australian Capital Territory-Waltons Stores Ltd, David Jones (Canberra) Pty Ltd, Coles New World Supermarkets, Myer Emporium Ltd and J. B. Young Limited-as all have 100 employees or more in the ACT or elsewhere in Australia in any number of shops. I spoke to Senator Harradine about this outside the Senate chamber and he expressed the opinion that perhaps shops would be set up which were major retailers but would have branches only in Canberra and therefore would circumvent the spirit of what the Committee recommended. I imagine that if the spirit were circumvented the relevant ordinance would be changed accordingly.

Senator Harradine also mentioned that perhaps we should have considered floor space rather than the number of employees. Unfortunately this was not evidence that was presented before the Committee so it was not something that we were able to take into account. I reiterate that the Australian Labor Party will oppose the amendment moved by Senator Reid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find myself in a position not so much of disarray but of uncertainty. I have just come from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which has been sitting all day dealing with the serious matter of fraud and overservicing in the medical area, to take part in this debate. I find it necessary to speak in this debate because I was a member of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory and in fact I put in a minority report-a minority report which dissents not only from the original report but also from the dissenting report of my colleagues. After looking at the amendment moved by Senator Colston and the amendment moved by Senator Reid, I find myself obliged to support my dissenting report. I will read it.
—I knew someone would quote it.
—I notice the interest that the Minister for Social Security has in my dilemma. My dissenting report reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. I concur with the dissenting report with exception to recommendations (b) and (c).
My recommendations are:
(a) deregulation of trading hours in the A.C.T. be rejected in the interests of retailers, employees and consumers;
(b) the present Trading Hours Ordinance is to be gradually re-enforced and that sufficient resources be made available for this purpose.

2. Any attempt to legalise present irregularities will lead to further unlawful practices. This will be used eventually as a justification for complete deregulation. As the dissenting reports points out this would mean a serious disadvantage for the people of the A.C.T.

I must explain that I find the recommendations of the majority report and the dissenting report to be unreal. I believe that the recommendations and the dissenting report as it stands would be very much to the disadvantage of the people of the Australian Capital Territory. As a result of my dissenting report a rather harsh editorial in the Canberra Times suggested that I was very hard, that, in fact, I was unreal and that I did not have the interests of the citizens of Canberra at heart. It indicated also that I did not properly understand the situation that applied that is, that Canberra citizens were not obliged to shop at 11 o'clock, if they did not want to. I know that. The editorial went on to say that retailers were not obliged to open their shops. That is where it is wrong. In that conclusion the editorial is absolutely wrong. The writer does not know the nature of a market- place when it comes to retailing. One person opening a shop in a particular area for an extended period forces his competitor to open. Senator MacGibbon will say: 'So what?'

TALK.START.PARA: —So what? You took the words out of my mouth.
—So what! I can read Senator MacGibbon's mind because he is the type of person who would impose upon everyone else extended hours of work to serve his purpose. His purpose is often one which is--
—You are wrong, Senator.
—Order! Senator Georges, you must address your remarks through the Chair, not to Senator MacGibbon across the chamber.
—I cannot blame Senator MacGibbon for the interjection because I invited his intervention. So, I accept what you say, Mr Acting Deputy President, and get back to the thread of my argument.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened in my experience is that extended shopping hours permit certain retailers to take advantage of those extended shopping hours. Even if a majority of other retailers disagree they are forced for a variety of reasons to follow the change. We have a situation where the whole social environment can be destroyed by a need of retailers to match their competitors. If there is one greedy and avaricious retailer operating in a particular area, he influences the decisions of every other retailer in that area. We can have the classic example in Canberra where at night one can see in a certain area a service station in all the glory of its illumination with not one customer present but with some poor juvenile sitting behind a console waiting for a customer. In the next area, exactly the same situation exists. An operator cannot close if another is to remain open. It would be to his disadvantage.

Anyone who understands what advertising is all about and sees how much unnecessary advertising there is on television and in newspapers will realise that one person who advertises an item forces his competitor so to advertise in case his share of the market is lost.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is like giving out how-to-vote cards on an election day.

—One can go into a dozen other examples. What fascinates me about Canberra and about Senator MacGibbons's attitude is that in Canberra 65 per cent of the employees work possibly a 37 1/2-hour week. They have the best of conditions and a limitation on working hours; yet they expect the service industries to stay open for extended hours for their benefit. They do not seem to realise that that sort of attitude leads to higher costs and higher charges which are to their disadvantages.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposed extension of trading hours, if adopted will lead to a further problem. It will lead to the breaking down of the conditions of employees. I refer to the conditions of work, the type of work and the awards under which employees operate. The planned industrial awards and the regulations which apply in this area which we are discussing exist for the benefit of all. They lay down the conditions under which everyone operates. They do not lead to unfair competition. I remember in this House when lawyers who did not understand what the market-place was all about, what conditions of work were and what conditions were needed in the market-place, moved for the abolition of resale price maintenance. This was a lawyer's approach to the problem. All that flowed from that was, I might say, widespread discounting and a breakdown in the level of servicing. I interrupt my argument to note that I had forgotten that the time for this debate is limited by the proposed order of the consideration of business. That occurs under a Standing Order the adoption of which I did not agree with. So, my time for speaking is finished.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I oppose the amendment moved by Senator Colston. I have much pleasure in supporting the report. My only reservation is that the recommendation does not go far enough. I think we should let trading hours set their own level, as Senator Georges has so correctly suggested. That is a fair thing for the Australian community.
—You don't do it in Queensland.

—We would if I had my way. We have to trust private enterprise to lift our standard of living and not take the closed shop philosophy of the trade unions and all those sorts of restrictive practices which afflict the free enterprise system. This afternoon we have had the biggest exposure I have heard of the counsel of fears from the ignorant.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 4.30 p.m., in accordance with sessional orders the Senate will now proceed to the consideration of General Business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 10 defines the actions that a Governor -General must take if the House of Representatives passes a resolution expressing a lack of confidence in the Prime Minister and other Ministers of state. If certain things do not happen it requires that the Governor-General shall dismiss the Prime Minister from office. The clause as printed and before us goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Governor-General shall not otherwise dismiss the Prime Minister from office.
I move:
Page 8, clause 10, lines 15 and 16, leave out'', but the Governor-General shall not otherwise dismiss the Prime Minister from office''.

The Committee's time is very limited. We have undertaken privately to be very brief in our debate on this matter. I understand that it will be treated as non- controversial. So I shall not go into detail on my views. I say simply that I have no objection to the Constitution having in it provisions that define what the Governor-General shall do in certain circumstances. However, I do have an objection to trying to second-guess every situation that could arise and to limiting absolutely the Governor-General's powers in this way. My amendment has the effect of leaving intact the intent of clause 10 that the Governor-General be required to dismiss a Prime Minister if certain things happen in the House of Representatives. However, I seek to take out of it the final definition of the Governor-General's powers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —By agreement, albeit the kind of agreement one enters into when one has someone standing over one with a foot on one's neck, the time for debate for the conclusion, we hope, of this Committee stage of the Bill is limited to 10 minutes. So, again, like Senator Martin, to whom I am indebted for her speech, I will be very brief in indicating my position on the amendment she has moved. Basically, I accept the inevitability of the success of Senator Martin's amendment. For that reason I will not kick and scream to the extent that I might otherwise have been minded to do. It might be thought that the particular phrase that she seeks to take out of the Bill does go further than is strictly necessary to ensure the kind of qualified fixed parliament model that this Bill is now all about. Certainly, the presence of that clause would, if it were to remain, quite properly generate debate as to the extent, scope and necessity for the reserve powers of the Governor-General. It remains the position of my party that the powers of the Governor-General be codified and limited. This Bill codifies and limits them, so far as dismissals are concerned, to a very considerable extent and, arguably, I appreciate, to a greater extent than is the accepted convention at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the better place to have a debate about the proper scope and extent of the Governor-General's reserve powers of dismissal if any such are to remain would be at the proposed next session of the Australian Constitutional Convention. In that respect, might I take another minute to read into the record the proposed declaration of convention that will be coming to that Convention from one of its standing committees relating to the Governor-General's dismissal power. The proposal that will, it is hoped, be debated by the next session of the Convention as perhaps an appropriate statement of what conventions governing this should be is as follows:
The Governor-General dismisses a Prime Minister (and thereby dismisses the other Ministers constituting his Government) only if-
(a) The Government fails to obtain or ceases to have the confidence of the House of Representatives and the Prime Minister does not resign or obtain a dissolution;

(b) It is established that the Government cannot and will not obtain Supply for the ordinary annual services of the Government in time to enable it to lawfully carry on the business of government and the Prime Minister does not resign or obtain a dissolution;
(c) The Government is involved in a gross and patent breach of the basic principles of the Constitutional system and the matter is not justifiable, or cannot be resolved by the courts.

I simply put that on record-it is probably improper of me to have done so, I am not sure-as a basis for debate in the months between now and what may be a session of the Constituional Convention rather than having that kind of debate here and now. If it does turn out that there is an agreement along the lines embodied in that proposal or in some more drastically curtailed version of it then, of course, there may still be time to embody that in the text of the proposal which I hope will be going forward to constitutional referendum. I indicate that it is not proposed to put to a division Senator Martin's amendment . It is one, the force of which we accept the inevitably of even if we do not like it very much.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly indicate that it must be evident from Senator Evans's remarks about the inevitability of the matter that the Government will be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Martin. It does significantly render the proposed clause much less objectionable. So the Government will support it for the reasons outlined in the speech of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on the second reading. We will be voting against the clause but in favour of the amendment to the clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I support the amendment inasmuch as one is compelled to support any part of this legislation. It seems to be at least a qualification of some sort. I looked only very briefly at the proposals today. Senator Evans's proposed alteration is almost ultra vires section 5 of the Constitution, which is very much in line with the Constitution of Papua New Guinea at present. It is interesting to note that in that country the Prime Minister, with the support of the Opposition, is seeking to move away from the circumstance whereby, if a motion of no confidence in the Prime Minister is carried, another Prime Minister can be appointed without the voters having a say about the new government. Of course, one recognises from time to time that that has happened in our history as well. But I do not think it is thoroughly desirable. I think the alternative of going to the people is a satisfactory course. I support the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I suggest that in the light of the amendments that have been made in running in the Committee stage it would be appropriate to delete the last two phrases from the title so that the title will simply read:

SPEECH.PARA: A Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution in relation to the duration of House of Representatives and the holding of elections for the Senate and House of Representatives.
