PROCTEXT.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to alter the hour of closing the poll.
Bill presented, and-by leave-read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill provides for the hour of closing the poll for Senate and House of Representatives elections to be two hours earlier than is presently the case; namely, 6 p.m., instead of 8 p.m. The purpose of this is to attempt to make the polling times in all elections, State, Territorial, and Federal, as uniform as possible in order to reduce confusion. Already a majority of polls operate with 6 p.m. as the closing time, the trend being in the direction of earlier closing, and this Bill will bring the elections for the national Parliament into line. Additionally, this measure will reduce the hours which polling staff are asked to work. This will decrease the pressure caused by a long day's effort on both the Commonwealth Electoral Office staff and party supporters, as well as reduce slightly the cost of holding the election. The earlier closing of the polls will also enable the Electoral Office to conclude the night's count with a firm result in any but a finely balanced election. For those electors who are not able to vote during the hours proposed, such as those restricted by religious conviction, ample opportunity exists to cast their ballot earlier using postal balloting procedures. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to provide for the listing of names on ballot papers for House of Representatives elections to be determined by lot.
Bill presented, and-by leave-read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The objective of this Bill is to reduce the effect of the unconsidered vote- normally called the donkey vote-on the national result in House of Representatives elections by introducing the law of probability into the selection and order of listing of names on the ballot paper for such elections. In combination with two other proposed reforms of the Electoral Act-the printing of party affiliation next to the candidates' names, and the simplification of ballot marking procedure through optional preferential voting-this Bill should help to eliminate the donkey vote as an undermining factor in our electoral system and remove the temptation, succumbed to in the past, for particular political parties and individual candidates to abuse cynically the loophole of alphabetical listing.

This Bill will also ensure uniformity in the method of selection for order of listing between the House of Representatives and the Senate, as well as allow for the continued use of how-to-vote advice, which is a traditional feature of Australian elections. There was little, if any, opposition to this measure when it was introduced in the Parliament in 1974. The current Treasurer (Mr Howard) was one of its supporters. The package of reforms contained in the Commonwealth Electoral Act Amendment Bill 1974, one of which this Bill is based on, was passed in the House of Representatives and was lost in the Senate only on a tied vote. This measure then has been delayed for eight years now despite widespread bipartisan support for it. There should be no further tardiness in its implementation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to provide a form of optional preferential voting at elections and to alter the rules relating to informal ballot papers.
Bill presented, and-by leave-read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The aim of this Bill is to reduce the extremely high number of informal or invalid ballots, particularly at elections for the Senate. The means by which this will be achieved is by replacing the current requirements of compulsory exhaustive preferential voting with a form of optional preferential voting and by liberalising the definition of informality. These two measures, in combination with the printing of party affiliations next to candidates' names, the listing of names on the ballot papers by lot, the continued use of how-to- vote cards, and an effective program of voter education, will ensure that more Australian electors will have an effective and secure involvement in the electoral process. The key to achieving this result can be summarised as simplicity and clarity. In Senate voting enormous numbers of voters are deprived of a meaningful vote purely because of the requirement that all squares must be marked. The percentage of informality regularly rises above 10 per cent nationally and often over 12 per cent in particular States. This clearly may have an influence on the outcome of the election.

Yet there is no rationale for this requirement. The number of ballot papers whose extreme preferences have to be counted is miniscule. Indeed, at least 80 per cent of voters in Senate elections see their first preference candidate elected, and in the case of States which elect a minor party candidate or independent this can be as high as 98 per cent. How perverted then is a system which can require that voters have to mark as many as 72 preferences on one ballot paper. There can be no plausible defence for the current electoral situation which deprives so many hundreds of thousands of citizens of their voting rights. If these reform measures are not implemented this number will pass the one million mark at the next election. I have prepared tables and a much longer second reading speech on this Bill. I seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
NUMBER OF CANDIDATES AT HALF OR FULL SENATE ELECTIONS 1901-1980
NSW Vic. Qld SA WA Tas. Total
* Denotes full Senate election.
* Senate enlarged to 10 seats per State.
GENERAL ELECTIONS FOR THE SENATE INFORMAL VOTES AS A PERCENTAGE OF TOTAL VOTES
NSW Vic. Qld SA WA Tas. Total
* Full Senate elections.
* Senate-only elections.
* Senate increased to 10 Senators from each State, 7 elected at this election.

Some further information will assist in any interpretation of these figures. The election for the first Federal Parliament was held under various State Acts and as such, plus the fact that it was the initial and somewhat novel experience of federal elections, can be ignored for statistical meaning.

From 1903 to 1917 voters were required to mark 3 and only 3 crosses against the names of their choice (in 1914, 6). The informality during this period is obviously lower than at any other time (mean=4.72%).

From 1919 to 1931 this was changed to a form of optional preferential voting which required the voters putting down preferences for twice the number of vacancies plus one, generally speaking that was 1 to 7. The mean informal vote during this period was 8.96%. However, it should be noted that during this period the number of candidates for election was generally small and on several occasions less than 7.

From 1934 to 1980 exhaustive preferential voting has prevailed with the number of senators to be elected generally 3 per State; and since 1949 this was increased to 5, with 7 in 1949 and 10 in 1951, 1974 and 1975. Since 1949 also the number of candidates has increased considerably. The mean informal vote for this period is 9.06%. However, it should also be noted that during this period occurred the four Senate-only elections in which mean informality was considerably lower.

One further point needs making, and that is that with all the systems used, including the form of optional preferential used between 1919 to 1931, there was a very strict requirement for the ballot to remain valid. That is, any variations from the requirement would be set aside as informal.

The only conclusion that can be reached then from these figures is that simplicity, whether it be in the form of the ballot paper, or the style of voting, or the number of candidates, or the absence of a simultaneous House election, contributes a major role to the reduction of the informal vote. There has been insufficient study done of this problem (the limited work done by the Australian Electoral Office in 1978 has not been made public) and academics are not agreed on the implications.

This Bill is an attempt to bring as much simplicity as is possible and practical into the current electoral system. No matter how many candidates may appear on the ballot paper the elector will still only have to put in preferences for the number of candidates plus one (i.e. 6 or 11) in the Senate, and just one in the House of Representatives.

In the Senate method of counting this number of preferences will ensure a balance between the smallest possible number for effectiveness and simplicity (i .e. 1 preference) and the need to prevent large numbers of ballot papers being set aside because their preferences have run out before they have voted for a successful candidate.

These exhausted ballots (as they are called) will account for less than 1% of the formal vote, and could be even less provided electors are aware of the nature of the voting system. Of course, not exercising their full voting rights of putting in more preferences is an added alternative for electors who wish to do so in an optional preferential system.

The other major contributory factor to the high level of informality is the strict definition and interpretation of what constitutes an informal vote. When this is associated with a complex voting system then the negative result is amplified.

The current situation is such that any voter making the simplest of errors anywhere on the ballot paper invalidates the ballot even though the error may not have any connection with the voter's intention. For example, '25' may be written twice, or the number '38' left out altogether. The number '27' may look like a '24' or a '21'. Yet the first few preferences (perhaps only the first preference) would be the only preferences that need be counted and the intention of the voter would be clear. Nevertheless, the votes would be invalid.
There is no reason why the voter's intentions should not be counted while they remain clear, even though later in the preferences there may be an error.

Nor should these measures be seen as a party political attempt to gain advantage for the ALP. The optional preferential method presented in the Bill does not deprive smaller parties and independents of the opportunity to direct their supporters' preference votes to selected candidates. Nor should it prevent surplus preferences from successful candidates flowing to them.

In fact, if anything, the smaller parties and independents have most to gain. The Australian Electoral Office survey of informal voting showed that such candidates suffered disproportionately more from probable protest informal votes than did the major parties.

The most recent major academic study of informality claims that high informality relative to low informality actually favours the conservative parties over the ALP. In short this Bill strives to reduce the informal vote.
Debate (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to make a very strong protest, as an ordinary back bencher, at the Executive's riding roughshod over the rights of honourable senators to deal with a whole range of papers and reports concerning Executive activity and reports of executive authorities undertaking certain roles in Australia's public life. Some 49 reports which are before the Senate were meant to be made available for honourable senators to comment on for some one and a half hours during the course of today's proceedings. A mere 20 minutes ago the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) came into this chamber and , unbeknown to honourable senators, moved a motion which had the effect of taking away our opportunity to exercise our right of review over a great range of government and government authorised activity. Not only did this frustrate honourable senators in their role of review but also it completely and utterly curtailed the exercise of that right for this sitting week.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is thereby saying to all those taxpayers who thought honourable senators might have interest in, for example, the report of the Commissioner of Taxation that that is not worthy of some consideration in this chamber today. The Government is saying to all those who have an interest in peace that the report of the General Assembly of the United Nations-Second Special Session Devoted to Disarmament should not be spoken about by honourable senators today. It is saying to all those users in the community of the services of Telecom Australia that the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Telecommunication Services in Australia ought not to be considered by honourable senators. The list goes on-the Agricultural Policy; the report of the Australian Shipping Commission; the report of the Uranium Advisory Council; the report on the Higher Defence Organisation in Australia, the report of the Industrial Relations Bureau ; the report of the Australian Federal Police; the report of the Industries Assistance Commission; and the report of the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council. The Government has said that honourable senators will be denied the right to comment on those reports and exercise their right of review.

I find it very ironic that that situation should occur after both Senator Walters and Senator Missen this afternoon felt constrained by their experiences at the Inter-Parliamentary Union meetings in Cuba and Rome to complain about the fact that parliamentarians at that international forums were not acting as responsible, democratically elected parliamentarians exercising a proper right of independence from the Executive. I find it amazing that within half an hour of those comments being made from Government senators that the Executive should override our ordinary senatorial rights of comment on this important range of reports which covers, as I have indicated, a very wide variety of matters of concern to the general public and the community of Australia. I certainly did not want to let the matter pass without raising my voice in protest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to protest most strongly at what Senator Tate has just had to say to this Parliament. He talked about the Executive riding roughshod over this Parliament. I would like to know what Senator Tate had to say in his Caucus room in relation to the nonsense matter of public importance which was raised this morning by his side in relation to maintaining the rage of 11 November 1975. The sessional order adopted earlier this year provides that on a Thursday the Senate will debate for at least an hour and a half in the morning the papers which are tabled on a Thursday. They are especially tabled on a Thursday and the sessional order provides that we will start off with an hour and a half debate in the morning. If we get an opportunity later on a Thursday afternoon there will be further debate in relation to those papers. Instead of that occurring this morning a matter of public importance was raised.
—Of course it is a matter of public importance.

—Nonsense, it is not a matter of public importance because 11 November 1975 is past history. As if that is not bad enough we could have had one speaker a side. Perhaps Senator Button could have spoken for his side and the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, could have responded; that would have been adequate. At first our side was told that there would be two speakers a side. Finally we were told that the Opposition intended to have three speakers a side. We ended up having six speakers on an absolute nonsense matter talking about past history. As a result we had 12 minutes to debate papers. I was in the chair at the time. It was nearly ten to one before we got around to debating the papers for which we should have had an hour and a half debate.

SPEECH.PARA: As a special concession to Senator Evans this afternoon and at his specific request we brought on the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliament) Bill 1981 and gave him another 10 to 15 minutes in which to finish off that nonsense Bill so that he could issue his Press release which he had prepared and planned to issue immediately before he went to Sydney. Senator Tate complains about our side riding roughshod over the Parliament. It is his side which is riding roughshod over the Parliament. It is not giving honourable senators on this side an opportunity to debate matters which we consider to be of importance. We are having to put up with the nonsense that we put up with this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-There have been upsets in the day's program. I think the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) as a Minister understands that. We have had an opportunity of discussing the matter with him. In some respects there was an error by the Government-I think some delay was occasioned by us-in the procedural motion which Senator Chaney moved, an error in the sense that it was not agreed that it should be done in that form. Senator Tate, who is gaining his rage rather than maintaining it, as Senator Lewis said, was I think properly and understandably aggrieved by the course which was followed. I do not think it is of any help for Senator Lewis to come in here with his red neck arguments from Portland, or wherever he comes, and talk about this sort of thing. It does not help the progress of the Senate's business.

SPEECH.PARA: We have undertaken to the Minister that we will facilitate the business of the Senate as much as possible. We have repeatedly given those undertakings in the last two months. Only last night Senator Martin said that it was a very sad thing that the Senate's legislative program had been delayed by the failure of the Government to get its legislation through the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Delays by the House of Representatives, not the Government.

—The honourable senator is not so naive as to suggest that that pack of thugs that the Government has in the House of Representatives cannot get business through the House if it wants to. As the honourable senator knows, the Government can process the business of the House of Representatives as rapidly as it wants to. But that was not done because, of course, the legislation was not ready. The Government has had much disagreement within its party about what it is going to do about tax evaders. That is the problem with which the Government has been concerned. The matter of public importance which was raised this morning was not a nonsense matter. Senator Lewis referred to it as a matter of history and said that we are not interested in history. If honourable senators read the Hansard they will find that the Leader Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, is interested in nothing else but history. If he could talk about contemporary issues, the business of the Senate might proceed much better than it does. I hope that the Government will see fit to facilitate the progress of some discussion of the reports. We will be happy to talk to the Government about other arrangements that can be made about Government Business.

—by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. Senator Button referred to some statements which I made last night in debate on the Estimates. I referred to the fact that our consideration of the Estimates and the Appropriation Bills was late because they were late in arriving in the Senate and had been delayed in the House of Representatives. I did not suggest that it was because the Government was in any way slow in preparing or introducing the Appropriation Bills. I was merely pointing out that the Appropriation Bills came into the Senate some two or three weeks later than we might have expected because other things had intervened in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to lodge the same type of objection as that which was lodged by my colleague Senator Tate. I do so because of the way in which the motion was put by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney. We on this side had no idea that Senator Chaney intended to incorporate things in the motion in the way he did. I understood, from looking at the Notice Paper, that at the end of the introduction of certain Bills by Senator Gietzelt the motion would be put by Senator Chaney that Government Business would take precedence over General Business. We would have been given the opportunity to lodge our objection to that-even though I realise that some agreement had been made-and we would not have gone to a division on the matter. We would have gone on to consider Government Business. The matter was handled in a very sneaky way.

SPEECH.PARA: Ever since we have had a change of sitting hours in this place we have run into trouble every Thursday because nobody can follow the business sheet, including honourable senators on the Government side. We are all over the place like a dog 's breakfast. The sooner we get back to sitting proper hours where at 8 o'clock every Thursday we consider General Business to enable back benchers to air their grievances in the time allocated for General Business, the sooner this place will operate in a better and fairer way for everybody.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am indebted to Senator McLaren who made it clear that he did anticipate our moving on to consider Government Business but that he thought a different procedure would be followed. I can only say with respect to the procedure that, as Minister in charge of the Senate at the time, I used the form of motion which was prepared by the Clerks. I was not in any sense trying to be clever in what I did. I was surprised that the objection which I understood would occur did not take place. I understand that when I read the motion honourable senators might not have picked up that it was in three parts and that the third part covered the return to consideration of Government Business.

SPEECH.PARA: I am indebted to Senator McLaren because I would not have wished the Senate to think this was a matter of bad faith. The setting of business is normally handled by the Whips with the respective leaders being involved. I became involved today because, on behalf of the Attorney-General, I was concerned with legislation which Senator Evans, on behalf of the Opposition, was anxious to have passed through the Committee stage. For that reason, and for that reason alone, I became involved in some discussions with Senator Evans. It was arranged that his Bill-I understood with the approval of the Opposition-would take precedence to enable it to be cleared in time for him to meet commitments elsewhere in Australia. In other words, there could not have been a more obvious attempt to accommodate the requirements of the Opposition that it should get a non-Government Bill, which it regarded as important, considered today. I note the request which has been made by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) that we should look at the possibility of providing some time to discuss papers. I will refer that to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, for consideration.

I wish to stress that in a situation where numbers in the Senate are so even- the balance lies with the Australian Democrats and the independent senator-it is quite obvious that the Government would not really see it as a particularly clever way to approach the business of the Senate to proceed by way of subterfuge or trickery. If we are to meet the program which is set down it is necessary for reasonable compromises to occur. Sometimes that is very dificult given the strong interest which honourable senators have in debating particular issues which are perhaps close to their hearts or the hearts of their electors. In the instant case, we have moved a motion which I understood was anticipated. As I say, I am grateful to Senator McLaren for the acknowledgment of that in his comments. I suggest that we move on to consider some Bills and other matters of moment rather than spend endless hours debating this procedural matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I agree with the substance of Senator Tate 's remarks, although I am surprised that he made them. I was given to understand that an agreement had been made between the Government and the Opposition parties that there would be no discussion of papers in this later part of the day. Whilst I disagreed with that, obviously there was no point in objecting to it. If the Opposition parties had wished to discuss the papers, we would now be discussing them. I thought that the point raised by Senator McLaren was very odd . I cannot see what this matter has to do with the times at which the Senate sits. I would have thought that an honourable senator of his experience would have been able to read today's red business sheet very easily, because it is probably the most explicit red that we have had all week. Therefore, I find that comment very surprising.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet
Advance to the Minister for Finance
Acquisition of Sites and Buildings (Defence Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two questions to ask. Providing the Government is co-operative, the matter will not take more than a few minutes . It concerns the appropriation of $1.5m for the Department of the Treasury for what has been called an information program. My questions are: Is this program to proceed? Have advertisements been prepared? Are those advertisements newspaper advertisements, television advertisements, radio advertisements or a mixture of all three? Assuming that such advertisements have been prepared and the program is to go ahead, on what date will it commence and for how long is it envisaged it will continue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators Robert Ray and Gietzelt made comments on the same matter concerning an information program vote of $1.5m for the Department of Treasury. Throughout the Committee stage of the Appropriation Bill and the consideration of the Estimates the views of those honourable senators have become well known with regard to this matter. They have been expressed on numerous occasions. The information in response to their earlier discussion was presented to the Committee on 21 September and was printed in the Hansard record of the Estimates Committee C on 11 October.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robert Ray asked some questions with regard to advertising programs. In particular, he raised the question of the nature of advertising programs during an election period. As was stated in the information presented to the Committee, there is considered to be the need for information to be given on a number of program changes and programs that have arisen from the Budget which is before the Committee at present. Changes have been made in areas such as housing rebates, housing assistance, taxation matters, social security, training schemes for the unemployed and matters of that sort. Programs are being arranged in the usual way as far as many departments are concerned. Indeed, some of the information that was given to the Committee listed a number of departments with information or advertising votes. As was said earlier today, and previously something like $40m will be spent on these matters in this year.

Senator Ray was particularly interested in the forthcoming by-election in Victoria and asked about the way in which government advertising would proceed throughout the campaign. I think it has to be understood that information programs and advertising campaigns of government are a matter of continuity. They are matters which arise from time to time. They can be spasmodic things that might occur with regard to, say, Aussie Bonds or something of that sort. We really would be seeking the proper use of funds, the accountability of government with regard to public expenditure. When talking about information programs that arise from the most recent Budget, I think one would have to differentiate between those sorts of programs and what would be a political campaign which would be run during a campaign by the party organisations of the political parties concerned. To my thinking the political party campaign is quite different from government services and government information programs. The only example I could perhaps give to Senator Ray, who is from Victoria, is the advertising for the forthcoming Waverley by-election which will be occurring in that State. He could look at some of the advertising that has been undertaken by the Victorian Government with regard to, for example, its tourist authority or its tourist aspirations. We see the Premier featured in those advertisements and advertisements to attract attention to the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you ever been to Waverley as a tourist?

— I am talking about advertisements in Victoria. There are the sorts of advertisements we see with regard to public transport and so on. I think it is accepted that throughout a by-election in a State or for a Federal seat there is still a continuity of government. Government does not suspend all advertising that might arise from government departments during that time. It is a matter of the accountability for expenditure by government and the proper use of expenditure. Political campaigns are quite separate from government advertising in that sense.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ray was also interested whether the results of surveys which were undertaken through the Department of Administrative Services could be made available to senators and members on request or generally. I think he mentioned the public surveys and the community issues surveys. Just as we did with the post-Budget survey, in which some interest was shown, I am quite certain that the Department of Administrative Services, through the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), would be perfectly happy to make the results available. I will see that Senator Ray's interest is drawn to the Minister's attention. As to whether they are complicated surveys containing the volume of information of the sort that arose in the survey report which was placed in the Parliamentary Library or whether they are short surveys that could be put on general distribution to members and senators, I think that matter would need to be investigated at the relevant time. When the information that comes from the surveys undertaken through the Department of Administrative Services becomes available I can see no difficulty in making it freely available .

Questions were raised by Senator Walsh with regard to the $1.5m for information funds. He asked whether this program is to proceed, whether the advertisements have been prepared and on what date they will commence. I do not know that it is appropriate to relate those questions to the $1.5m. Some advertisements which are in the course of preparation through the Department of Administrative Services will cover the changes in the Budget. As I understand it, Ministers are still to meet to determine the acceptability of the proposed advertisements, what form they will take and when they are to commence being shown. I think that meeting is to be held either at the end of this week-that would probably be tomorrow-or early next week. At the meeting a decision will be taken with regard to some of the proposed advertisements that have been prepared through the Department of Administrative Services.

Having made those statements, I am not able to say whether the campaign is to proceed because we have yet to decide, through the Ministers concerned, on the acceptability of proposals put forward by the advertising agents. As to the program of issue of advertisements and whether they will involve radio, television or the Press, I am not aware of the precise facts but I understand that some of the television advertisements or the information to be given will refer people to more detailed information, say through the Department of Social Security, relating to housing or whatever. I think a combination of information would be provided through television, perhaps radio, and the Press on these matters. However, as to the commencement dates and the final form of the advertisements, I am not able to give information yet because as far as I know that has not yet been decided finally. I think they were the only questions raised with regard to these matters. I commend Group C to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reference to the answer of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), I take it from what has been said that some of the more detailed information is likely to be available for the Senate next week following the meeting of Ministers. I do not wish to pursue the matter now but I understand that that is likely.
—That is right. It has not been definitely decided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the reply I want to make a couple of points. The Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) has indicated that the primary, if not the sole, intention of this $1.5m information campaign was to convey to the public information about changes pursuant to the 1982 Budget. The great majority of those changes commenced as from 1 November. If the intention of the Government was to inform the public about those changes that information campaign-to adopt the Government's euphemism-would commence now or about now and it would continue for the next couple of months. The fact that the Government has not yet decided whether to proceed with the planned information campaign confirms very strongly the suspicion that the intention never was to provide the public with information but to provide the Liberal Party with a bit of public money for a political slush fund to spread Liberal propaganda for an election which was planned for this year.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government does not proceed with the information campaign that it had planned we will have absolute confirmation that that, indeed, is the true situation-that the Government was not interested in informing the public but was very interested in diverting a bit of public money into the Liberal Party till in order to use it for spreading Liberal propaganda at public expense. I suggest that a further confirmation of that analysis of the intention of this measure is the fact that it is being contemplated that television will be used. If the intention is to convey information, particularly about rather complex matters such as changes in taxation and changes in social security benefits, obviously the most effective way to convey it is in written form so that people can refer back to it. The ephemeral message given from television does not convey information but it is a very effective means of spreading propaganda and impressions, which I suggest are likely to be highly misleading impressions at that.

With those words I will leave that matter. I want to take up one other matter. A letter concerning the Australian Taxation Office written only this week by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to Mr Willis in reply to an earlier letter to the Treasurer from Mr Dawkins states that the estimate of tax to be recovered from the recoupment legislation which is presently before the Senate is $620m which, I understand, comprises something like $500m of ordinary company tax not paid and about $120m of Division 7 tax which was not paid because the companies were disposed of in the way in which they were. Incidentally, that is the highest official estimate I have seen. I know that there is nothing terribly surprising about that because, as time goes by, the Taxation Office is able to compile more accurate lists of the number and type of companies which are to be affected by the legislation. A substantially different recoupment Bill was introduced in the House of Representatives on 21 October. Of particular note is the inclusion in that second Bill of clause 3, sub-clause (12), which was not in the original Bill. That sub-clause provides for the exemption of vendor shareholders of companies disposed of to promoters in the belief that current year profits would be successfully treated in the hands of the promoters under tax avoidance schemes-which schemes subsequently failed because they were disallowed either by the Commissioner or the courts. I trust that that is a brief but reasonably accurate interpretation of what that sub-clause provides.

I understand that some 700 companies are likely to be exempted by that sub- clause, which was not in the original legislation, and that the revenue forgone as a result will be proportionately much higher than would be suggested by the number of companies involved. No figure has been suggested, but the impression created is that as much as a third, or perhaps even more, of the revenue originally expected to be recovered will not, because of the insertion of sub- clause 3 (12), the limited-innocence clause, now be recovered. I do not want to discuss in great detail the merits or otherwise of that sub-clause; it will be the subject of debate next week.

The point I want to take up is that the most recent estimate by the Treasurer of the revenue to be recovered from this legislation, as given in his letter of as recently as the last Monday, appears to make no allowance for the revenue leakage consequent upon the addition of sub-clause 3 (12) to the Bill which was introduced into the House of Representatives on 21 October. I seek clarification from the Australian Taxation Office, through the Minister for Finance, as to whether that latest figure of $620m has allowed for revenue leakage attributable to the insertion of sub-clause 3 (12).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

We have no later advice and I suggest that it would be appropriate to deal with the matter when the recoupment tax Bills are before the Senate. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to a matter which causes me a great deal of concern. It is to be found under the estimates for administrative expenses of the Department of Administrative Services at page 20 of Appropriation Bill (No. 1), and concerns the conduct of Commonwealth elections, referendums and industrial ballots. I want to refer to a number of specific matters in regard to that item. Honourable senators may recall that as shadow Minister for Administrative Services I have asked over the last couple of years a number of questions about the conduct of ballots and the preparation of the electoral roll. On 24 March 1982 I asked the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume, a question in respect of the habitation reviews and the maintenance of the electoral roll in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it a fact that, as a result of restrictions based upon staff and funds, the Chief Australian Electoral Officer is unable to carry out the regular habitation review procedures in most States of the Commonwealth? Does that mean that the electoral rolls will not be brought up to date?

The reply suggested that no particular financial problem or limitation had caused habitation review activities in this current financial year to be reduced . The Minister suggested that the curtailment did not flow from staff restrictions. Yet page 20 of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1982-83 shows that of a sum of $5,182,000, only $4,232,000-a difference of $950,000-was spent in that year. The reply that was given to me suggested that there was no curtailment of funds in respect of habitation reviews. That means that the information that was provided to the Parliament was inadequate and is belied by the information that is available in item 05 concerning administration of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. It is clear from the report of the Australian Electoral Office that there has been a reduction in the habitation reviews and, contrary to the reply that I received, there has been a definite curtailment of activities to such an extent that the habitation reviews were reduced considerably in the financial year ending 30 June last year. I would like an explanation for that.

I raise another matter which I believe is quite serious. The recent report of the Australian Electoral Office indicated a large increase in the number of ballots conducted under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act-in other words, ballots referred to as court ballots. A substantial number of unions now are utilising the provisions of the Act to have their ballots conducted by the Australian Electoral Office. There is currently a section 73 application before the Federal Court in respect of a ballot that was conducted a year ago from the New South Wales branch of the Amalgamated Postal Workers Union. I appreciate that I am restricted in what I can say about this matter. Honourable senators may recall that I raised some serious matters about interference in the post office in the conduct of a ballot in 1979. As a result of alleged irregulatirities, a section 73 inquiry is being conducted by the Honourable Mr Justice St. John. However, Mr Lewis, the officer who was appointed to conduct that ballot, has admitted in evidence-as reported in the Australian Financial Review about five weeks ago-that the ballot papers the subject of the court proceedings that were in his custody have disappeared while the court has been considering the matter.

I cannot comment on the case except to say that grave allegations of irregularities have been made. I find it completely unacceptable that the officer concerned in the conduct of that ballot should admit to the court that the ballot papers have disappeared from his custody. In those circumstances, I find it difficult to understand how the Chief Australian Electoral Officer can appoint the same person, Mr Lewis, to conduct several other ballots which are currently in progress. This officer has admitted before a court that he has lost ballot papers which are the subject of a section 73 application. It seems to me that for that officer to be placed in charge of other trade union ballots is a dereliction of duty not only on his part but also on the part of the Commonwealth Electoral Officer. If he cannot properly handle the ballot papers for a case which is currently before the court one is entitled to say, according to the constituents who have been firstly to see my office while Parliament was sitting and subsequently who came to see me, that there are misgivings, justified or not, about that person's capacity to handle properly the ballot which is due to start very shortly.

I notice in an advertisement in one of the daily newspapers that the same Mr Lewis is conducting another ballot. I think we ought to be given an explanation here of how an officer, who freely admits that the ballot papers in his custody disappeared during a court case, can still be held to be a person above reproach in respect of the conduct of other elections. Not only must justice be done but also it must be seen to be done. Therefore there are misgivings felt by the unions concerned that that same officer should be appointed to carry out ballots when in fact he is still a witness before a court to which he has freely admitted that ballot papers have disappeared. If the trade union movement is to continue to utilise the resources provided by the Parliament, that is, the application for ballots to be conducted by Commonwealth industrial legislation, obviously a returning officer needs to be appointed for that purpose in whom members, no matter what their ideological beliefs may be, will have complete and utmost confidence in the way in which he conducts ballots.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I want to refer to under the line items for the Department of Administrative Services deals with both the Remuneration Tribunal's changed recommendations and the parliamentary and ministerial staff and services. My colleague in the other place, Mr Manfred Cross, yesterday asked a question of the Minister for Administrative Services ( Mr Newman) as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Was the definition of 'home base' for the purpose of the payment of travel allowances to Ministers altered in the 1982 review of the Remuneration Tribunal? What was the reason for this change? What evidence, or other information, was advanced to the Remuneration Tribunal in support of such a change?

In reply to the first part of the question the Minister said yes, the definition for the 'home base' was altered. To the second part of the question the Minister replied that the reason for the change was administrative convenience and efficiency and to the third part of the question stated that he did not know, and that the question would have to be asked of the Remuneration Tribunal. We know, of course, having looked at the latest recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal, which were put down in this Parliament early in the Budget session, that the definition of 'home base' was changed in the 1982 review of the Remuneration Tribunal. The 1980 review contained the following definition:
'Home base' for the purpose of payment of travelling allowance to Ministers, shall be the home of a Minister unless he nominates otherwise to the Minister for Administrative Services.
The 1982 review changed the definition to read:
'Home base', for the purpose of payment of travelling allowance to a Minister, shall be the principal place of residence of the minister.

Under the 1980 definition it would always have been open to a Minister to nominate a residence other than his home for the purpose of payment of travelling allowance. In the 1980 review it was made clear that the home base would be the principal place of residence of the Minister. There was no provision for nominating any other place of residence. The new wording allows much less scope for ripping the system off. I am told that the change in wording was not recommended by the Government. I want to know whether the change in the definition of 'home base' was recommended by officers of the Department of Administrative Services. I also want to know the reason for it being altered. If I do not get a satisfactory answer from the Minister I will ask further questions about three very senior Ministers who I am reliably informed were involved and were the reason for the changes being made in the definition of ' home base'. A very large amount of money is involved.

While we are being told repeatedly by senior Ministers of the Government that the work force of Australia should exercise great restraint in their demands for increased wages those Ministers are doing the very opposite. I will not pursue the matter further. I will leave it to the Minister or to an officer who perhaps might volunteer the real reason why the change has been made. The names of the senior Ministers might even be volunteered. If that is not forthcoming I will put to the Ministers a series of questions about those Ministers and the amount of money that is involved. This matter has to be cleared up. This country is being told time and time again that the work force is making too great a demand on the public purse and that that is the reason for the economic chaos we now face. We heard this argument enunciated here today by Senator Carrick in no uncertain terms. He said that the high level of unemployment in this country was brought about by the excessive demands of wage earners; that that was the reason the country is going down the gurgler. I would say from the outset that if we are to put a stop to that sort of activity the senior Ministers of this Government will have to set the example. I will leave the matter at that. I ask the Minister to give me the information I have sought. If she cannot, I will pursue the matter further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to give information with regard to a question that was answered yesterday in the other place by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman). I am advised that the definition of 'home base' was altered by the Remuneration Tribunal to include the words 'principal place of residence'. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will follow this matter up now so that we do not get out of sequence. I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) whether in the recent 12 months period-that is the calendar year-the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Anthony Street, claimed travelling allowance for a total of 320 days. SPEECH.PARA: I also want to know whether the Deputy Prime Minister, now the Acting Prime Minister, Mr John Douglas Anthony, claimed travelling allowance for 200 days in the last 12 months. I also want to know whether he was engaged in what is know as the rotation of home bases. That is, when the Parliament is in session, one nominates the home base in one's electorate as where one lives, and, when the Parliament is in recess, one gives one's home address as Canberra. We all know that Mr Anthony has a home in Canberra, financed at a very low rate of interest. From the answer that we had the other day, I think that he has paid only about $ 360 in interest on the loan for that home in the last year.

I also want to know whether the Minister for Defence, Mr Sinclair, also made a claim in the last calendar year for a similar period of 200 days travelling allowance. To each of those persons this would have meant an amount of $17,000. I also want to know whether Mr Sinclair had been engaged in what is known, as I have said, as the rotation of home bases which means, I repeat that whilst the Parliament is in session the home base is given as the place where one lives in one's electorate, or somewhere else but away from Canberra, and, when the Parliament is in recess and one is back in one's home town or electorate, the home base is put down as having been Canberra.

If that is so, I can well see why a recommendation has been made to the Remuneration Tribunal. The Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, may not have made that recommendation. He quickly sidestepped that question yesterday. He must have known all about it. He, being the Minister for Administrative Services, I would hardly think that he would not be briefed on what has been going on in the Department, particularly when these senior Ministers, as I have said, are repeatedly calling on the work force of Australia to exercise restraint in their demands. We know that the Acting Prime Minister would have a salary, without travelling allowance, of about $90,000. It would take the average worker about-

TALK.START.PARA: —Five years.

—Longer than five years, because not too many workers get more than $15,000 a year-so to earn $90,000, which Mr Anthony gets in one year, would take them at least six or seven years. As I have repeatedly said in this Parliament, he has availed himself of the perks of office by having a cheap home loan. SPEECH.PARA: We notice another matter in an answer given to my colleague Senator Bolkus yesterday about Mr Sinclair. It cost nearly $1,700 of taxpayers' money recently- in July, I think-to fly him by VIP aircraft from Sydney to Inverell for him to spend about 2 1/2 hours in the electorate and then to fly back to Sydney where his aircraft broke the curfew by landing after midnight.

These are the sorts of things that are going on, and these are the people who ought to be setting the example to the work force. If they are continually to demand restraint from the work force, they are the people who have to set an example. In this Bill, one can see the amount of money that is being expended on these people. One can look there to see what it costs for the Minister for Foreign Affairs to go overseas. One can look to see what it costs for the Minister for Administrative Services. It is an enormous sum. Rumour has it that quite a large amount of that money was used in a weekend trip down the Nile for each of them. I am told that it was about $5,000. Perhaps as I have given notice of that, we shall get an answer about it. Another Minister-not so senior, but he is a Minister-made a trip on the Orient Express some time ago when he could have travelled by other means, and that was a large cost, too. If necessary, if I do not get the right answers, next week I shall name that Minister in Parliament, too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The first question that I raise is somewhat similar to the matter which has just been raised by Senator McLaren. It is occasioned by the fact that earlier this week I contacted the appropriate Senate official to inform him that he had overpaid my travelling allowance-not that I object to getting money, but I could not quite understand how I was being paid for days when I was out of Canberra. While I was talking to that official he said that there had been a slip-up and that the payment for another senator from my State had been translated to my pay slip. He said that it would be adjusted. I then asked why anybody would expect to be paid for being in Canberra on a Saturday night except perhaps on some very rare occasion when there was some parliamentary reason for being here. I was informed that no real checking process is used and that senators and members are placed very largely on trust in their claims for TA.

SPEECH.PARA: Apparently prior to 1974 the situation was that a senator or member was paid travelling allowance for time necessarily spent in Canberra. That is how it was defined. At the moment we are paid travelling allowance for each overnight stay away from our home base which is occasioned primarily by parliamentary business. When the Senate or the House of Representatives is sitting this is checked on through the transport office when we fly in and fly out. In that case it is fairly easy to check on the number of days that we spend in Canberra. It is assumed that if we are here during a sitting week we are actually doing parliamentary business. At the moment I do not want to engage in a debate on who does what work and how often.

TALK.START.PARA: —A work test.

—I think there would be a number of people who might fail that. During recess weeks apparently no assumptions are made about why we are in Canberra and each senator or member is expected to fill in a claim form. It is those claim forms, the officer told me, that are taken on trust. The officers assume that if a senator or member says that he or she is in Canberra for a particular reason then indeed he or she is. Checking around a little more after that, since my curiosity was aroused, I discovered that there are a number of senators and members who not only own, as I do, a home unit or a home here in Canberra or Queanbeyan but also actually live in Canberra, Queanbeyan or some other local area for a substantial part of the year. It has not been unknown, so the rumors that I have heard assert, for some of these members and senators to claim a substantial amount of TA including TA for the Easter weekend and Christmas Day. Being perhaps a bearer of very little brain, I find it difficult to work out why a senator or member should be so conscientious that he or she is busy in Canberra on parliamentary work even over Easter and on Christmas Day and New Year's Day.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I ask just exactly what checking up is done on claims made by senators and members for travel during up weeks and in particular for the longer winter and Christmas recesses. If it is not going beyond the bounds of decency, I also ask how many senators and members are known-I want the number, not the names-to live in or around Canberra for the majority of the year and whether there is in effect any significant difference between the TA paid to those senators and members who reside here for a substantial part of the year rather than in their home States or electorates and the TA paid to those of us who travel on a weekly basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I think it would be best if I sought leave to raise one small matter relating to the appropriations under the Department of the Treasury. Because I was at a meeting and out of the chamber I was not aware that we had gone back to consideration of the Appropriation Bills. If leave can be granted I will be very brief on this matter .
—There are no Treasury officers here.
—I am sure that I would not be able to get a response immediately anyway. It is more a comment I wish to make on the matter than a question that requires an answer.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September I raised with the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), who represents the Treasurer (Mr Howard), a matter relating to a de facto partner paying health insurance. In de facto relationships there may be no children. I understand that among de facto couples it is fairly widespread practice for one person to take it upon himself or herself to pay the family rate of health insurance. In actual fact de facto couples are being advised by some health benefit funds that they can claim health insurance payments as a taxation deduction. The problem is that misleading advice has been given by the health benefit funds.

SPEECH.PARA: In one particular instance misleading advice was given to me in relation to this matter by the Taxation Office in Perth. When I was contacted by a constituent about this matter I rang a fairly senior officer in the Taxation Office and I was told that it was quite permissible for a de facto partner to claim the family rate for health benefits. I passed on that advice to my constituent. At the time I spoke to the officer I said that, because the assessment had already gone out, perhaps the easiest way to resolve the issue would be for the person concerned to lodge an objection. The officer agreed that that might be a much simpler way of tackling the matter. I then advised my constituent of the action she should take. After she had taken that action she received a letter which stated:
The basic health insurance rebate applied only to premiums which secure entitlement to basic benefits for the taxpayer on his/her legally married spouse .

The purpose of my asking a question on 22 September about this was to find out whether in actual fact the Taxation Office was ever going to move into the twentieth century and recognise, as other government departments do, that de facto relationships exist and that, by its legislation, it is virtually encouraging people to cheat. To my knowledge, what happens now is that if the partners in a de facto relationship recognise that they can pay family rates but cannot claim family rates as a tax deduction in some cases both then claim the single rate, which is not the same as the family rate, so the Government is in actual fact losing money.

I am a little disturbed with the response from the Treasurer. Apparently the Government has no intention of changing either the Income Tax Assessment Act or the health insurance rebate provision to include de facto partners. I do not have an estimate of the number of people who are living in de facto relationships where no children are involved, but I have had a number of inquiries at my office and a number of inquiries have been handled by the health benefit funds. I am not naming any particular fund because I have been in touch with most of them in my State. Most of the health benefit funds have told me that they have been approached on any number of occasions during the year about whether it is possible for people in a de facto relationship to claim the family rate when they have no children. The health benefit funds have been under the misapprehension that it is possible for these people to claim a family rate. A number of them have been so doing. As the advice given to me came from a senior officer of the Taxation Office, I would anticipate that that information would have been handed on to a number of couples who are in a like situation.

I make this contribution to the debate basically to suggest that there are a number of ways in which this problem could be tackled. To my mind it is a simple matter. If we are concerned about tax cheats-much has been said about them in the headlines lately-we should not be encouraging people to cheat in a situation where they believe they have just cause to claim health insurance rebates. In actual fact we should simply be amending the health insurance rebate provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act to enable de facto partners who do not have dependants to be able to make a satisfactory claim on their taxation form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) will recall that a short while ago I raised the matter of habitation reviews. As a consequence my office was contacted by the State member of parliament for the electorate of Bathurst. He claimed-I have every reason to believe that his claim is a correct one-that a habitation review is taking place in the urban areas of his electorate of Bathurst and that no habitation review has been carried out in rural areas. There has been a lot of criticism about the selectivity of habitation review-the fact that they are carried out in some electorates and not in others. There seems to be a rather haphazard approach to habitation reviews. As the Government has suggested in recent times that money will be allocated during this financial year for the carrying out of habitation reviews I wonder whether we could have an assurance from the Australian Electoral Office that habitation reviews will be carried out on an electoral basis, on a thorough basis and not on a basis of selectivity.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the general experience we have had with these matters is that urban folk may well move about or be more transitory than others, but there is evidence, according to the local member, Mr R. J. Clough, of changes taking place in rural centres largely because of the current problems of unemployment in rural towns. All he is asking-I think his request is a proper one and is one that the Opposition would want to see applied generously-is that if the electorate is to be reviewed, and that would involve the Federal electorate of Macquarie, that it be done not on a selective basis but include every subdivision in every town and every little village, regardless of the difficulties.

I am sure the Minister appreciates that persons in country towns are appointed by the Electoral Office to do these reviews, whereas in rural sectors they are usually done by the local postmistress, police constable or some other agent appointed by the Electoral Office who can or cannot do the job thoroughly. SPEECH.PARA: The next problem I wish to raise was brought to my attention by the Town Clerk of the City of Port Pirie. It is a somewhat more parochial matter than the one I raised earlier. Apparently earlier this year the Chief Property Officer of the Department of Administrative Services in South Australia wrote to the Corporation of the City of Port Pirie and also to the Port Pirie Rifle Club Inc. advising them that the property on which the rifle club was situated had been declared surplus to the requirements of the Commonwealth and asking whether either the Council, the rifle club or both were interested in purchasing the property. It gave them a sort of priority option on it. The property concerned is approximately 40 hectares in the hundred of Pirie. It had been used by the Army for some time. The Department of Administrative Services indicated that the Army had no further interest in the rifle range and as a courtesy, I guess, offered it to the rifle club.

The current market value was assessed by the Commonwealth valuer and I understand that the figure arrived at was $5,000. The Port Pirie Rifle Club is quite happy to purchase the land but does not want to spend that amount of money on the purchase. The club has apparently occupied the range in its present situation for something like 30 years. In that time the upkeep of the land has been basically its responsibility. It has undertaken almost all of the improvements made at the range at its own expense. Firing mounds have been grassed, water has been laid on, pit ramps have been erected, the stock butt repaired and raised. I am told that the only thing the Army was asked to do was to cut the grass to avert a fire, and that was only twice in 10 years.
In a letter addressed to the Clerk of the Corporation of Port Pirie seeking his assistance, the secretary of the rifle club stated:

In view of the 'Zoning' of the area and the fact that almost all of the land concerned is and has been subject to saltwater flooding, or inundation, we seek the support of the Corporation towards a revaluation of the property. We would have been prepared to accept a valuation of no more than $2,500.
Apparently the land consists, in part at least, of a tidal creek bed. The club felt that the $5,000 that the land had been valued by the Commonwealth valuer was twice the price it should have been.

I am aware that this is perhaps more a matter of revenue or at least of potential revenue forgone than actual expenditure. But I wonder whether I could be informed whether the Department of Administrative Services would be prepared to take into account the matters that were raised by both the Council and the rifle club with regard to the valuation, perhaps to ask the Commonwealth valuer to take these matters into account and to re-assess the price that is being asked for something that has been looked after and used by this club for over three decades.
