TALK.START.PARA: —During the consideration of the estimates for the Department of Defence, one of the first issues that was discussed by the Estimates Committee was what the Department of Defence had learned from the Falklands war, especially in relation to the effectiveness of Australia's present defence equipment and our future requirements. As a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I had been fortunate to receive a briefing from a British defence team, prior to the Estimates Committee hearing, on the major lessons from the war, such as the power of the Exocet A- type missiles and the ability of those ships that were struck by them to withstand fire damage.

SPEECH.PARA: It was certainly not unreasonable for Committee members to express interest in learning what lessons Australia had gained from the experiences in the Falklands . I do not believe that we received a satisfactory reply. It was an issue that was raised continually by a Government senator from Tasmania. It is a pity that he is not here this afternoon to raise the issue. I do not know whether it would have been possible but it certainly would have been to Australia's benefit if we had had observers from the Royal Australian Air Force, the Royal Australian Navy and the Army in the Falklands to report on the performance of some of the major defence show pieces of both Argentina and Great Britain. The availability of such first hand knowledge would have been invaluable for our defence strategists .

I remind the Senate that, some time ago, a Senate committee strongly stressed the fact that we should have defence attaches in parts of the world where conflicts are likely to break out. A Senate committee recommended that we have defence attaches positioned in the Middle East. Nothing has been done about that . The situation at the moment is that we have, I think, some 93 or 94 defence attaches throughout the United States but we do not have any in Damascus, Tel Aviv and the places where I believe they could do a very good job indeed. Also out of the Falklands war we discovered that the Australian Navy had been making a concerted effort to recruit British specialist officers and sailors particularly for submarine crews. As would be expected, the Falklands dispute has meant a severe blow to this recruitment campaign.

We on this side of the chamber are not terribly concerned that the Government will not purchase HMS Invincible. Whilst the proposed cost was supposed to make the purchase a bargain, we believe that the vessel possessed few of the requirements deemed neccessary by our Navy. The buying exercise in relation to the Invincible proved to be not only a waste of time but also a waste of a good deal of money. During the consideration of the estimates for the Department of Defence we were informed, following a question that I asked about the non- recoverable costs that Australia had so far been involved in concerning the purchase of HMS Invincible, that we had already spent money on the establishment of a project office in the United Kingdom, on overseas travel, including the assessment of HMS Invincible, and on the establishment of an office in Bath, England, as well as costs associated with the office of the Director General of Ships in the Ministry of Defence (Navy) and the initial operating costs of the project office. This came to a sum of approximately $200,000, which has now gone down the drain.

I now deal with another issue in the Department of Defence estimates-that is, patrol boats. For some years now the Government has been promising to supply additional patrol boats to make the outlying areas of the Australian coastline more secure. My Opposition colleagues from Western Australia in particular have become increasingly concerned at this Government's failure to build a patrol boat base in Western Australia and grant that State additional patrol boats. The Australian coastline is extremely vulnerable. We have long believed that the Government should give top priority to making some attempt to patrol it more effectively. Earlier this year the Minister for Defence deferred the purchase of five patrol boats. When I asked how many of these five patrol boats would now be purchased I was told that they had been deferred until 1985-86 and that, even then, it remained to be seen how many would be ultimately acquired. That is not a very encouraging response, I submit, on such a very important issue.

Some members of the Estimates Committee expressed concern about the ultimate cost to Australia of the 75 F18 Hornet aircraft. The contract which Australia entered into late last year has become increasingly complicated and more and more prone to price rises. Articles are appearing in the Press regularly suggesting that all is not well between the United States Navy, which is the major purchaser of the F18, and the supplier, McDonnell Douglas. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an article from yesterday's Australian entitled 'F-18 bombs out in US Navy tests'.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
F-18 BOMBS OUT IN US NAVY TESTS
From PETER SAMUELin Washington
The US Navy's F-18 fighter plane-provisionally chosen by the RAAF as its new war-plane-has failed attack tests at sea and shown deficiencies serious enough to leave its future in doubt.

Many weeks of tests aboard the aircraft carrier USS Constellation have shown the F-18 seriously deficient in range, take-off ability, landing weight, fuel- carrying capacity, turnaround time and in escape systems.
The navy's prestigious Operational Test and Evaluation Force has recommended against certification of the plane for use in an attack role.
Since it is mediocre but very expensive when used as a fighter, non-use of the plane in the attack role will heavily undermine its whole rationale.
The Secretary for the Navy, Mr John Lehman, has repeatedly said the US Navy has adequate alternatives to the F-18 and is prepared to cut off the $40,000 million program.
The major argument in the F-18's favour is its ''swing'' capability, which means it can be switched from an attack role to a fighter role simply by being armed differently.
Three major Washington publications yesterday reported the failure of the F-18 in the carrier tests-Defence Week, Aviation Week and the Washington Times.
But there has as yet been no official response to these reports, despite promises of a statement by the Pentagon press office.
The stories in the three authoritative publications differ somewhat.
Defence Week said the carrier tests showed that as a bomber the F-18 was 110 sea miles short in range.
Naval officers described the plane's turnaround time-80 minutes-as ''terrible'' . By comparison the F-14 can be turned around, essentially rearmed and refueled, in 20 minutes.

Aviation Week, published by McGraw-Hill, reported that the F-18 in its carrier tests proved a range of only 220 sea miles with two MK83 1000lb (4539kg) bombs and no external fuel tanks. In a similar mission the A-7E, an alternative attack plane, has a range of more than 400 sea miles.
Defence Week said the over-weight condition of the F-18 meant it required high winds across the carrier deck to take off.
Claims of a 575 sea mile range were made to Defence Week by defenders of the plane, but it was admitted these were achieved with the use of three external fuel tanks.
Commander of Naval Sea Systems, Admiral Ernest Seymour, is reported to have admitted recently: ''We thought we'd be able to fix it (the plane), but we have not been able to.''
By WILLIAM PINWILL

The Minister for Defence, Mr Sinclair, last night rejected the criticisms of the F-18 as not relevant to the latest production aircraft or not applicable to the land-based role in which the RAAF will use the fighter.
The US Navy report had also praised key features of the aircraft, he said.

In a statement to the Australian, Mr Sinclair said: ''The role of operational testing and evaluation is to critically assess the F-18 aircraft against the stated US Navy requirements irrespective of improvements planned or under development.
''In this case, the aircraft used were not fully representative of production aircraft.
''The F-18 has performed up to expectation in the US Navy squadron at Lemoore Naval Air Station.
''The report commented favourably on such aspects as the aircraft's capability for self-defence, reliability and maintainability.''

TALK.START.PARA: —One departmental officer who appeared before the Committee explained that this type of contractual problem was fairly common practice in the United States, where the Government demands a price reduction from suppliers as a matter of course. However, the Committee still feels that the Australian Government should make very sure that the arrangements entered into last year relating to cost, offset and Australian industry participation continue to be fair and equitable. The Committee in its report had this to say about the F18:

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting that the estimated $2,430m which Australia was expected to pay for 75 aircraft has already been significantly increased by the 20 per cent devaluation of the Australian dollar against the US dollar since August 1981. The Committee also wishes to point out that given that by 1983-84, projected spending on the FA18s will almost equal the total spent on all new defence equipment in 1981-82, it is obvious that the cost of FA18 procurement between 1983-84 and 1989-90 will place great strains on the Budget.

Virtual doubling of the proportion allocated to capital equipment would achieve the 25 per cent goal set by the Government in early 1980. Whether the goal is feasible might be a matter for examination at future Committee hearings.

Another issue on which I might make some remarks regarding the Department of Defence is the VIP Boeing 707 fleet. It has been revealed during the Estimates committee meetings over the past few years that the Australian Government has paid excessive amounts of money to have the 707 pilots trained on 707 simulators in Hong Kong. The reason they have to go to Hong Kong for this training is that no airline, with I think the exception of Air Niugini, operates commercial 707s into Australia at the moment, with the result that we do not have the appropriate equipment. The nearest equipment suitable for the training of the pilots happens to be in Hong Kong. During the Estimates Committee hearing it was revealed that $216,000 was spent in the previous year for overseas training, $66 ,000 was spent on simulator training and $150,000 was spent on travel expenses.

I have raised in the chamber for many years why it is that we are continuing to use these 707s when smaller planes, such as the BAC111s, would fulfil the same function at a much cheaper cost. I have pointed out here in successive years that if it is good enough for the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) to be able to take a BAC111 from Australia to the Middle East and back we should be able to modify the planes we have at the moment and do away with the expensive 707s. The editorial that appeared in the Australian of 4 August 1982 gives a very good idea of how the Australian feels about the VIP fleet. The editorial contained these words:

The cost of salaries and allowances for the PM's staff has jumped by almost 50 per cent in the past year, to $759,025 a year . . . Cabinet costs have also risen sharply, as have the costs of staffs of other Ministers.
The editorial continued:

These costs do not include the ludicrously expensive VIP fleet of aircraft, which stand by on the tarmac at Fairbairn to whisk Ministers away to lunches in Sydney and Melbourne where RAAF pilots have to await their masters' pleasures. Countries in a much better financial state than Australia make their politicians travel on commercial jets. Why not Australian Ministers? Mr Fraser is fond of lecturing others on how they should tighten their belts. He should set an example in his own office.

The 707s are being phased out all over the world and it appears that Cathay Pacific will shortly close down its simulator in Hong Kong. During the Estimates committee hearings I inquired about where in future pilots will receive the training which they now do in Hong Kong. I was informed that a decision will have to be made on how the VIP pilots will receive their training in future and that one of the more likely alternatives would be to acquire a simulator at an economic price. It would be interesting to learn just how much the equipment is likely to cost Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I was in my room I heard the biggest load of nonsense I have heard all day in relation to the 707 aircraft. The function of the 707 is to provide a freighting and transport capacity for the Royal Australian Air Force which, if one happened to look at the manifest of the aircraft and their utilisation on an annual basis, would become very clear. They provide a capability for the Air Force that is absolutely essential. I am pleased to see that two more of them are to be bought. Those aircraft will be used in an air refuelling mode. It just happens that we do not have simulators in this country. The proposition that we get rid of those 707s is very wrong for Australia. I hope that, instead of buying another two, we can buy another four so that we will get both an effective freighting component and an air refuelling capability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague Senator Mulvihill, who served on the Estimates Committee D with me, is away from the Senate ill today. He asked me to raise one issue. It concerns the fact that we have been using Singapore facilities for sandblasting and the painting of certain Royal Australian Navy vessels. Senator Mulvihill is concerned about that. He mentioned in a letter to one of the unions concerned that the Government used the magical term 'preventative maintenance'. He said that he thought that the increasing use of facilities of this type could be the thin end of the wedge. Senator Mulvihill , when dealing with this matter in May of this year, said:

SPEECH.PARA: This morning when I read page 7 of the Sydney Daily Telegraph I was stunned to discover that a Singaporean firm called Autoblast Singapore Pty Ltd has a contract to indulge in certain sandblasting and painting of several Australian Navy craft. The contract involves HMAS Stalwart, and I understand the same treatment is to be given to HMAS Stuart, HMAS Parramatta and HMAS Brisbane.
I raise this issue on behalf of Senator Mulvihill and hope that we can get an answer to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the point raised by Senator Sibraa on behalf of Senator Mulvihill-we wish him all the best-I would need to refer that matter to the Department of Defence and obtain a reply. However, I understand that generally the work done in Singapore in respect of sandblasting is a relatively small amount of work on vessels that happen to be visiting the area.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the first point raised by Senator Sibraa in relation to F18 aircraft, I repeat the answer I gave in this place to a question asked by Senator Robert Ray yesterday in connection with the different kinds of uses to which F18s are put. I point out again that the United States Navy was commenting upon the use of the F18 in a mode related to the use of aircraft carriers, which is substantially different from that to which the Royal Australian Air Force intends to put the F18 as a land-based aircraft. It is for those reasons, whilst our attention has been drawn to the problems relating to the United States Navy operations, that clearly we will need to take other considerations into account in our assessment of the aeroplane. I can cite some further information from the Estimates Hansard of 9 September 1982. Apparently the amount spent in respect of sand blasting was of the order of $100,000. Of that sum, $75,000 was to remedy urgent defects which could not be held over until the vessels returned to Australia. That work related to safety, seaworthiness and fighting capability defects which had to be repaired while the ship was away from Australia. A further $25,000 was provided for preventative maintenance, which again was declared essential by the fleet commander at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not respond by way of interjection to the comment made by Senator MacGibbon about the cost of the Boeing 707 aircraft. We have asked in Estimates committees over the last four or five years for the costing of these aircraft. We now have the figures and perhaps early next week when we are in a position to present a table of the costs Senator MacGibbon might agree with our point of view and he might agree with the Australian newspaper that the planes have been ludicrously expensive. I do not intend to take the time of the Senate on this matter tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise under the votes for the Department of Defence Support relates particularly to the expensive inquiry conducted by this Government into the sale of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory following a decision of the so-called Review of Commonwealth Functions in April 1981, and the decision of that inquiry that the factory should be sold. Of course, I am aware that more recently, when an election was thought to be in the offing, the Government abandoned its great principle about selling that factory. It has now announced that Government ownership of the factory will continue. Of course, that is not anything but a glib political solution to the problem of that establishment. During the course of the Senate Select Committee inquiry on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories a number of suggestions were made by the Committee, particularly in the minority report, regarding the administration of the factory, the accounting arrangements of the factory, the orders which were made available to the factory by the Department of Defence and the methods of defence procurement. Suggestions were made about the level of so-called commercial work which the factory might be able to attract in the heavy engineering field to support and reduce the loss to the Government of keeping that factory in business.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister: Has the Government done anything about the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee report and have any steps been taken in relation to any of those matters which I have mentioned? If not, will such steps be taken as soon as possible? In referring to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory I also mention the Lithgow Small Arms Factory and ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs ( Senator Messner) what current orders are available to that establishment from the Department of Defence Support? Insofar as I believe it to be relevant I also ask the same question in relation to the level of orders from the Department of Defence to the Commonwealth Clothing Factory at Coburg, having regard to the fact that in connection with the clothing factory the Department of Defence in its submission to the Senate inquiry specifically recommended its retention and apparently thought that it was a worthwhile establishment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest, if Senator Button agrees, that we will prepare a written answer to his questions and have it incorporated in Hansard at the next available opportunity.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —That is quite all right with me, Mr Temporary Chairman. I do not think that I will be stewing over it over the weekend. After all, it has taken about 10 years to get to this point.

INTERJECT.PARA: Progress reported.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Tasmanian Economy-Social Wage Committee: Pamphlet-Demonstration in Sydney: Alleged Involvement of Australian Broadcasting Commission Announcer

PROCTEXT.PARA: Tasmanian Economy-Social Wage Committee: Pamphlet-Demonstration in Sydney: Alleged Involvement of Australian Broadcasting Commission Announcer
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend to honourable senators and the public a publication entitled Tasmania 'The Squeeze'. This document has been compiled by a group of Tasmanians who are extremely concerned about the severe deterioration of the economic structure of my State and, with that deterioration, the putting into jeopardy of the livelihoods of many Tasmanians and, consequently, the whole way of life which has characterised Tasmania for so many years. The ever- quickening pace of that economic deterioration under the twin impacts of the policies of the Federal Government and the international recession becomes more evident day by day. This ever-quickening pace brings to the average Tasmanian a sense of foreboding.

SPEECH.PARA: One reads in the newspapers today that Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd, which operates a paper and timber mill at Burnie and, indeed, is the foundation for the prosperity of that town and much of the north-west coast of Tasmania, has announced that it will close the pine sawmill with a further loss of 60 jobs . I say 'a further loss' because that announcement comes only two days before 190 people finish work at the East Mill of the paper production section which closes tomorrow. Consequently, this affects the log haulers who supply the timber to that enterprise.

As I say, that is the type of thing Tasmanians read day by day. For that reason , it is important that there be a constructive and positive approach based on a sound and well thought out analysis of the Tasmanian economy. The theme of this publication which comes from a group which calls itself the Social Wage Group is that there is great inherent strength in the Tasmanian economy. That wealth is represented by the great mineral areas of the west coast of Tasmania which would be well known to honourable senators, the tremendous timber resources in the State, the agricultural productivity and the enterprise of those involved in agriculture and, dare I say it, the abundant supplies of electricity based on our great water resources and the skills and flair of Tasmanians. It is interesting to read-this may not be as well known to honourable senators-that the opium poppy industry is a very prosperous new industry for Tasmania. One reads in the Press of this week that there is a secure future for the island's 700 poppy growers, a guaranteed world market with competitive prices under the umbrella of various companies including Johnson and Johnson Pty Ltd. The season' s poppy crop is estimated to involve $5m in earnings to Tasmanian farmers, Tasmania being the only State in Australia where poppy cultivation is permitted for the production of opiate alkaloids. In fact they are grown in the fields around my own small block where I live on the north-west coast. In fact they have been grown on my property.

So there is an inherent strength in the Tasmanian economy, but the fact is that along with that inherent strength is a great dependence for many of the key agricultural and industrial development decisions on people and organisations outside Tasmania. That is not altogether a bad thing and of course one does not advocate that Tasmania be somehow closed off from the benefits which can accrue from investment decisions of those outside Tasmania to put money into a Tasmanian venture. But this dependence on outsiders for decision making creates a situation in which Tasmanians feel, with some justification, that decisions are taken without regard to the impact on the communities which are so fragile and so dependent on perhaps just one particular industry on which a town or a small regional area is based. One has a clear example of that with the closure of the Geeveston pulp mill some days ago where I think-Senator Harradine can indicate whether this is the case-some 350 workers found themselves without employment and without the proper notice and regard for their rights and future which one would have hoped would have characterised an employer with a more sensitive appreciation of its obligations to a Tasmanian work force which had been extremely loyal and efficient in co-operation with the capital put in by that company for the development of that enterprise. Tasmanians are experiencing a decline in economic activity which has come about not only as a result of the decisions of companies and corporations based outside Tasmania but also, it also has to be said, because of decisions by the Federal Government, which has not made sufficient contribution to the real level of moneys available to Tasmania for its public and community resources and activities. One thinks of hospitals, the education sector or, most spectacularly, the area of housing.

It would be out of order for me to go into definitive solutions to the difficulties facing the Tasmanian people. I think the desire of Tasmanians to take control of as much of the investment decision making taking place in regard to the State as is possible can be well understood. Not only is there that desire but also there is a desire for a marshalling of the wealth and funds which arise out of Tasmania but which at the moment can be syphoned off by banks , insurance companies and non-Tasmanian corporations for investment other than in Tasmania. The means that have been suggested in recent weeks, including a detailed proposal by the Tasmanian Leader of the Opposition, Mr Ken Wriedt, include a State development corporation and a State bank to marshal and invest those funds.

As I said, it is not my purpose tonight, nor indeed is it the purpose of the writers of this pamphlet, to proffer definitive solutions, but there is a recognition that when those solutions emerge they can only be based on a sound analysis of Tasmania's economic structure. I believe that this pamphlet, 'The Squeeze', is indeed a step in pursuit of that analysis. It is easily readable. It is to be distributed at a cost of 60c, and that itself is an indication of how importantly the Social Wage Committee regards the distribution of this pamphlet in order that as many Tasmanians as possible come to an understanding of the situation of the State and therefore are able to engage in a process of discussion about its future. It is an encouraging sign that something as positive as this pamphlet should be brought into the public debate about Tasmania's future.

The Social Wage Committee consists of a range of people whom I will not name because they would not want to be particularly singled out. However, representatives of unions and community organisations, having held a seminar in Tasmania during June on the social wage concept, felt that they could make a good contribution by putting such a pamphlet together. They have done a considerable amount of work in order to ensure that their intitial hope is fulfilled in as short a time as possible. They have produced a pamphlet which I am sure will get the wide distribution which its contents deserve. I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — My reason for rising during the adjournment debate is altogether different from that of the last speaker. Of course, the question of employment has been the subject of a great many debates in the Senate. More importantly, it has been the subject of a great deal of consideration elsewhere. It appears Australia is not going to have an early election this year because of the bad back of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I would have thought, frankly, if I am not out of order in saying so, that the Prime Minister would show a great deal of statesmanship if he were to announce within the next week or so that he intends to give away his undoubted advantage of calling a double dissolution before 26 May 1983 and will allow the Parliament to run its full term until December 1983 come what may. That would then challenge the mettle on the Prime Minister and everybody else in the community. He could then say: 'I have given away this advantage. I ask everybody to focus his attention on the social and economic ills which beset this country. ' The Government could then put forward its own views on how these economic and social ills can be overcome.

SPEECH.PARA: Employers also would be put on their mettle-as to whether, even if interest rates do come down, they will employ more labour or will install more technology . I think it behoves the Government to consider whether the investment allowance in fact is inhibiting the employment of labour. One should really question very seriously the installation of new technology in industries which do not have to compete on the international market. The unions would also need to consider, as central to their wage fixing policy, the preservation of jobs. I believe that a consensus along those lines would lead the country towards a recovery. At another time-I know that I would probably be out of order if I did so now-I shall proceed with an analysis of the current situation and my suggestions for, as it were, a community-led recovery, with leadership, as well, from the Prime Minister down.

The point I want to raise, however, has nothing to do with that. I notified the President's office that I would be speaking about it on the adjournment and I have notified the office of the appropriate Minister, the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown). Today, outside of parliament in Sydney there was a very ugly demonstration. That demonstration was encouraged by the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It was mounted by a pro-abortion group, whose telephone number was freely given out early this morning over 2CN and 2JJJ in Sydney by an announcer who made no secret of his pro-abortion views. The news media have carried views of the demonstration today in their evening bulletins.

The situation is that a pro-life group had decided to meet in front of Parliament House for the purpose of supporting a motion that was before the Parliament in respect of a pro-life issue. It would have been expected that that meeting would have been peaceful and it was not anticipated that it would be very large, since the pro-life group concerned had not marshalled the forces that were available to it but was simply there to make a point known both to parliamentarians and to those who would listen.

Early this morning, over 2JJJ which, incidentally, comes to Canberra through 2CN, the disc jockey, or whatever he is, whose name I have-he gave his name at that time-and whose pro-abortion views were certainly not hidden, indicated that those who wanted to turn up at a counter, pro-abortion rally should ring a certain person, whose number the announcer gave. This was all done at your expense, Mr Deputy President, and my expense, over the public airways of the public broadcasting media. I want to know what the Government and the ABC propose to do about that. What action will the ABC take against that sort of incitement to counter demonstration by a disc jockey employed by the ABC, which, in turn, receives its money through vote of the Parliament?

I need not say anything more. I have further details, but I am sure that they will be available in the ABC. The ABC knows precisely what went on. All that I want to know is what action it will take. I appreciate that the Minister at the table the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), is probably totally unaware of this matter, but I would be interested to know by this time next week what action the ABC has taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly respond to the matters raised in the adjournment debate by Senator Tate and Senator Harradine. I wish to acknowledge the measured tone in which Senator Tate addressed the subject of the Tasmanian economy. I agree with him that one of the prerequisites of finding a suitable course of action is to have a careful analysis of the situation. I note the strengths of the Tasmanian economy which he listed and the concerns which he expressed. I agree with him that it is a matter of some complexity which does require analysis. I would quarrel with his comments towards the end of his speech when he referred to decisions of the Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not in a position to give chapter and verse on this subject on the adjournment, but I think any fair-minded person, and I think Senator Tate is that, would acknowledge that there has been considerable attention to the economic situation of Tasmania. Of course in the transport field a lot of action has been taken to try to reduce the relative difficulties faced by Tasmania because it is an island. In terms of investment of Commonwealth money and placement of Commonwealth facilities there has been clear recognition following the Callaghan Inquiry into the Structure of Industry and the Employment Situation in Tasmania of the need to do things which perhaps historically were not done in Tasmania. I refer to the placement of institutions and to ensuring that an adequate share of funding goes to that island State. I was particularly conscious of this because I cam- paigned with Mr Hodgman in his electorate. He had a pamphlet which was headed '50 million reasons why you should vote for Hodgman'. It related to the $50m invested in his electorate of Denison during his term of office. That may be a fairly broad way of demonstrating the point I am making.

In response to Senator Tate I suggest that there has been a high degree of recognition on the part of the Federal Government of the difficulties suffered by Tasmania. As a result, particular policies have been directed in that respect . In addition to suggesting to Senator Tate that he might make sure that the pamphlet to which he has referred is in the hands of Government representatives of Tasmania as well as Opposition representatives, if the Social Wage Committee has not already done so, I will request either the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) or the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), both of whom represent Tasmania in the House of Representatives, to provide some information to Senator Tate on the various measures which have been taken to provide adequately for Tasmania. I do not suggest that they would be provided on the basis that nothing more needed to be done. I think it is common ground around the place that there are considerable economic difficulties for the world , for Australia and for Tasmania. I would welcome attempts at analysis of the sort which Senator Tate has said is proceeding in Tasmania. I also welcome Senator Harradine's suggestion that he will at a later time set down his views on what action can be taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already done so in a number of areas outside.

—My point really is that I do not think anybody, whether the Government, the Treasury or whatever, has a monopoly of wisdom in this area.We can look around the world to see the different approaches adopted in other countries. For example, France changed its economic approach recently to some negative effect to some positive effect. It is quite clear there are no panaceas available and we should be prepared to both analyse and seek better solutions.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the other point raised by Senator Harradine is concerned, I must say that I did not hear any of the broadcast to which he referred. I have no advice from the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown). I can understand Senator Harradine's concern that a publicly funded body should adopt a partisan and, effectively, an advertising viewpoint, in that situation-if that is in fact what occurred. On Senator Harradine's description it does not sound a very satisfactory course of conduct. I have little doubt that soon we will be vigorously debating the Government's legislation on the Australian Broadcasting Commission. People will be alleging how horrific it is that we should have any mechanism to check bias in that exalted organisation. Perhaps some of these comments on the adjournment will be recalled during the consideration of that legislation. I must not get involved in that debate now. I will seek a response from the Minister for Communications with respect to the inquiry raised by Senator Harradine. I note that Senator Harradine would like that response within a week, if possible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.20 p.m. until 1.45 p.m., on Tuesday, 16 November 1982.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 15 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress has been made in negotiations with the Western Australian Government with regard to returning the Monte Bello Islands to the control of that State.
(2) Will the Commonwealth's prohibition under the Defence (Special Undertakings ) Act be lifted, if and when the Monte Bello Islands are returned to State control.

(3) With what frequency are tests conducted to determine radiation levels in the area, and what has been the result of recent tests, are the radiation levels considered safe enough to allow public access to the islands, and are there any factors other than radiation which justify the restriction of public access to the islands, if so, what are they.
(4) Will the Federal Government consider making access for recreational purposes to those areas where no radiation is detectable.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Discussions have been held between Commonwealth and State officials concerning the conditions which might be attached to a transfer of control of the Monte Bello Islands. Proposals by State authorities for management of the islands are currently being considered by the Commonwealth.

(2) Revocation of the Commonwealth declaration under the Defence (Special Undertakings) Act 1952, which controls public access to the islands and their waters will be considered as soon as agreement is reached between the Commonwealth and State on the management plans referred to in (1).

(3) In 1962, 1968 and 1972 radiological surveys of the Islands were made for the Atomic Weapons Tests Safety Committee. In 1978, a further radiological survey was undertaken on behalf of the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council (AIRAC) whose subsequent report, AIRAC Report No. 5 ''Radiological Safety and Future Land Use in the Monte Bello Islands'', dated August 1979, was tabled in Parliament. This report, which is the prime reference point for Commonwealth/State consultations on questions of radiological safety and land use in the Monte Bello Islands, addresses the several questions raised. AIRAC has been requested to update its 1978 survey and a further radiological survey of the Monte Bello Islands will be carried out in 1982-83.

(4) The Naval Officer Commanding, West Australia Area (NOCWA) is responsible for the control of access to the gazetted Prohibited Area surrounding the Islands and their waters. For some time now, NOCWA has granted access approval on a case-by-case basis for recreational visits to specified areas within the Prohibited Area. These approvals however, do not extend into designated areas in the vicinity of ground zeros on Alpha and Trimouille Islands and adjacent waters . Persons seeking access to the Monte Bello Islands or adjacent waters should contact the Naval Officer Commanding, West Australia Area, PO Box 228, Rockingham, WA 6168.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 12 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it currently possible to safely diagnose and isolate viruses from Australian stock showing mucosal disease symptoms near the affected stock without the aid of imported live viruses.

(2) Can immuno-assay tests be conducted using antisera supplied by overseas laboratories; if so, why is live foot and mouth disease virus being imported into Australia when quarantine, slaughter and disinfection are the recognised defences against this disease which can be diagnosed through basic serological testing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australian livestock showing clinical signs suggestive of mucosal disease may be affected by any of several important exotic or endemic diseases. Their accurate differential diagnosis requires a range of diagnostic tests which can only be carried out reliably in a specialised laboratory. It is unlikely that makeshift facilities would have the necessary specialised equipment operating efficiently and effectively to undertake a truly satisfactory diagnosis.
It would be possible to safely perform a number of tests and attempt to isolate viruses near the affected stock without the aid of imported viruses.

The results obtained under such conditions are likely to be affected by the vagaries of climate and weather and temporary equipment and would not carry the accuracy or reliability of a diagnosis carried out in a laboratory under controlled environmental conditions.
The range of tests that could be used under such circumstances would be limited and this would have a bearing on the accuracy of the diagnosis.

Any such testing, virus isolation and diagnosis would need to be undertaken by experienced personnel. It would be quicker and more reliable to transport samples to a permanent and secure laboratory, to enable the full range of diagnostic tests to be undertaken, than to transport facilities and personnel to the site of affected stock.
Results, particularly negative results, obtained under makeshift conditions as proposed, would lack international credibility.

(2) Immuno-assay tests can be conducted using antisera supplied by overseas laboratories. These antisera would first need to be treated and tested to ensure that they contained no exotic disease contaminants.
Quarantine, slaughter and disinfection are the recognised means to combat foot and mouth disease and this is unequivocally the firmly approved first policy for Australia.

However, the use of vaccines cannot be disregarded in the event that an outbreak becomes wide-spread or cannot be controlled by conventional means. Vaccination must be considered as an important but secondary control option. Slaughter and disposal of affected herds would continue but vaccination could provide the breathing space to enable slaughter and disposal to overtake spread.

If vaccines have to be used it is preferable and safer for them to be manufactured in Australia. The timely supply of safe and effective vaccines from overseas presents problems as large quantities could be required. Additionally, the importation of vaccines from some countries can be a quarantine risk as they may be contaminated by other exotic animal pathogens.

The process of developing vaccine seeds and substrates for manufacture and scaling-up to production is time-consuming. It is too late to leave this until an exotice disease outbreak has occurred. Developmental work should commence in advance of an outbreak to ensure vaccines are safe and effective by testing their immunity with live virus challenge.

Live foot and mouth disease virus would also be used for research purposes and for training of laboratory and field staff in the diagnosis of foot and mouth disease. Research that has already been done extensively overseas would not be repeated at ANAHL.

Australia has only a small number of veterinarians well trained in the clinical recognition and laboratory diagnosis of exotic diseases. A small number of veterinarians have participated in outbreaks of exotic diseases in overseas countries. Although this is the best form of training, it has to be restricted to small numbers of key people.

No final decision has been made to import live foot and mouth disease virus. This is still dependent upon security checking of ANAHL after the laboratory is completed, continuing consultation with industry and consideration by the Government of new technological developments in this area.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation: Muscular Dystrophy Research

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 20 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the CSIRO Institute of Animal and Food Sciences, Division of Human Nutrition, carry out research on muscular dystrophy; if so, what funds have been allocated to this research over each of the previous five years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Division of Human Nutrition of CSIRO's Institute of Animal and Food Sciences is not currently carrying out research on muscular dystrophy. However, it did investigate this problem from 1978-79 to 1980-81. The work was funded entirely by external grants from the Muscular Dystrophy Association of the United States of America. These grants were discontinued at the end of 1980-81. Expenditure was $US13,980 in 1978-79; $US17,500 in 1979-80; and $US23,200 in 1980-81.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 September 1982 (Hansard, page 620) Senator Chipp asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice concerning South West Tasmania. I undertook to provide him with an answer to the following specific question:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Prime Minister replied to letters from 24 of the world's leading archeaologists received in June.
The Prime Minister has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

Since June 1982 the Prime Minister has received over 6,000 letters on the subject of South West Tasmania, including a number from eminent archeologists and anthropologists. Replies to all these letters are under consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 October 1983 (Hansard, page 1851) Senator Robertson asked me a question without notice regarding the proposed rehabilitation of the Rum Jungle area, and whether water in the Finniss River will be suitable for stock, agriculture and horticulture when the rehabilitation program has been completed.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to obtain further advice and my answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The Commonwealth has agreed with the broad objectives of a rehabilitation program proposed by the Northern Territory Government subject to satisfactory arrangements and procedures being agreed between the two Governments. The Northern Territory estimates the proposed program of works to cost $16.2m in June 1982 prices over four financial years, which is comparable with the Commonwealth's earlier estimate of $12.1m based on 1980 prices. An amount of $ 800,000 has been appropriated in 1982-83 for commencement of works.

Following completion of rehabilitation works, water quality in the Finnis River will be suitable for stock, agriculture and horticulture use. However, in the east branch of the Finniss River which does not flow continuously throughout the year, some natural deterioration of water quality will occur during the dry season as happens in other intermittent streams in the Northern Territory. Thus at the end of the dry season, any remaining water in pools in the east branch may not be suitable for all purposes.
